<<PAGE_56>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-32
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.8
Creep and Stress Rupture<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.8.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
At high temperatures, metal components can slowly and continuously deform under load below the
yield stress. This time dependent deformation of stressed components is known as creep.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Deformation leads to damage that may eventually lead to a rupture.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.8.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>All metals and alloys.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.8.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The rate of creep deformation is a function of the material, load, and temperature.  The rate of
damage (strain rate) is sensitive to both load and temperature.  Generally, an increase of about 25°F
(12°C) or an increase of 15% on stress can cut the remaining life in half or more, depending on the
alloy.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Table 4-3  lists threshold temperatures above which creep damage is a concern.  If the metal
temperature exceeds these values, then creep damage and creep cracking can occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The level of creep damage is a function of the material and the coincident temperature/stress level at
which the creep deformation occurs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The life of metal components becomes nearly infinite at temperatures below the threshold limit
( Table 4-3 ) even at the high stresses near a crack tip.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The appearance of creep damage with little or no apparent deformation is often mistakenly referred
to as creep embrittlement, but usually indicates that the material has low creep ductility.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Low creep ductility is:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
More severe for higher tensile strength materials and welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
More prevalent at the lower temperatures in the creep range, or low stresses in the upper creep
range.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
More likely in a coarse-grained material than a fine-grained material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Not evidenced by a deterioration of ambient temperature properties.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Promoted by certain carbide types in some CrMo steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Increased stress due to loss in thickness from corrosion will reduce time to failure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.8.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Creep damage is found in high temperature equipment operating above the creep range.  Heater
tubes in fired heaters are especially susceptible as well as tube supports, hangers and other furnace
internals.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Piping and equipment, such as hot-wall catalytic reforming reactors and furnace tubes, hydrogen
reforming furnace tubes, hot wall FCC reactors, FCC main fractionator and regenerator internals all
operate in or near the creep range.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Low creep ductility failures have occurred in weld heat-affected zones (HAZ) at nozzles and other
high stress areas on catalytic reformer reactors. Cracking has also been found at long seam welds in
some high temperature piping and in reactors on catalytic reformers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Welds joining dissimilar materials (ferritic to austenitic welds) may suffer creep related damage at
high temperatures due to differential thermal expansion stresses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_57>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-33
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.8.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The initial stages of creep damage can only be identified by scanning electron microscope
metallography.  Creep voids typically show up at the grain boundaries and in later stages form
fissures and then cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
At temperatures well above the threshold limits, noticeable deformation may be observed.  For
example, heater tubes may suffer long term creep damage and exhibit significant bulging before final
fracture occurs. The amount of deformation is highly dependent on the material, and the combination
of temperature and stress level ( Figure 4-17  to  4-19 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In vessels and piping, creep cracking can occur where high metal temperatures and stress
concentrations occur together, such as near major structural discontinuities including pipe tee joints,
nozzles, or welds at flaws.  Creep cracking, once initiated, can progress rapidly.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.8.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
There is little that inspectors or operators can do to prevent this damage once a susceptible material
has been placed into creep service, other than to minimize the metal temperature, particularly with
fired heater tubes.  Avoiding stress concentrators is important during design and fabrication.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Low creep ductility can be minimized by the careful selection of chemistry for low alloy materials.
Higher post weld heat treatment temperatures may help minimize creep cracking of materials with
low creep ductility such as 1.25Cr-0.5Mo.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Creep damage is not reversible.  Once damage or cracking is detected much of the life of the
component has been used up and typically the options are to repair or replace the damaged
component.  Higher PWHT in some cases can produce a more creep ductile material with longer life.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Equipment – Repair of creep damaged catalytic reformer reactor nozzles has been successfully
accomplished by grinding out the affected area (making sure all the damaged metal is
removed), re-welding and careful blend grinding to help minimize stress concentration.  PWHT
temperatures must be carefully selected and may require a higher PWHT than originally
specified.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Fired Heater Tubes<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Alloys with improved creep resistance may be required for longer life.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Heaters should be designed and operated to minimize hot spots and localized overheating
( Figure 4-19 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Visual inspection followed by thickness measurements and or strap readings may be
required to assess remaining life of heater tubes in accordance with API 579-1/ASME FFS-
1 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Minimizing process side fouling/deposits and fire side deposits/scaling can maximize tube
life.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.8.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Creep damage with the associated microvoid formation, fissuring and dimensional changes is not
effectively found by any one inspection technique.  A combination of techniques (UT, RT, EC,
dimensional measurements and replication) should be employed.  Destructive sampling and
metallographic examination are used to confirm damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
For pressure vessels, inspection should focus on welds of CrMo alloys operating in the creep range.
The 1 Cr-0.5Mo and 1.25Cr-0.5Mo materials are particularly prone to low creep ductility.  Most
inspections are performed visually and followed by PT or WFMT on several-year intervals.  Angle
beam (shear wave) UT can also be employed, although the early stages of creep damage are very
difficult to detect.  Initial fabrication flaws should be mapped and documented for future reference.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_58>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-34
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Fired heater tubes should be inspected for evidence of overheating, corrosion, and erosion as
follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Tubes should be VT examined for bulging, blistering, cracking, sagging and bowing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Wall thickness measurements of selected heater tubes should be made where wall losses are
most likely to occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Tubes should be examined for evidence of diametric growth (creep) with a strap or go/no go
gauge, and in limited cases by metallography on in place replicas or tube samples.  However,
metallography on the OD of a component may not provide a clear indication of subsurface
damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Retirement criteria based on diametric growth and loss of wall thickness is highly dependent on
the tube material and the specific operating conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.8.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Creep damage that occurs as a result of exposure to very high temperatures is described in  4.2.10 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Reheat cracking (see  4.2.19 ) is a related mechanism found in heavy wall equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.2.8.9
References
1. API 579-1/ASME FFS-1 2007  Fitness-For-Service , American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.,
2007
2. API Standard 530, Calculation of Heater Tube Thickness in Petroleum Refineries, American
Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.
3. API Standard 660, Shell and Tube Heat Exchangers for General Refinery Service, American
Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_63>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-39
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.9
Thermal Fatigue<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.9.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Thermal fatigue is the result of cyclic stresses caused by variations in temperature.  Damage is in the
form of cracking that may occur anywhere in a metallic component where relative movement or
differential expansion is constrained, particularly under repeated thermal cycling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.9.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All materials of construction.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.9.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Key factors affecting thermal fatigue are the magnitude of the temperature swing and the frequency
(number of cycles).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Time to failure is a function of the magnitude of the stress and the number of cycles and decreases
with increasing stress and increasing cycles.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Startup and shutdown of equipment increase the susceptibility to thermal fatigue.  There is no set
limit on temperature swings; however, as a practical rule, cracking may be suspected if the
temperature swings exceeds about 200°F (93°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Damage is also promoted by rapid changes in surface temperature that result in a thermal gradient
through the thickness or along the length of a component. For example: cold water on a hot tube
(thermal shock); rigid attachments and a smaller temperature differential; inflexibility to
accommodate differential expansion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Notches (such as the toe of a weld) and sharp corners (such as the intersection of a nozzle with a
vessel shell) and other stress concentrations may serve as initiation sites.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.9.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Examples include the mix points of hot and cold streams such as hydrogen mix points in
hydroprocessing units, and locations where condensate comes in contact with steam systems, such
as de-superheating or attemporating equipment ( Figures 4-20  and  4-23 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Thermal fatigue cracking has been a major problem in coke drum shells.  Thermal fatigue can also
occur on coke drum skirts where stresses are promoted by a variation in temperature between the
drum and skirt ( Figure 4–21  and  Figure 4–22 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In steam generating equipment, the most common locations are at rigid attachments between
neighboring tubes in the superheater and reheater.  Slip spacers designed to accommodate relative
movement may become frozen and act as a rigid attachment when plugged with fly ash.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Tubes in the high temperature superheater or reheater that penetrate through the cooler waterwall
tubes may crack at the header connection if the tube is not sufficiently flexible.  These cracks are
most common at the end where the expansion of the header relative to the waterwall will be greatest.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Steam actuated soot blowers may cause thermal fatigue damage if the first steam exiting the soot
blower nozzle contains condensate.  Rapid cooling of the tube by the liquid water will promote this
form of damage.  Similarly, water lancing or water cannon use on waterwall tubes may have the
same effect.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_64>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-40
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.9.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Thermal fatigue cracks usually initiate on the surface of the component. They are generally wide and
often filled with oxides due to elevated temperature exposure.  Cracks may occur as single or
multiple cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Thermal fatigue cracks propagate transverse to the stress and they are usually dagger-shaped,
transgranular, and oxide filled ( Figure 4-24  and  4-25 ).  However, cracking may be axial or
circumferential, or both, at the same location.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In steam generating equipment, cracks usually follow the toe of the fillet weld, as the change in
section thickness creates a stress raiser. Cracks often start at the end of an attachment lug and if
there is a bending moment as a result of the constraint, they will develop into circumferential cracks
into the tube.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d )
Water in soot blowers may lead to a crazing pattern. The predominant cracks will be circumferential
and the minor cracks will be axial.  ( Figure 4-26  to  4-27 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.9.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Thermal fatigue is best prevented through design and operation to minimize thermal stresses and
thermal cycling.  Several methods of prevention apply depending on the application.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Designs that incorporate reduction of stress concentrators, blend grinding of weld profiles, and
smooth transitions should be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Controlled rates of heating and cooling during startup and shutdown of equipment can lower
stresses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Differential thermal expansion between adjoining components of dissimilar materials should be
considered.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Designs should incorporate sufficient flexibility to accommodate differential expansion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
In steam generating equipment, slip spacers should slip and rigid attachments should be
avoided.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Drain lines should be provided on soot-blowers to prevent condensate in the first portion of the
soot blowing cycle.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In some cases, a liner or sleeve may be installed to prevent a colder liquid from contacting the hotter
pressure boundary wall<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.9.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Since cracking is usually surface connected, visual examination, MT and PT are effective methods of
inspection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
External SWUT inspection can be used for non-intrusive inspection for internal cracking and where
reinforcing pads prevent nozzle examination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Heavy wall reactor internal attachment welds can be inspected using specialized ultrasonic
techniques.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.9.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Corrosion fatigue (see  4.5.2 ) and dissimilar metal weld cracking (see  4.2.12 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |

<<PAGE_70>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-46
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.10 Short Term Overheating – Stress Rupture<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.10.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Permanent deformation occurring at relatively low stress levels as a result of localized overheating. This
usually results in bulging and eventually failure by stress rupture.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.10.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All fired heater tube materials and common materials of construction.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.10.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Temperature, time and stress are critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Usually due to flame impingement or local overheating.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Time to failure will increase as internal pressures or loading decrease. However, bulging and
distortion can be significant at low stresses, as temperatures increase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Local overheating above the design temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Loss in thickness due to corrosion will reduce time to failure by increasing the stress.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.10.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All boiler and fired heater tubes are susceptible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Furnaces with coking tendencies such as crude, vacuum, heavy oil hydroprocessing and coker units
are often fired harder to maintain heater outlet temperatures and are more susceptible to localized
overheating.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Hydroprocessing reactors may be susceptible to localized overheating of reactor beds due to
inadequate hydrogen quench or flow maldistribution.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Refractory lined equipment in the FCC, sulfur plant and other units may suffer localized overheating
due to refractory damage and/or excessive firing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.10.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Damage is typically characterized by localized deformation or bulging on the order of 3% to 10% or
more, depending on the alloy, temperature and stress level.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Ruptures are characterized by open “fishmouth” failures and are usually accompanied by thinning at
the fracture surface ( Figure 4-28  to  4-31 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.10.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Minimize localized temperature excursions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Fired heaters require proper burner management and fouling/deposit control to minimize hot spots
and localized overheating.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Utilize burners which produce a more diffuse flame pattern.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In hydroprocessing equipment, install and maintain bed thermocouples in reactors and minimize the
likelihood of hot spots through proper design and operation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Maintain refractory in serviceable condition in refractory lined equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_71>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-47
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.10.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
In fired heaters, visual observation, IR monitoring of tubes and tubeskin thermocouples are used to
monitor temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Refractory lined equipment can be monitored with heat indicating paint and periodic IR scans.
Inspect for refractory damage during shutdowns.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Maintain and monitor reactor bed thermocouples as well as reactor skin thermocouples.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.10.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Creep/stress rupture (see  4.2.8 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.2.10.9
References
1. API 579-1/ASME FFS-1 2007  Fitness-For-Service , American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.,
2007
2. API Standard 530, Calculation of Heater Tube Thickness in Petroleum Refineries, American
Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.
3. API Standard 660, Shell and Tube Heat Exchangers for General Refinery Service, American
Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_75>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-51
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.11 Steam Blanketing<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.11.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The operation of steam generating equipment is a balance between the heat flow from the combustion of
the fuel and the generation of steam within the waterwall or generating tube. The flow of heat energy
through the wall of the tube results in the formation of discrete steam bubbles (nucleate boiling) on the ID
surface. The moving fluid sweeps the bubbles away.  When the heat flow balance is disturbed, individual
bubbles join to form a steam blanket, a condition known as Departure From Nucleate Boiling (DNB).
Once a steam blanket forms, tube rupture can occur rapidly, as a result of short term overheating, usually
within a few minutes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.11.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel and low alloy steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.11.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Heat flux and fluid flow are critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Flame impingement from misdirected or damaged burners can provide a heat flux greater than the
steam generating tube can accommodate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
On the water side, anything that restricts fluid flow (for example, pinhole leaks lower in the steam
circuit or dented tubes from slag falls) will reduce fluid flow and can lead to DNB conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Failure occurs as a result of the hoop stress in the tube from the internal steam pressure at the
elevated temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.11.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All steam-generating units including fired boilers, waste heat exchangers in sulfur plants, hydrogen
reformers and FCC units.  Failures can occur in superheaters and reheaters during start-up when
condensate blocks steam flow.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.11.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
These short-term, high-temperature failures always show an open burst with the fracture edges
drawn to a near knife-edge ( Figure 4-32 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The microstructure will always show severe elongation of the grain structure due to the plastic
deformation that occurs at the time of failure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.11.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
When a DNB condition has developed, tube rupture will quickly follow.  Proper burner management
should be practiced to minimize flame impingement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Proper BFW treatment can help prevent some conditions that can lead to restricted fluid flow.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Tubes should be visually inspected for bulging.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.11.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Burners  should be properly maintained to prevent flame impingement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.11.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Steam blanketing can cause caustic corrosion (caustic gouging) as outlined in  4.3.10 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Very similar characteristics are observed in short term overheating (see  4.2.10 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

2. “Combustion Fossil Power Systems,” Third Edition, Combustion Engineering, CT, 1981.

<<PARAGRAPH>>4-54
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.12 Dissimilar Metal Weld (DMW) Cracking<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.12.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Cracking of dissimilar metal welds occurs in the ferritic (carbon steel or low alloy steel) side of a weld
between an austenitic (300 Series SS or Nickel base alloy) and a ferritic material operating at high
temperature ( Figure 4-33  and  4-44 ).  Cracking can result from creep damage, from fatigue cracking, from
sulfide stress cracking or hydrogen disbonding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.12.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The most common are ferritic materials such as carbon steel and low alloy steels that are welded to the
austenitic stainless steels as well as any material combinations that have widely differing thermal
expansion coefficients.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.12.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Important factors include the type of filler metal used to join the materials, heating and cooling rate,
metal temperature, time at temperature, weld geometry and thermal cycling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracking can occur because of the different coefficients of thermal expansion between ferritic and
austenitic (e.g. 300 Series stainless steel or nickel-base alloys) which differ by about 25 to 30% or
more. At high operating temperatures, the differences in thermal expansion leads to high stress at
the heat-affected zone on the ferritic side ( Table 4-4 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
As the operating temperature increases, differential thermal expansion between the metals results in
increasing stress at the weldment, particularly if a 300 Series SS weld metal is used.
Ferritic/austenitic joints can generate significant thermal expansion/thermal fatigue stresses at
temperatures greater than 510°F (260°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Thermal cycling aggravates the problem. Stresses during start up and shut down can be significant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Stresses acting on the weldment are significantly higher when an austenitic stainless steel filler metal
is used.  A nickel base filler metal has a coefficient of thermal expansion that is closer to carbon
steel, resulting in significantly lower stress at elevated temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
For dissimilar welds that operate at elevated temperatures, the problem is aggravated by the
diffusion of carbon out of the heat-affected zone of the ferritic material and into the weld metal.  The
loss of carbon reduces the creep strength of the ferritic material heat-affected zone, thereby
increasing the cracking probability ( Figure 4-35 ). The temperature at which carbon diffusion
becomes a concern is above 800°F to 950°F (427°C to 510°C) for carbon steels and low alloy steels,
respectively.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Dissimilar metal welds on a ferritic steel that are made with a 300 Series SS weld metal or a nickel-
based filler metal result in a narrow region (mixed zone) of high hardness at the toe of the weld, near
the fusion line on the ferritic steel side.  These high hardness zones render the material susceptible
to various forms of environmental cracking such as sulfide stress cracking or hydrogen stress
cracking ( Figures 4-36  and  4-37 ).  PWHT of the weldment will not prevent environmental cracking if
the weld is exposed to wet H 2 S conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
DMW’s for high temperature service in hydrogen environments must be carefully designed and
inspected to prevent hydrogen disbonding ( Figures 4-38  to  4-41 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
In environments that promote liquid ash corrosion, weld cracking problems may be accelerated by
stress-assisted corrosion. The ferritic heat-affected zone will preferentially corrode due to the large
thermal strain.  The results are long, narrow, oxide wedges that parallel the fusion line of the weld
( Figure 4-42 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>j)
Poor geometry of the weld, excessive undercut, and other stress intensification factors will promote
crack formation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>

| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_79>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-55
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.12.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Dissimilar metal welds are utilized in special applications in refineries and other process plants.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Examples of DMW’s include:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Welds used to join clad pipe in locations such as transitions in hydroprocessing reactor
outlet piping from overlaid low alloy CrMo nozzles or piping to solid 300 Series stainless
steel pipe.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Hydroprocessing exchanger inlet and outlet piping.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Alloy transitions inside fired heaters (e.g. 9Cr to 317L in a crude furnace)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Hydrogen reformer  furnace 1.25 Cr inlet pigtails to Alloy 800 sockolets or weldolets on
Hydrogen reformer tubes<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Hydrogen reformer furnace Alloy 800 outlet cones to CS or 1.25 Cr refractory lined transfer
lines.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Alloy transitions inside fired heaters (e.g. 9Cr to 317L in a crude or vacuum furnace)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Welds joining clad pipe sections to themselves or to unclad carbon or low alloy steel pipe
(e.g. Alloy C276 clad CS piping in crude unit overhead system)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Nickel base alloy welds joining socket weld valves in 5 and 9 Cr piping systems<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
300 series SS weld overlay in numerous refinery reactors and pressure vessels<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Similar DMWs have been used in FCCU reactors and regenerator vessels and in Coker
Units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
All superheaters and reheaters that have welds between ferritic materials (1.25Cr-0.5Mo and 2.25Cr-
1Mo) and the austenitic materials (300 Series SS, 304H, 321H and 347H).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.12.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
In most cases, the cracks form at the toe of the weld in the heat-affected zone of the ferritic material
( Figure 4-36  to  Figure 4-42 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Welds joining tubes are the most common problem area, but support lugs or attachments of cast or
wrought 300 Series SS to 400 Series SS are also affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.12.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For high temperature applications, nickel base filler metals which have a coefficient of thermal
expansion closer to carbon steel and low alloy steels may dramatically increase the life of the joint,
because of the significant reduction in thermal stress acting on the steel (ferritic) side of the joint.
Refer to API 577 and API 582 for additional information on filler metal selection, welding procedures
and weld inspection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
If 300 Series SS welding electrodes are used, the dissimilar metal weld should be located in a low
temperature region.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Consider buttering the ferritic side of the joint with the SS or nickel base filler metal and perform
PWHT prior to completing the DMW to minimize the hardness of the mixed weld zone in order to
minimize susceptibility to environmental cracking. See  Figure 4-34  and  4-35 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
On buttered joints, the thickness of the weld metal should be a minimum of 0.25 inch (6.35 mm)
after the bevel is machined.   Figure 4-35 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
In steam generating equipment, the weld at the high temperature end should be made in the
penthouse or header enclosure, out of the heat transfer zone.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>

<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_80>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-56
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
For high temperature installations, consider Installing a pup piece that has an intermediate thermal
expansion coefficient between the two materials to be joined.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.12.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The following elements should be considered for non-destructive examination of critical dissimilar
butt welds before they are put into service:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
100% PT after buttering and completion<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
100% UT on butter layer after PWHT (check bonding)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
100% RT<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
100% UT – recordable<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
PMI<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
For dissimilar welds in fired heater tubes, RT and UT shear wave inspection should be performed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Environmental cracking will also result in surface breaking cracks initiating on the ID surface
exposed to the corrosive environment, which can be detected using WFMT or external SWUT
methods.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.12.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Thermal fatigue (see  4.2.9 ), corrosion fatigue (see  4.5.2 ), creep (see  4.2.8 ), and sulfide stress cracking
(see  5.1.2.3 .)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.2.12.9

<<PAGE_87>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-63
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.13 Thermal Shock<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.13.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A form of thermal fatigue cracking – thermal shock – can occur when high and non-uniform thermal
stresses develop over a relatively short time in a piece of equipment due to differential expansion or
contraction.  If the thermal expansion/contraction is restrained, stresses above the yield strength of the
material can result.  Thermal shock usually occurs when a colder liquid contacts a warmer metal surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.13.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All metals and alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.13.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The magnitude of the temperature differential and the coefficient of thermal expansion of the material
determine the magnitude of the stress.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cyclic stresses generated by temperature cycling of the material may initiate fatigue cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Stainless steels have higher coefficients of thermal expansion than carbon and alloy steels or nickel
base alloys and are more likely to see higher stresses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
High temperature exposure during a fire.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Temperature changes that can result from water quenching as a result of rain deluges.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Fracture is related to constraint on a component that prevents the component from expanding or
contracting with a change in temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Cracking in cast components such as valves may initiate at casting flaws on the ID and progress
through the thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Thick sections can develop high thermal gradients.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.13.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
FCC, cokers, catalytic reforming and high severity hydroprocessing units are high temperature units
where thermal shock is possible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
High temperature piping and equipment in any unit can be affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Materials that have lost ductility, such as CrMo equipment (temper embrittlement) are particularly
susceptible to thermal shock.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Equipment subjected to accelerated cooling procedures to minimize shutdown time.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.13.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Surface initiating cracks may also appear as “craze” cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.13.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Prevent interruptions in the flow of high temperature lines.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Design to minimize severe restraint.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Install thermal sleeves to prevent liquid impingement on the pressure boundary components.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Minimize rain or fire water deluge situations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Review hot/cold injection points for potential thermal shock.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>4-64
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.13.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
This type of damage is highly localized and difficult to locate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
PT and MT can be used to confirm cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.13.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Thermal fatigue (see  4.2.9 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.2.13.9

<<PAGE_89>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-65
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.14 Erosion/Erosion – Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.14.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Erosion is the accelerated mechanical removal of surface material as a result of relative movement
between, or impact from solids, liquids, vapor or any combination thereof.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Erosion-corrosion is a description for the damage that occurs when corrosion contributes to erosion
by removing protective films or scales, or by exposing the metal surface to further corrosion under
the combined action of erosion and corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.14.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All metals, alloys and refractories.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.14.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
In most cases, corrosion plays some role so that pure erosion (sometimes referred to as abrasive
wear) is rare.  It is critical to consider the role that corrosion contributes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Metal loss rates depend on the velocity and concentration of impacting medium (i.e., particles,
liquids, droplets, slurries, two-phase flow), the size and hardness of impacting particles, the hardness
and corrosion resistance of material subject to erosion, and the angle of impact.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Softer alloys such as copper and aluminum alloys that are easily worn from mechanical damage may
be subject to severe metal loss under high velocity conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Although increasing hardness of the metal substrate is a common approach to minimize damage, it
is not always a good indicator of improved resistance to erosion, particularly where corrosion plays a
significant role.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
For each environment-material combination, there is often a threshold velocity above which
impacting objects may produce metal loss.  Increasing velocities above this threshold result in an
increase in metal loss rates as shown in  Table 4-5 .  This table illustrates the relative susceptibility of
a variety of metals and alloys to erosion/corrosion by seawater at different velocities.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
The size, shape, density and hardness of the impacting medium affect the metal loss rate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Increasing the corrosivity of the environment may reduce the stability of protective surface films and
increase the susceptibility to metal loss. Metal may be removed from the surface as dissolved ions,
or as solid corrosion products which are mechanically swept from the metal surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Factors which contribute to an increase in corrosivity of the environment, such as temperature, pH,
etc., can increase susceptibility to metal loss.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.14.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All types of equipment exposed to moving fluids and/or catalyst are subject to erosion and erosion-
corrosion. This includes piping systems, particularly the bends, elbows, tees and reducers; piping
systems downstream of letdown valves and block valves; pumps; blowers; propellers; impellers;
agitators; agitated vessels; heat exchanger tubing; measuring device orifices; turbine blades;
nozzles; ducts and vapor lines; scrapers; cutters; and wear plates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Erosion can be caused by gas borne catalyst particles or by particles carried by a liquid such as a
slurry.  In refineries, this form of damage occurs as a result of catalyst movement in FCC
reactor/regenerator systems in catalyst handling equipment (valves, cyclones, piping, reactors) and
slurry piping ( Figure 4-43 ); coke handling equipment in both delayed and fluidized bed cokers
( Figure 4-44 ); and as wear on pumps ( Figure 4-45 ), compressors and other rotating equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Hydroprocessing reactor effluent piping may be subject to erosion-corrosion by ammonium bisulfide.
The metal loss is dependent on several factors including the ammonium bisulfide concentration,
velocity and alloy corrosion resistance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_90>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-66
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Crude and vacuum unit piping and vessels exposed to naphthenic acids in some crude oils may
suffer severe erosion-corrosion metal loss depending on the temperature, velocity, sulfur content and
TAN level.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.14.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Erosion and erosion-corrosion are characterized by a localized loss in thickness in the form of pits,
grooves, gullies, waves, rounded holes and valleys. These losses often exhibit a directional pattern.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Failures can occur in a relatively short time.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.14.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Improvements in design involve changes in shape, geometry and materials selection. Some
examples are: increasing the pipe diameter to decrease velocity; streamlining bends to reduce
impingement; increasing the wall thickness; and using replaceable impingement baffles.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Improved resistance to erosion is usually achieved through increasing substrate hardness using
harder alloys, hardfacing or surface-hardening treatments.  Erosion resistant refractories in cyclones
and slide valves have been very successful.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Erosion-corrosion is best mitigated by using more corrosion-resistant alloys and/or altering the
process environment to reduce corrosivity, for example, deaeration, condensate injection or the
addition of inhibitors.  Resistance is generally not improved through increasing substrate hardness
alone.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Heat exchangers utilize impingement plates and occasionally tube ferrules to minimize erosion
problems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Higher molybdenum containing alloys are used for improved resistance to naphthenic acid corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.14.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Visual examination of suspected or troublesome areas, as well as UT checks or RT can be used to
detect the extent of metal loss.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Specialized corrosion coupons and on-line corrosion monitoring electrical resistance probes have
been used in some applications.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
IR scans are used to detect refractory loss on stream.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.14.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Specialized terminology has been developed for various forms of erosion and erosion-corrosion in
specific environments and/or services. This terminology includes cavitation, liquid impingement erosion,
fretting and other similar terms.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.2.14.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, Volume 13, “Corrosion,” ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
2. ASM Metals Handbook, Volume 11, “Failure Analysis and Prevention,” ASM International, Metals
Park, OH.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>4-70
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.15 Cavitation<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.15.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cavitation is a form of erosion caused by the formation and instantaneous collapse of innumerable
tiny vapor bubbles.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The collapsing bubbles exert severe localized impact forces that can result in metal loss referred to
as cavitation damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The bubbles may contain the vapor phase of the liquid, air or other gas entrained in the liquid
medium.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.15.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Most common materials of construction including copper and brass, cast iron, carbon steel, low alloy
steels, 300 Series SS, 400 Series SS and nickel base alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.15.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
In a pump, the difference between the actual pressure or head of the liquid available (measured on
the suction side) and the vapor pressure of that liquid is called the Net Positive Suction Head
(NPSH) available.  The minimum head required to prevent cavitation with a given liquid at a given
flow rate is called the net positive suction head required.  Inadequate NPSH can result in cavitation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Temperatures approaching the boiling point of the liquid are more likely to result in bubble formation
than lower temperature operation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The presence of solid or abrasive particles is not required for cavitation damage but will accelerate
the damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.15.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cavitation is most often observed in pump casings, pump impellers (low pressure side) and in piping
downstream of orifices or control valves.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Damage can also be found in restricted-flow passages or other areas where turbulent flow is
subjected to rapid pressure changes within a localized region.  Examples of affected equipment
include heat exchanger tubes, venturis, seals and impellers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.15.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Cavitation damage generally looks like sharp-edged pitting but may also have a gouged appearance in
rotational components.  However, damage occurs only in localized low-pressure zones (see  Figure 4-46 ,
Figure 4-47  to  Figure 4-49 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_95>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-71
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.15.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Resistance to cavitation damage in a specific environment may not be significantly improved by a
material change. A mechanical modification, design or operating change is usually required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cavitation is best prevented by avoiding conditions that allow the absolute pressure to fall below the
vapor pressure of the liquid or by changing the material properties.  Examples include:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Streamline the flow path to reduce turbulence.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Decrease fluid velocities.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Remove entrained air.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Increase the suction pressure of pumps.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Alter the fluid properties, perhaps by adding additives.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6)
Use hard surfacing or hardfacing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7)
Use of harder and/or more corrosion resistant alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Attack is accelerated by the mechanical disruption of protective films at the liquid-solid interface
(such as a protective corrosion scale or passive films).  Therefore, changing to a more corrosion
resistant and/or higher hardness material may not improve cavitation resistance.  Excessively hard
materials may not be suitable if they lack the toughness required to withstand the high local
pressures and impact (shear loads) of the collapsing bubbles.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.15.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cavitating pumps may sound like pebbles are being thrashed around inside.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Techniques include limited monitoring of fluid properties as well as acoustic monitoring of turbulent
areas to detect characteristic sound frequencies.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Visual examination of suspected areas, as well as external UT and RT can be used to monitor for
loss in thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.15.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Liquid impingement or erosion (see  4.2.14 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.2.15.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, “Evaluation of Erosion and Cavitation,” Corrosion, Volume 13.
2. C.P. Dillon, “Corrosion Control in the Chemical Process Industries,” MTI (printed by NACE), 1994.
3. V.R. Pludek, “Design and Corrosion Control,” Macmillan Press LTD., 1979.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-73

<<IMAGE_32>>
[Image 32 contains text: Aa
aft a
\ i Mec A]
<<HEADING level=3>>Figure 4-48 – Cavitation pitting on the low-pressure side of a stainless steel pump impeller.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Figure 4-49 – Cavitation pitting on the water side of a cast iron cylinder liner in a large engine.<<HEADING_END>>

<<PAGE_98>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-74
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.16 Mechanical Fatigue<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.16.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Fatigue cracking is a mechanical form of degradation that occurs when a component is exposed to
cyclical stresses for an extended period, often resulting in sudden, unexpected failure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
These stresses can arise from either mechanical loading or thermal cycling and are typically well
below the yield strength of the material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.16.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All engineering alloys are subject to fatigue cracking although the stress levels and number of cycles
n ecessary to cause failure vary by material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.16.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Geometry, stress level, number of cycles, and material properties (strength, hardness, microstructure) are
the predominant factors in determining the fatigue resistance of a component.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Design: Fatigue cracks usually initiate on the surface at notches or stress raisers under cyclic
loading. For this reason, design of a component is the most important factor in determining a
component’s resistance to fatigue cracking. Several common surface features can lead to the
initiation of fatigue cracks as they can act as stress concentrations. Some of these common features
are:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Mechanical notches (sharp corners or groves);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Key holes on drive shafts of rotating equipment;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Weld joint, flaws and/or mismatches;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Quench nozzle areas;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Tool markings;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6)
Grinding marks;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7)
Lips on drilled holes;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8)
Thread root notches;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9)
Corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Metallurgical Issues and Microstructure<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
For some materials such as titanium, carbon steel and low alloy steel, the number of cycles to
fatigue fracture decreases with stress amplitude until an endurance limit reached.  Below this
stress endurance limit, fatigue cracking will not occur, regardless of the number of cycles.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
For alloys with endurance limits, there is a correlation between Ultimate Tensile Strength (UTS)
and the minimum stress amplitude necessary to initiate fatigue cracking. The ratio of endurance
limit over UTS is typically between 0.4 and 0.5. Materials like austenitic stainless steels and
aluminum that do not have an endurance limit will have a fatigue limit defined by the number of
cycles at a given stress amplitude.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Inclusions found in metal can have an accelerating effect on fatigue cracking. This is of
importance when dealing with older, “dirty” steels or weldments, as these often have inclusions
and discontinuities that can degrade fatigue resistance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Heat treatment can have a significant effect on the toughness and hence fatigue resistance of a
metal.  In general, finer grained microstructures tend to perform better than coarse grained.
Heat treatments such as quenching and tempering, can improve fatigue resistance of carbon
and low alloy steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_99>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-75
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Carbon Steel and Titanium:  These materials exhibit an endurance limit below which fatigue cracking
will not occur, regardless of the number of cycles.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
300 Series SS, 400 Series SS, aluminum and most other non-ferrous alloys:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
These alloys have a fatigue characteristic that does not exhibit an endurance limit. This means
that fatigue fracture can be achieved under cyclical loading eventually, regardless of stress
amplitude.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Maximum cyclical stress amplitude is determined by relating the stress necessary to cause
fracture to the desired number of cycles necessary in a component’s lifetime. This is typically
106 to 107 cycles.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.16.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Thermal Cycling<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Equipment that cycles daily in operation such as coke drums.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Equipment that may be auxiliary or on continuous standby but sees intermittent service such as
auxiliary boiler.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Quench nozzle connections that see significant temperature deltas during operations such as
water washing systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Mechanical Loading<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Pressure Swing Absorbers on hydrogen purification units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Rotating shafts on centrifugal pumps and compressors that have stress concentrations due to
changes in radii and key ways.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Components such as small diameter piping that may see vibration from adjacent equipment
and/or wind. For small components, resonance can also produce a cyclical load and should be
taken into consideration during design and reviewed for potential problems after installation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
High pressure drop control valves or steam reducing stations can cause serious vibration
problems in connected piping.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.16.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The signature mark of a fatigue failure is a “clam shell” type fingerprint that has concentric rings
called “beach marks” emanating from the crack initiation site ( Figure 4-50  and  Figure 4-51 ).  This
signature pattern results from the “waves” of crack propagation that occur during cycles above the
threshold loading. These concentric cracks continue to propagate until the cross-sectional area is
reduced to the point where failure due to overload occurs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracks nucleating from a surface stress concentration or defect will typically result in a single “clam
shell” fingerprint ( Figure 4-52  to  Figure 4-56 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Cracks resulting from cyclical overstress of a component without significant stress concentration will
typically result in a fatigue failure with multiple points of nucleation and hence multiple “clam shell”
fingerprints. These multiple nucleation sites are the result of microscopic yielding that occurs when
the component is momentarily cycled above its yield strength.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_100>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-76
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.16.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The best defense against fatigue cracking is good design that helps minimize stress concentration of
components that are in cyclic service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Select a metal with a design fatigue life sufficient for its intended cyclic service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Allow for a generous radius along edges and corners.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Minimize grinding marks, nicks and gouges on the surface of components.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Insure good fit up and smooth transitions for welds. Minimize weld defects as these can accelerate
fatigue cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Remove any burrs or lips caused by machining.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Use low stress stamps and marking tools.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.16.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
NDE techniques such as PT, MT and SWUT can be used to detect fatigue cracks at known areas of
stress concentration.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
VT of small diameter piping to detect oscillation or other cyclical movement that could lead to
cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Vibration monitoring of rotating equipment to help detect shafts that may be out of balance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In high cycle fatigue, crack initiation can be a majority of the fatigue life making detection difficult.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.16.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Vibration induced fatigue (see  4.2.17 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.2.16.9
References
1. “Fracture and Fatigue Control in Structures,”J.M. Barsom and S.T. Rolfe, American Society for
Testing and Materials, West Conshohocken, PA.
2. ASTM STP1428, Thermo-mechanical Fatigue Behavior of Materials, American Society for Testing
and Materials, West Conshohocken, PA.
3. ASTM MNL41, Corrosion in the Petrochemical Industry, ASM International, Mateirals Park, OH, 1995.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-81
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.17 Vibration-Induced Fatigue<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.17.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A form of mechanical fatigue in which cracks are produced as the result of dynamic loading due to
vibration, water hammer, or unstable fluid flow.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.17.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All engineering materials.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.17.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The amplitude and frequency of vibration as well as the fatigue resistance of the components are
critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
There is a high likelihood of cracking when the input load is synchronous or nearly synchronizes with
the natural frequency of the component.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
A lack of or excessive support or stiffening allows vibration and possible cracking problems that
usually initiate at stress raisers or notches.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.17.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Socket welds and small bore piping at or near pumps and compressors that are not sufficiently
gusseted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Small bore bypass lines and flow loops around rotating and reciprocating equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Small branch connections with unsupported valves or controllers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Safety relief valves are subject to chatter, premature pop-off, fretting and failure to operate properly.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
High pressure drop control valves and steam reducing stations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Heat exchanger tubes may be susceptible to vortex shedding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.17.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Damage is usually in the form of a crack initiating at a point of high stress or discontinuity such as a
thread or weld joint ( Figure 4-57  and  Figure 4-58 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
A potential warning sign of vibration damage to refractories is the visible damage resulting from the
failure of the refractory and/or the anchoring system.  High skin temperatures may result from
refractory damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.17.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Vibration-induced fatigue can be eliminated or reduced through design and the use of supports and
vibration dampening equipment.  Material upgrades are not usually a solution.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Install gussets or stiffeners on small bore connections.  Eliminate unnecessary connections and
inspect field installations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Vortex shedding can be minimized at the outlet of control valves and safety valves through proper
side branch sizing and flow stabilization techniques.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Vibration effects may be shifted when a vibrating section is anchored. Special studies may be
necessary before anchors or dampeners are provided, unless the vibration is eliminated by removing
the source.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_106>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-82
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.17.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Look for visible signs of vibration, pipe movement or water hammer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Check for the audible sounds of vibration emanating from piping components such as control valves
and fittings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Conduct visual inspection during transient conditions (such as startups, shutdowns, upsets, etc.) for
intermittent vibrating conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Measure pipe vibrations using special monitoring equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The use of surface inspection methods (such as PT, MT) can be effective in a focused plan.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Check pipe supports and spring hangers on a regular schedule.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Damage to insulation jacketing may indicate excessive vibration.  This can result in wetting the
insulation which will cause corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.17.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Mechanical fatigue (see  4.2.16 ) and refractory degradation (see  4.2.18 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.2.17.9
References
1. “Environmental Effects on Components: Commentary for ASME Section III,” EPRI NP-5775, Project
1757-61, Final Report, EPRI, CA, 1998.
2. API RP 581, Risk-Based Inspection Technology, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.,
2008.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>4-84
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18 Refractory Degradation<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Both thermal insulating and erosion resistant refractories are susceptible to various forms of mechanical
damage (cracking, spalling and erosion) as well as corrosion due to oxidation, sulfidation and other high
temperature mechanisms.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Refractory materials include insulating ceramic fibers, castables, refractory brick and plastic refractories.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Refractory selection, design and installation are the keys to minimizing damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Refractory lined equipment should be designed for erosion, thermal shock and thermal expansion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Dry out schedules, cure times and application procedures should be in accordance with the
manufacturer’s specifications and the appropriate ASTM requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Anchor materials must be compatible with thermal coefficients of expansion of the base metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Anchors must be resistant to oxidation in high temperature services.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Anchors must be resistant to condensing sulfurous acids in heaters and flue gas environments.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Refractory type and density must be selected to resist abrasion and erosion based on service
requirements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Needles and other fillers must be compatible with the process environment composition and
temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Refractories are extensively used in FCC reactor regenerator vessels, piping, cyclones, slide valves
and internals; in fluid cokers; in cold shell catalytic reforming reactors; and in waste heat boilers and
thermal reactors in sulfur plants.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Boiler fire boxes and stacks which also use refractory are affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Refractory may show signs of excessive cracking, spalling or lift-off from the substrate, softening or
general degradation from exposure to moisture.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Coke deposits may develop behind refractory and promote cracking and deterioration.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In erosive services, refractory may be washed away or thinned, exposing the anchoring system.
( Figure 4-59 )<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Proper selection of refractory, anchors and fillers and their proper design and installation are the keys to
minimizing refractory damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Conduct visual inspection during shutdowns.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Survey cold-wall equipment onstream using IR to monitor for hot spots to help identify refractory
damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
