<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-85
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Oxidation (see  4.4.1 ), sulfidation (see  4.4.2 ) and flue gas dew point corrosion (see  4.3.7 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.18.9
References
1. R.A. White and E.F. Ehmke, “Materials Selection for Refineries and Associated Facilities,” NACE
International, Houston, TX, 1991, pp. 33,57.<<HEADING_END>>

<<PAGE_111>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-87
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.19 Reheat Cracking<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.19.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Cracking of a metal due to stress relaxation during Post Weld Heat Treatment (PWHT) or in service at
elevated temperatures above 750°F (399°C).  It is most often observed in heavy wall sections.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.19.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Low alloy steels, especially the Cr-Mo steels with vanadium added, as well as 300 Series SS and nickel
base alloys such as Alloy 800H.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.19.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Important parameters include the type of material (chemical composition, impurity elements), grain size,
residual stresses from fabrication (cold working, welding), section thickness (which controls restraint and
stress state), notches and stress concentrators, weld metal and base metal strength, welding and heat
treating conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>From the various theories of reheat cracking for both 300 Series SS and low alloy steels, cracking
features are as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Reheat cracking requires the presence of high stresses and is therefore more likely to occur in
thicker sections and higher strength materials.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Reheat cracking occurs at elevated temperatures when creep ductility is insufficient to accommodate
the strains required for the relief of applied or residual stresses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In the first half of 2008, numerous cases of reheat cracking occurred during 2 ¼ Cr-1 Mo-V reactor
fabrication. The cracks were in weld metal only, transverse to the welding direction, and in only SAW
welds. It was traced to a contaminant in the welding flux.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Reheat cracking can either occur during PWHT or in service at high temperature. In both cases,
cracks are intergranular and show little or no evidence of deformation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Fine intragranular precipitate particles make the grains stronger than the grain boundaries and force
the creep deformation to occur at the grain boundaries.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Stress relief and stabilization heat treatment of 300 Series SS for maximizing chloride SCC and
PTASCC resistance can cause reheat cracking problems, particularly in thicker sections.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.19.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Reheat cracking is most likely to occur in heavy wall vessels in areas of high restraint including
nozzle welds and heavy wall piping.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
HSLA steels are very susceptible to reheat cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.19.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Reheat cracking is intergranular and can be surface breaking or embedded depending on the state
of stress and geometry.  It is most frequently observed in coarse-grained sections of a weld heat-
affected zone.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
In many cases, cracks are confined to the heat-affected zone, initiate at some type of stress
concentration, and may act as an initiation site for fatigue.  Figure 4-60  to   4-63 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_112>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-88
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.19.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Joint configurations in heavy wall sections should be designed to minimize restraint during welding
and PWHT.  Adequate preheat must also be applied.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The grain size has an important influence on the high temperature ductility and on the reheat
cracking susceptibility. A large grain size results in less ductile heat-affected zones, making the
material more susceptible to reheat cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Metallurgical notches arising from the welding operation are frequently the cause of heat-affected
zone cracking (at the boundary between the weld and the heat-affected zone).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In design and fabrication, it is advisable to avoid sharp changes in cross section, such as short
radius fillets or undercuts that can give rise to stress concentrations.  Long-seam welds are
particularly susceptible to mismatch caused by fitup problems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
For 2 ¼ Cr-1 Mo-V SAW weld materials, prequalification screening tests for reheat cracking such as
high temperature (650 o C) Gleeble tensile tests should be considered.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
For Alloy 800H, the risk of in-service cracking can be reduced by using base metal and matching
weld metal with Al+Ti <0.7%.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
For Alloy 800H which will operate >540 o C, the material may need to be purchased with a thermal
stabilization heat treatment, and with PWHT of welds and cold worked sections.  Welds should be
made with matching Alloy 800H filler material and should be stress relieved.  Refer to ASME Section
VIII, Div. 1 Code in UNF-56(e) for additional information.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
For thick-wall SS piping, PWHT should be avoided whenever possible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.19.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Surface cracks can be detected with UT and MT examination of carbon and low alloy steels<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
UT and PT examination can be used to detect cracks in 300 Series SS and nickel base alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Embedded cracks can only be found through UT examination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Inspection for reheat cracking in 2 ¼ Cr-1 Mo-V reactors during fabrication is typically done with
TOFD or manual shearwave UT with the demonstration block having defects as small as 3 mm side
drilled holes<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.19.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Reheat cracking has also been referred to in the literature as “stress relief cracking” and “stress relaxation
cracking”.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-93
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.20 Gaseous Oxygen-Enhanced Ignition and Combustion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.20.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Many metals are flammable in oxygen and enriched air (>25% oxygen) services even at low pressures,
whereas they are non-flammable in air.  The spontaneous ignition or combustion of metallic and non-
metallic components can result in fires and explosions in certain oxygen-enriched gaseous environments
if not properly designed, operated and maintained.  Once ignited, metals and non-metals burn more
vigorously with higher oxygen purity, pressure and temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.20.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbon steels and low alloy steels are flammable in low pressure oxygen, greater than about 15 psig
(0.103 MPa). With special precautions, these materials are safely used in high pressure oxygen.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Austenitic stainless steels (300 series) have better resistance to low pressure oxygen and are
generally difficult to ignite at pressures below about 200 psig (1.38 MPa).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Copper alloys (with >55% copper) and nickel alloys (with >50% nickel) are very fire resistant and are
generally considered non-flammable. Because of their excellent oxygen “compatibility” they are often
selected for impingement and turbulent services such as valves and instrumentation ( Figure 4-69 ).
Alloy 400 is highly resistant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Although widely used for oxygen cylinders and in oxygen manufacturing plants, aluminum is usually
avoided for flowing oxygen. If ignited it burns quickly and with a large energy release.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The easiest materials to ignite are plastics, rubbers, and hydrocarbon lubricants and these are
minimized in oxygen systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Titanium alloys are generally avoided in oxygen and oxygen-enriched service because they have low
ignition energies and release a large amount of energy during combustion. Tests indicate that
titanium can sustain combustion at oxygen pressure as low as 7 kPa (1 psi) absolute.  Most industry
documents caution against the use of titanium in oxygen systems (References 6 and 7).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Note:  These are general guidelines and should not be considered for design.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.20.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Many factors affect the likelihood of combustion and ignition in oxygen services including the system
pressure, oxygen content of the stream, line velocity, component thickness, design and piping
configuration, cleanliness and temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The primary concern under high velocity oxygen flow conditions is the entrainment of particulate and
their subsequent impingement on a surface, such as at a pipe bend. Oxygen velocities in carbon
steel and stainless steel piping should comply with industry limits as shown in Reference 1.
Allowable velocity is a function of pressure and flow condition (direct impingement or non-
impingement).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The temperature of a material affects its flammability.  As temperature increases, a lower amount of
additional energy is required for ignition and sustained combustion. The minimum temperature at
which a substance will support combustion, under a specific set of conditions is referred to as the
ignition temperature. Published ignition temperatures for most alloys are near the alloy’s melting
temperature. However, these are measured in non-flowing conditions. Actual systems can suffer
ignition and combustion at room temperature (and lower) due to particle impact and other
mechanisms.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
System cleanliness is important for the safe operation of oxygen systems.  Contamination of with
metallic fines or hydrocarbons such as oils and greases during construction or maintenance activities
can lead to fires during subsequent start up of the unit.  These materials are easy to ignite and can
lead to a large fire and breach of the system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute ,,`                       |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API ---                       |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_118>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-94
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Impingement areas such as sharp elbows, tees and valves have a higher risk of ignition than straight
pipe. Particles in the flowing oxygen can strike these areas and cause ignition. Operation of valves
and regulators (opening / closing) cause high turbulence and impingement and only components
selected and cleaned specifically for oxygen service should be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.20.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
These guidelines apply to any unit that uses oxygen or enriched air for combustion or other process
reasons.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Oxygen is sometimes used in sulfur recovery units (SRU) and fluid catalytic cracking units (FCCU),
Gasification, and Partial Oxidation (POX) units.   Figures 4-64  to  4-66 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Oxygen piping systems especially valves, regulators, and other impingement areas are potentially
vulnerable. Non-metals such as those used for seats and seals, are easier to ignite than metals
( Figure 4-69 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.20.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
In some cases a small component will burn, such as a valve seat, without kindling other materials
and without any outward sign of fire damage. It is noticed when the component is removed because
it is not functioning properly.  Figure 4-67  to  4-68 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Also, external heat damage (glowing pipe or heat tint) is a strong indication of an internal fire. This
can be caused by accumulation of flammable debris at a low point or other location and combustion
or smoldering of the debris.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The worst situation is when the pressure envelope is breached because of fire. Oxygen fires can
cause significant burning of metal components and extensive structural damage ( Figure 4-68 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.20.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Refer to industry recommended guidelines included in the references listed below.  Some general
considerations are as follows:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Oxygen fires are a sudden occurrence and not a progressive degradation or weakening of the
material. Prevention is best accomplished be keeping systems clean, or cleaning them after
maintenance or inspections.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Maintain velocity within recommended limits.  If practical, avoid velocities that are nominally above
100 feet/second (30 m/sec) in gaseous oxygen.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Ensure that replacement components are suitable for oxygen service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Oxygen systems should be thoroughly cleaned after maintenance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Minimize lubricants and use only “oxygen compatible” lubricants.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Do not unnecessarily open oxygen systems for visual or other inspections as this could introduce
contamination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
A thorough review is needed before modifying oxygen systems to operate at higher pressures,
temperatures, or velocities.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Minimize sudden changes in pressure in the system.  If high pressure oxygen suddenly enters a
system initially at low pressure by quick operation of a valve, the “dead end” of that system
experiences heating from adiabatic compression of the oxygen. Adiabatic compression heating can
ignite plastics and rubbers, but will not ignite metals. Valve seats, seals, non-metallic hoses, etc can
be ignited by this mechanism.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
Do not use plastic pipe in oxygen piping systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>j)
Personnel activities near oxygen piping and systems should be minimized during start ups.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_119>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-95
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.20.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Most commercial oxygen is dry and non-corrosive at normal ambient temperatures.  Because of the
sudden catastrophic ignition of metals under certain conditions this type of damage is difficult to
inspect for in advance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Tell-tale signs of a minor fire such as external heat damage, or signs of malfunctioning valves or
other components containing non-metallic components may be indicative of a problem.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Blacklights can be used to check for hydrocarbon contamination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.2.20.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Not applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.2.20.9
References
1. Compressed Gas Association Pamphlet G-4.4, "Industrial Practices for Gaseous Oxygen
Transmission and Distribution Piping Systems."
2. ASTM G88, Standard Guide for Designing Systems for Oxygen Service;
3. ASTM G93, Standard Practice for Cleaning Methods for Material and Equipment Used in Oxygen
Enriched Service.
4. CGA G-4.1, Cleaning Equipment for Oxygen Service Compressed Gas Association, latest edition.
5. CGA G-4.4, Industrial Practices for Gaseous Oxygen Transmission and Distribution Piping Systems,
Compressed Gas Association, latest edition.
6. NFPA 53M, Manual on Fire Hazards in Oxygen-Enriched Atmospheres.
7. ASTM MNL 36, Safe Use of Oxygen and Oxygen Systems: Handbook for Design, Operation, and
Maintenance, 2nd Edition, H. D. Beeson, S. R. Smith, and W. F. Stewart, Editors, 2007.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_125>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-101
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3
Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1
Galvanic Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A form of corrosion that can occur at the junction of dissimilar metals when they are joined together in a
suitable electrolyte, such as a moist or aqueous environment, or soils containing moisture.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1.2
Affected Material<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All metals with the exception of most noble metals.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For galvanic corrosion, three conditions must be met:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Presence of an electrolyte, a fluid that can conduct a current.  Moisture or a separate water
phase is usually required for the solution to have enough conductivity.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Two different materials or alloys known as the anode and the cathode, in contact with an
electrolyte.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
An electrical connection must exist between the anode and the cathode.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The more noble material (cathode) is protected by sacrificial corrosion of the more active material
(anode). The anode corrodes at a higher rate than it would if it were not connected to the cathode.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
A typical listing of the relative position of alloys in seawater is shown in  Table 4-6.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The farther the alloys are apart in the table, the higher the driving force for corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The relative exposed surface areas between anodic material and the cathodic material has a
significant affect.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Corrosion rates of the anode can be high, if there is a small anode to cathode ratio.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Corrosion rates of the anode will be less affected if there is a large anode to cathode ratio.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
If there is a galvanic couple, the more noble material may need to be coated. If the active
material were coated, a large cathode to anode area can accelerate corrosion of the anode at
any breaks in the coating.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
The same alloy may act as both an anode and a cathode due to surface films, scale, and/or
local environment (for example, old steel pipe connected to new steel pipe).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Galvanic corrosion can occur in any unit where there is a conductive fluid and alloys are coupled.
Heat exchangers are susceptible if the tube material is different from the tubesheet and/or baffles,
particularly if salt water cooling is utilized.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Buried pipelines, electrical transmission support towers and ship hulls are typical locations for
galvanic corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Damage occurs where two materials are joined at welded or bolted connections.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The more active material can suffer generalized loss in thickness or may have the appearance of a
crevice, groove or pitting corrosion, depending on the driving force, conductivity and relative
anodic/cathodic areas ratio.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_126>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-102
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion of the anode may be significantly higher immediately adjacent to the connection to the
cathode, depending on solution conductivity ( Figure 4-70  and  Figure 4-71 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The best method for prevention/mitigation is through good design.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Differing alloys should not be in intimate contact in conductive environments unless the
anode/cathode surface area ratio is favorable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Coatings can be helpful, but the more noble material should be coated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
For piping, specially designed electric insulating bolt sleeves and gaskets can eliminate the electrical
connection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Galvanic corrosion is the principle used in galvanized steel, where the Zn corrodes preferentially to
protect the underlying carbon steel.  (If there is a break in the galvanized coating, a large anode to
small cathode area prevents accelerated corrosion of the steel).  This anode-to-cathode relationship
reverses at water temperatures over about 150°F (66°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Visual inspection and UT thickness gauging are very effective methods for detecting galvanic corrosion.
The damage may sometimes be hidden underneath a bolt or rivet head.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Soil corrosion (see  4.3.9 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.1.9
References
1. “Corrosion Basics – An Introduction,” NACE International, Houston, TX, 1984, pp. 33-37.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_129>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-105
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2
Atmospheric Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A form of corrosion that occurs from moisture associated with atmospheric conditions.  Marine
environments and moist polluted industrial environments with airborne contaminants are most severe. Dry
rural environments cause very little corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel, low alloy steels and copper alloyed aluminum.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Critical factors include the physical location (industrial, marine, rural); moisture (humidity), particularly
designs that trap moisture or when present in a cooling tower mist; temperature; presence of salts,
sulfur compounds and dirt.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Marine environments can be very corrosive (20 mpy) as are industrial environments that contain
acids or sulfur compounds that can form acids (5-10 mpy).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Inland locations exposed to a moderate amount of precipitation or humidity are considered
moderately corrosive environments (~1-3 mpy).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Dry rural environments usually have very low corrosion rates (<1 mpy).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Designs that trap water or moisture in crevices are more prone to attack.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Corrosion rates increase with temperature up to about 250°F (121°C).  Above 250°F (121°C),
surfaces are usually too dry for corrosion to occur except under insulation (see  4.3.3 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Chlorides, H 2 S, fly ash and other airborne contaminates from cooling tower drift, furnace stacks and
other equipment accelerate corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Bird turds can also cause accelerated corrosion and unsightly stains.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Piping and equipment with operating temperatures sufficiently low to allow moisture to be present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
A paint or coating system in poor condition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Equipment may be susceptible if cycled between ambient and higher or lower operating
temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Equipment shut down or idled for prolonged periods unless properly mothballed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Tanks and piping are particularly susceptible.  Piping that rests on pipe supports is very prone to
attack due to water entrapment between the pipe and the support.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Orientation to the prevailing wind and rain can also be a factor.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Piers and docks are very prone to attack.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Bimetallic connections such as copper to aluminum electrical connections<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The attack will be general or localized, depending upon whether or not the moisture is trapped.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
If there is no coating, corrosion or loss in thickness can be general.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Localized coating failures will tend to promote corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |

| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |

| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |

| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_130>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-106
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Metal loss may not be visually evident, although normally a distinctive iron oxide (red rust) scale
forms as shown in  Figure 4-72 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Surface preparation and proper coating application are critical for long-term protection in corrosive
environments.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>VT and UT are techniques that can be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Corrosion under insulation (see  4.3.3 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.2.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook,  Volume 13, “Corrosion,”  ASM International, Materials Park, OH.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_132>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-108
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.3
Corrosion Under Insulation (CUI)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.3.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Corrosion of piping, pressure vessels and structural components resulting from water trapped under
insulation or fireproofing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.3.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel, low alloy steels, 300 Series SS, and duplex stainless steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.3.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
It affects externally insulated piping and equipment and those that are in intermittent service or
operate between:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
10°F (–12°C) and 350°F (175°C) for carbon and low alloy steels,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
140 º F (60°C) and 400 º F (205°C) for austenitic stainless steels and duplex stainless steels<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion rates increase with increasing metal temperature up to the point where the water
evaporates quickly.  For insulated components, corrosion becomes more severe at metal
temperatures between the boiling point 212°F (100°C) and 350°F (121°C), where water is less likely
to vaporize and insulation stays wet longer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Design of insulation system, insulation type, temperature and environment are critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Poor design and/or installations that allow water to become trapped will increase CUI.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Insulating materials that hold moisture (wick) can be more of a problem.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Cyclic thermal operation or intermittent service can increase corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Equipment that operates below the water dewpoint tends to condense water on the metal surface
thus providing a wet environment and increasing the risk of corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Damage is aggravated by contaminants that may be leached out of the insulation, such as chlorides.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
Plants located in areas with high annual rainfall or warmer, marine locations are more prone to CUI
than plants located in cooler, drier, mid-continent locations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>j)
Environments that provide airborne contaminants such as chlorides (marine environments, cooling
tower drift) or SO 2  (stack emissions) can accelerate corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.3.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All insulated piping and equipment are susceptible to CUI under conditions noted above even on
piping and equipment where the insulation system appears to be in good condition and no visual
signs of corrosion are present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Examples of locations where CUI can occur are listed below:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
CUI can be found on equipment with damaged insulation, vapor barriers, weatherproofing or
mastic, or protrusions through the insulation or at insulation termination points such as flanges.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Equipment designed with insulation support rings welded directly to the vessel wall (no
standoff); particularly around ladder and platform clips, and lifting lugs, nozzles and stiffener
rings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Piping or equipment with damaged/leaking steam tracing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Localized damage at paint and/or coating systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Locations where moisture/water will naturally collect (gravity drainage) before evaporating
(insulation support rings on vertical equipment) and improperly terminated fireproofing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_133>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-109
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6)
Vibrating  piping  systems  that  have  a  tendency  to  inﬂict damage  to  insulation  jacketing
providing  a  path  for  water ingress.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7)
Deadlegs (vents, drains, and other similar items).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8)
Pipe hangers and other supports.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>9)
Valves and ﬁttings (irregular insulation surfaces).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>10) Bolted-on pipe shoes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>11) Steam tracer tubing penetrations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>12)  Termination  of  insulation  at  ﬂanges  and  other  piping components.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>13)  Insulation jacketing seams located on the top of horizontal piping or improperly lapped or
sealed insulation jacketing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>14) Termination of insulation in a vertical pipe.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>15) Caulking that has hardened, has separated, or is missing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>16) Bulges or staining of the insulation or jacketing system or missing  bands.  (Bulges  may
indicate  corrosion  product buildup.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>17) Low points in piping systems that have a known breach in the insulation system, including low
points in long unsupported piping runs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>18)  Carbon or low-alloy steel ﬂanges, bolting, and other components under insulation in high-alloy
piping systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>19) Locations  where  insulation  plugs  have  been  removed  to permit  piping  thickness
measurements on  insulated  piping and equipment should  receive  particular  attention.  These
plugs should be promptly replaced and sealed.  Several types of removable plugs are
commercially available that permit inspection and identiﬁcation of inspection points for future
reference.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>20) The first few feet of a horizontal pipe run adjacent to the bottom of a vertical run.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.3.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbon and low alloy steels are subject to localized pitting corrosion and or localized loss in
thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
300 Series SS are also subject to Stress Corrosion Cracking (SCC) if chlorides are present, while
the duplex SS are less susceptible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
300 Series SS and duplex SS are subject to pitting and localized corrosion.  For 300 Series SS,
specifically in older calcium silicate insulation (known to contain chlorides), localized pitting and
chloride stress corrosion cracking can occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
After insulation is removed from carbon and low alloy steels, CUI damage often appears as loose,
flaky scale covering the corroded component.  Damage may be highly localized ( Figure 4-73  to  4-
79 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
In some localized cases, the corrosion can appear to be carbuncle type pitting (usually found under a
failed paint/coating system).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Tell tale signs of insulation and paint/coating damage often accompany CUI.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.3.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Since the majority of construction materials used in plants are susceptible to CUI degradation,
mitigation is best achieved by using appropriate paints/coatings and maintaining the
insulation/sealing/vapor barriers to prevent moisture ingress.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_134>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-110
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Flame-sprayed aluminum coatings have been used on carbon steels.  The coating corrodes
preferentially by galvanic action, thereby protecting the base metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
High quality non-metallic coatings, properly applied to the surfaces to be insulated can provide long
term protection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Thin aluminum foil wrapped on stainless steel piping and equipment has been used on stainless
steels as an effective barrier under insulation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Careful selection of insulating materials is important. Closed-cell foam glass materials will hold less
water against the vessel/pipe wall than mineral wool and potentially be less corrosive.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Low chloride insulation should be used on 300 Series SS to minimize the potential for pitting and
chloride SCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
It is not usually possible to modify operating conditions.  However, consideration should be given to
removing the insulation on equipment where heat conservation is not as important.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.3.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
An inspection plan for corrosion under insulation should be a structured and systematic approach
starting with prediction/analysis, then looking at the more invasive procedures. The inspection plan
should consider operating temperature; type and age/condition of coating; and type and
age/condition of insulation material.  Additional prioritization can be added from a physical inspection
of the equipment, looking for evidence of insulation, mastic and/or sealant damage, signs of water
penetration and rust in gravity drain areas around the equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Although external insulation may appear to be in good condition, CUI damage may still be occurring.
CUI inspection may require removal of some or all insulation. If external coverings are in good
condition and there is no reason to suspect damage behind them, it may not be necessary to remove
them for inspection of the vessel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Considerations for insulation removal are not limited to but include:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
History of CUI for the vessel or comparable equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Visual condition of the external covering and insulation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Evidence of fluid leakage, e.g. stains.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Equipment in intermittent service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Condition/age of the external coating, if applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Common areas of concern in process units are high moisture areas such as those down-wind from
cooling towers, near steam vents, deluge systems, acid vapors, or near supplemental cooling with
water spray.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
When developing the inspection plan for CUI inspection, the inspector should consider<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Areas that are most susceptible to CUI.  If CUI damage is found, the inspector should inspect
other susceptible areas on the vessel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Utilize multiple inspection techniques to produce the most cost effective approach, including:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Partial and/or full stripping of insulation for visual examination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
UT for thickness verification.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Real-time profile x-ray (for small bore piping).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Neutron backscatter techniques for identifying wet insulation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Deep penetrating eddy-current inspection (can be automated with a robotic crawler).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_135>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-111
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
IR thermography looking for wet insulation and/or damaged and missing insulation under
the jacket.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Guided wave UT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.3.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Atmospheric corrosion (see  4.3.2 ), oxidation (see  4.4.1 ) and chloride SCC (see  4.5.1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.3.9
References
1. API RP 581, Risk-Based Inspection Technology, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.,
2008.
2. NACE Standard RP0198, The Control of Corrosion Under Thermal Insulation, and Fireproofing – A
Systems Approach, NACE International, Houston, TX.
3. W.I. Pollock and C.N. Steely, “Corrosion Under Wet Thermal Insulation,” NACE International,
Houston, TX, 1990.
4. M. M. Chauviere, et al., “Managing CUI in aging refinery pressure vessels”, Paper #07566, NACE
International, Houston, TX.
5. API 510, “Pressure Vessel Inspection Code: Maintenance Inspection, Rating, Repair, and Alteration”,
American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.
6. API 570, Piping Inspection Code, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_141>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-117
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.4
Cooling Water Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.4.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>General or localized corrosion of carbon steels and other metals caused by dissolved salts, gases,
organic compounds or microbiological activity.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.4.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel, all grades of stainless steel, copper, aluminum, titanium and nickel base alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.4.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cooling water corrosion and fouling are closely related and should be considered together. Fluid
temperature, type of water (fresh, brackish, salt water) and the type of cooling system (once-through,
open circulating, closed circulating), oxygen content, and fluid velocities are critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Increasing cooling water outlet temperatures and or process side inlet temperatures tend to increase
corrosion rates as well as fouling tendency.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Increasing oxygen content tends to increase carbon steel corrosion rates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
If the process side temperature is above 140°F (60°C), a scaling potential exists with fresh water and
becomes more likely as process temperatures increase and as cooling water inlet temperatures rise.
Brackish and salt water outlet temperatures above about 115°F (46°C) may cause serious scaling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Fouling may occur from mineral deposits (hardness), silt, suspended organic materials, corrosion
products, mill scale, marine and microbiological growth.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Velocities should be high enough to minimize fouling and drop out of deposits but not so high as to
cause erosion.  Velocity limits depend on the tube material and water quality.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Low velocities can promote increased corrosion.  Velocities below about 3 fps (1 m/s) are likely to
result in fouling, sedimentation and increased corrosion in fresh and brackish water systems.
Accelerated corrosion can also result from dead spots or stagnant areas if cooling water is used on
the shell side of condensers/coolers rather than the preferred tube side.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
300 Series SS can suffer pitting corrosion, crevice corrosion and SCC in fresh, brackish and salt
water systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
Copper/zinc alloys can suffer dezincification in fresh, brackish and salt water systems.  The
copper/zinc alloys can suffer SCC if any ammonia or ammonium compounds are present in the
water or on the process side.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>j)
ERW carbon steel may suffer severe weld and/or heated affected zone corrosion in fresh and/or
brackish water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>k)
When connected to a more anodic material, titanium may suffer severe hydriding embrittlement.
Generally, the problem occurs at temperatures above 180°F (82°C) but can occur at lower
temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.4.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Cooling water corrosion is a concern with water-cooled heat exchangers and cooling towers in all
applications across all industries.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.4.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cooling water corrosion can result in many different forms of damage including general corrosion,
pitting corrosion ( Figure 4-81 ), MIC, stress corrosion cracking and fouling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
General or uniform corrosion of carbon steel occurs when dissolved oxygen is present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_142>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-118
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Localized corrosion may result from underdeposit corrosion, crevice corrosion or microbiological
corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Deposits or crevices can lead to underdeposit or crevice corrosion of any of the affected materials.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Wavy or smooth corrosion at nozzle inlets/outlets and tube inlets may be due to flow induced
corrosion, erosion or abrasion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Corrosion at ERW weld areas will appear as grooving along the weld fusion lines.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Metallurgical analysis of tube samples may be required to confirm the mode of failure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.4.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cooling water corrosion (and fouling) can be prevented by proper design, operation and chemical
treatment of cooling water systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Design for process side inlet temperatures below 140°F (60°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Minimum and maximum water velocities must maintained, particularly in salt water systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The metallurgy of heat exchanger components may need to be upgraded for improved resistance,
especially in waters with high chloride content, low velocity, high process temperatures, and/or
poorly maintained water chemistry.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Periodic mechanical cleaning of tube ID’s and OD’s should be performed in order to maintain clean
heat transfer surfaces.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
With very few exceptions, cooling water should be on the tube side to minimize stagnant areas.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.4.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cooling water should be monitored for variables that affect corrosion and fouling including, pH,
oxygen content, cycles of concentration, biocide residual, biological activity, cooling water outlet
temperatures, hydrocarbon contamination and process leaks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Periodic calculation of U-factors (heat exchanger performance measurement) will provide information
on scaling and fouling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Ultrasonic flow meters can be used to check the velocity of water in the tubes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
EC or IRIS inspection of tubes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Splitting representative tubes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.4.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Microbiologically induced corrosion (see  4.3.8 ), chloride stress corrosion cracking (see  4.5.1 ) and
galvanic corrosion (see  4.3.1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.4.9
References
1. T.J. Tvedt, Jr., “Cooling Water Systems,” NACE Course Book on Corrosion Control in the Refining
Industry, NACE International, Houston, TX, 1999.
2. H.M. Herro and R.D. Port, “NALCO Guide to Cooling Water System Failure Analysis,” McGraw-Hill,
Inc., NY, 1991, pp. 259-263.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_144>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-120
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.5
Boiler Water Condensate Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.5.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>General corrosion and pitting in the boiler system and condensate return piping.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.5.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Primarily carbon steel, some low alloy steel, some 300 Series SS and copper based alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.5.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion in boiler feedwater and condensate return systems is usually the result of dissolved gases,
oxygen and carbon dioxide, which lead to oxygen pitting corrosion and carbonic acid corrosion,
respectivley.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Critical factors are the concentration of dissolved gas (oxygen and or carbon dioxide), pH,
temperature, quality of the feedwater, and the specific feedwater treating system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion protection in the boiler is accomplished by laying down and continuously maintaining a
layer of protective Fe 3 O 4  (magnetite).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The chemical treatment for scale and deposit control must be adjusted to coordinate with the oxygen
scavenger for the specific water service and boiler feedwater treating system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Ammonia SCC of Cu-Zn alloys can occur due to hydrazine, neutralizing amines or ammonia-
containing compounds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.5.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Corrosion can occur in the external treatment system, deaerating equipment, feedwater lines, pumps,
stage heaters and economizers as well as the steam generation system on both the water and fire sides
and the condensate return system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.5.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion from oxygen tends to be a pitting type damage and can show up anywhere in the system
even if only very small quantities break through the scavenging treatment.  Oxygen is particularly
aggressive in equipment such as closed heaters and economizers where there is a rapid water
temperature rise ( Figure 4-82 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion in the condensate return system tends to be due to carbon dioxide although some oxygen
pitting problems can occur if the oxygen scavenging treatment is not working correctly.  Carbon
dioxide corrosion tends to be a smooth grooving of the pipe wall ( Figures 4-83  and  4-84 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.5.6
Prevention/Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Oxygen scavenging treatments typically include catalyzed sodium sulfite or hydrazine depending on
the system pressure level along with proper mechanical deaerator operation.  A residual of the
oxygen scavenger is carried into the steam generation system to handle any oxygen ingress past the
deaerator.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
If the scale/deposit control/magnetite maintenance treatment scheme does not minimize carbon
dioxide in the condensate return system, an amine inhibitor treatment might be required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.5.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Water analysis is the common monitoring tool used to assure that the various treatment systems are
performing in a satisfactory manner.  Parameters which can be monitored for signs of upset include
the pH, conductivity, chlorine or residual biocide, and total dissolved solids to check for leaks in the
form of organic compounds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>

|:----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API `,`                            |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS ,``` |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_145>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-121
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
There are no proactive inspection methods other than developing an appropriate program when
problems such as a ruptured boiler tube or condensate leaks are recognized in the various parts of
complex boiler water and condensate systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Deaerator cracking problems can be evaluated off-line at shutdowns by utilizing properly applied wet
fluorescence magnetic particle inspection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.5.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>CO 2  corrosion (see  4.3.6 ), corrosion fatigue (see  4.5.2 ), and erosion/erosion-corrosion (see  4.2.14 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.5.9
References
1. “Betz Handbook of Industrial Water Conditioning,” Eighth Edition, Betz Laboratories, Inc., PA, 1980.
2. R.D. Port and H.M. Herro, “The Nalco Guide to Boiler Failure Analysis,” McGraw-Hill, Inc., NY, 1991.
3. NACE SP0590-2007, “Prevention, Detection, and Correction of Deaerator Cracking”, NACE
International, Houston, TX.
4. T-Y Cnen et al., “Condensate corrosion in  steam generating systems, Paper # 718, NACE
International, Houston, TX, 1998.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_148>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-124
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.6
CO 2  Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.6.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) corrosion results when CO 2  dissolves in water to form carbonic acid (H 2 CO 3 ).  The
acid may lower the pH and sufficient quantities may promote general corrosion and/or pitting corrosion of
carbon steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.6.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel and low alloy steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.6.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The partial pressure of CO 2 , pH and temperature are critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Increasing partial pressures of CO 2  result in lower pH condensate and higher rates of corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion occurs in the liquid phase, often at locations where CO 2  condenses from the vapor phase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Increasing temperatures increase corrosion rate up to the point where CO 2  is vaporized.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Increasing the level of chromium in steels offers no major improvement in resistance until a minimum
of  12% is reached.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.6.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Boiler feedwater and condensate systems in all units are affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Effluent gas streams of the shift converters in hydrogen plants can be affected. Corrosion usually
occurs when the effluent stream drops below the dew point, approximately 300°F (149°C). Corrosion
rates as high as 1000 mpy have been observed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Overhead systems of regenerators in CO 2  removal plants are affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.6.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Localized thinning and/or pitting corrosion of carbon steel ( Figure 4-85 ,  Figure 4-86  and  Figure 4-87 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Carbon steel may suffer deep pitting and grooving in areas of turbulence ( Figure 4-88 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion generally occurs in areas of turbulence and impingement and sometimes at the root of
piping welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.6.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion inhibitors can reduce corrosion in steam condensate systems. Vapor phase inhibitors may
be required to protect against condensing vapors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Increasing condensate pH above 6 can reduce corrosion in steam condensate systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The 300 Series SS are highly resistant to corrosion in most applications. Selective upgrading to
stainless steels is usually required in operating units designed to produce and/or remove CO 2  (such
as hydrogen plants and CO 2  removal units).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Steam condensate systems that experience CO 2  corrosion are usually the result of operating
problems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
400 Series SS and duplex SS are also resistant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.6.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
VT, UT and RT inspection techniques should focus on general and local loss in thickness where
water wetting is anticipated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_149>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-125
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Preferential corrosion of weld seams may require angle probe UT or RT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion may occur along the bottom surface of the pipe if there is a separate water phase, at the
top surface of the pipe if condensation in wet gas systems is anticipated, and in the turbulent flow
areas at elbow and tees.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Monitor water analyses (pH, Fe, etc.) to determine changes in operating conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.6.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Boiler water condensate corrosion (see  4.3.5 ) and carbonate cracking (see  5.1.2.5 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.6.9
References
1. “NACE Course Book on Corrosion Control in the Refining Industry,” NACE International, Houston,
TX, 1999.
2. L. Garverick, “Corrosion in the Petrochemical Industry,” ASM International, Materials Park, OH, 1994.
3. H.M. Herro and R.D. Port, “NALCO Guide to Cooling Water System Failure Analysis,” McGraw-Hill,
Inc., NY, 1991, pp. 259-263.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_152>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-128
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.7
Flue-Gas Dew-Point Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.7.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Sulfur and chlorine species in fuel will form sulfur dioxide, sulfur trioxide and hydrogen chloride within
the combustion products.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
At low enough temperatures, these gases and the water vapor in the flue gas will condense to form
sulfurous acid, sulfuric acid and hydrochloric acid which can lead to severe corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.7.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel, low alloy steels and 300 Series SS.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.7.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The concentration of contaminants (sulfur and chlorides) in the fuel and the operating temperature of
flue gas metal surfaces determine the likelihood and severity of corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Since all fuels contain some amount of sulfur, sulfuric and sulfurous acid dewpoint corrosion can
occur if the metal temperatures are below the dewpoint.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The dewpoint of sulfuric acid depends on the concentration of sulfur trioxide in the flue gas, but is
typically about 280°F (138°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Similarly, the dewpoint of hydrochloric acid depends on the concentration of hydrogen chloride. It is
typically about 130°F (54°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.7.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All fired process heaters and boilers that burn fuels containing sulfur have the potential for sulfuric
acid dewpoint corrosion in the economizer sections and in the stacks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Heat-Recovery Steam Generators (HRSG’s) that have 300 Series SS feedwater heaters may suffer
chloride-induced stress corrosion cracking from the gas side (OD) when the temperature of the inlet
water is below the dewpoint of hydrochloric acid.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
300 Series SS feedwater heaters in HRSG’s are potentially at risk if the atmosphere of the
combustion turbine includes chlorine.  Cooling tower drift from cooling towers that use chlorine-
based biocides may blow into the combustion turbine and lead to potential damage in the feedwater
heaters.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.7.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Sulfuric acid corrosion on economizers or other carbon steel or low alloy steel components will have
general wastage often with broad, shallow pits, depending on the way the sulfuric acid condenses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
For the 300 Series SS feedwater heaters in HRSG’s, stress corrosion cracking will have surface
breaking cracks and the general appearance will be somewhat crazed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.7.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Maintain the metallic surfaces at the back end of the boilers and fired heaters above the temperature
of sulfuric acid dewpoint corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
For HRSG’s, avoid the use of 300 Series SS in the feedwater heaters if the environment is likely to
contain chlorides.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Similar damage occurs in oil-fired boilers when the units are water-washed to remove ash if the final
rinse does not neutralize the acid salts.  Sodium carbonate should be added to the final rinse as a
basic solution to neutralize the acidic ash constituents.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>

| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_153>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-129
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.7.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Wall-thickness measurements by UT methods will monitor the wastage in economizer tubes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Stress corrosion cracking of 300 Series SS can be found using VT and PT inspection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.7.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>At lower temperatures, hydrochloric acid may condense and promote HCL corrosion of carbon steels (see
5.1.1.4 ) and chloride stress corrosion cracking of 300 Series SS (see  4.5.1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.7.9
References
1. “Steam - Its Generation and Use,” 40th Edition, Babcock and Wilcox, 1992.
2. “Combustion Fossil Power Systems,” Third Edition, Combustion Engineering, CT, 1981.
3. H. Thielsch, “Defects And Failures in Pressure Vessels and Piping,”  Krieger Publishing Co., NY,
1977.
4. R.D. Port and H.M. Herro, “The NALCO Guide to Boiler Failure Analysis,” McGraw Hill, NY, 1991.
5. D.N. French, “Metallurgical Failures in Fossil Fired Boilers,” John Wiley and Sons, Publishers, Inc.,
NY. 1993.
6. B. Dooley and W. McNaughton, “Boiler Tube Failures: Theory and Practice,” EPRI,  CA, 1995.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_154>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-130
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.8
Microbiologically Induced Corrosion (MIC)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.8.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A form of corrosion caused by living organisms such as bacteria, algae or fungi. It is often associated with
the presence of tubercles or slimy organic substances.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.8.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Most common materials of construction including carbon and low alloy steels, 300 Series SS and 400
Series SS, aluminum, copper and some nickel base alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.8.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
MIC is usually found in aqueous environments or services where water is always or sometimes
present, especially where stagnant or low-flow conditions allow and/or promote the growth of
microorganisms.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Because there are several types, organisms can survive and grow under severe conditions including
lack of oxygen, light or dark, high salinity, pH range of  0 to 12, and temperatures from 0°F to 235°F
(–17°C to 113°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Systems may become “inoculated” by the introduction of organisms that multiply and spread unless
controlled.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Different organisms thrive on different nutrients including inorganic substances (e.g., sulfur,
ammonia, H 2 S) and inorganic substances (e.g., hydrocarbons, organic acids).  In addition, all
organisms require a source of carbon, nitrogen and phosphorous for growth.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
In-leakage of process contaminants such as hydrocarbons or H 2 S may lead to a massive increase in
biofouling and corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.8.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
MIC is most often found in heat exchangers, bottom water of storage tanks, piping with stagnant or
low flow, and piping in contact with some soils.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
MIC is also found in equipment where the hydrotest water has not been removed or equipment has
been  left outside and unprotected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Product storage tanks and water cooled heat exchangers in any unit where cooling water is not
properly treated can be affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Fire water systems can be affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.8.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
MIC corrosion is usually observed as localized pitting under deposits or tubercles that shield the
organisms.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Damage is often characterized by cup-shaped pits within pits in carbon steel or subsurface cavities
in stainless steel ( Figure 4-89  through  Figure 4-95 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.8.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Microbes require water to thrive. Systems that contain water (cooling water, storage tanks, etc.)
should be treated with biocides such as chlorine, bromine, ozone, ultraviolet light or proprietary
compounds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Proper application of biocides will control but not eliminate microbes so that continued treatment is
necessary.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_155>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-131
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Maintain flow velocities above minimum levels. Minimize low flow or stagnant zones.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Systems that are not designed or intended for water containment should be kept clean and dry.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Empty hydrotest water as soon as possible. Blow dry and prevent moisture intrusion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Wrapping and cathodically protecting underground structures have been effective in preventing MIC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Effective mitigation of established organisms requires complete removal of deposits and organisms
using a combination of pigging, blasting, chemical cleaning and biocide treatment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Add biocides to water phase in storage tanks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
Maintain coatings on the interior of storage tanks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.8.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
In cooling water systems, effectiveness of treatment is monitored by measuring biocide residual,
microbe counts and visual appearance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Special probes have been designed to monitor for evidence of fouling which may precede or
coincide with MIC damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
An increase in the loss of duty of a heat exchanger may be indicative of fouling and potential MIC
damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Foul smelling water may be a sign of trouble.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.8.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Cooling water corrosion (see  4.3.4 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.8.9
References
1. D.H. Pope and J.G. Stoecker, “Process Industries Corrosion - The Theory and Practice,” NACE
International, Houston, TX, 1986, pp 227-235.
2. T.J. Tvedt, Jr., “Cooling Water Systems,” NACE Course Book on Corrosion Control in the Refining
Industry, NACE International, Houston, TX, 1999.
3. S.C. Dexter, “Biologically Induced Corrosion,” NACE Proceeding s of the International Conference on
Biologically Induced Corrosion, June 10 –12, 1985, NACE International, Houston, TX, 1986.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
