<<PAGE_160>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-136
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.9
Soil Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.9.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The deterioration of metals exposed to soils is referred to as soil corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.9.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel, cast iron and ductile iron.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.9.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The severity of soil corrosion is determined by many factors including operating temperature,
moisture and oxygen availability, soil resistivity (soil condition and characteristics), soil type (water
drainage), and homogeneity (variation in soil type), cathodic protection, stray current drainage,
coating type, age, and condition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
There is no single parameter that can be used to determine soil corrosivity.  Instead, a number of
characteristics must be combined to estimate the corrosion in particular soil as outlined in ASTM
STP 741 as well as API RP 580 and API RPl 581.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Soil resistivity is frequently used to estimate soil corrosivity, mainly because it is easy to measure.
Soil resistivity is related to soil moisture content and dissolved electrolytes in the soil water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Soils having high moisture content, high dissolved salt concentrations, and high acidity are usually
the most corrosive.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Soil-to-air interface areas are often much more susceptible to corrosion than the rest of the structure
because of moisture and oxygen availability ( Figure 4-96 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Corrosion rates increase with increasing metal temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Other factors that affect soil corrosion include galvanic corrosion, dissimilar soils, stray currents,
differential aeration corrosion cells, and microbiologically induced corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.9.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Underground piping and equipment as well as buried tanks and the bottoms of above ground
storage tanks ( Figure 4-97 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Ground supported metal structures ( Figure 4-98 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.9.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Soil corrosion appears as external thinning with localized losses due to pitting. The severity of
corrosion depends on the local soil conditions and changes in the immediate environment along the
equipment metal surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Poor condition of a protective coating is a tell tale sign of potential corrosion damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.9.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Soil corrosion of carbon steel can be minimized through the use of special backfill, coatings and cathodic
protection. The most effective protection is a combination of a corrosion resistant coating and a cathodic
protection system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.9.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The most common method used for monitoring underground structures is measuring the structure to
soil potential using dedicated reference electrodes near the structure (corrected for IR drop error).
Cathodic protection should be performed and monitored in accordance with NACE RP 0169.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_161>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-137
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
There are many techniques for inspecting buried or on-grade metallic components.  Piping may be
inspected by inline inspection devices, guided ultrasonic thickness tools, indirectly by pressure
testing, or visually by evaluation.  The same or similar techniques may be used on other structures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.9.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Galvanic corrosion (see  4.3.1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.9.9
References
1. API RP 580, Recommended Practice for Risk Based Inspection, American Petroleum Institute,
Washington, D.C., 2008.
2. API RP 581, Risk-Based Inspection Technology, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.,
2008.
3. Peabody, A.W., “Control of Pipeline Corrosion,” NACE International, Houston, TX, 1967.
4. Morgan, John, “Cathodic Protection,” NACE International, Houston, TX, 1987.
5. O’Day, D. Kelly, “External Corrosion in Distribution Systems,” AWWA Journal, October, 1989.
6. Parker, Marshall E., “Pipe Line Corrosion and Cathodic Protection,” Gulf Publishing Company, TX,
1954.
7. Romanoff, M., “Underground Corrosion,” NACE International, Houston, TX, 1997.
8. Jones, Denny A., “Principles and Prevention of Corrosion,” McMillan Publishing Co., NY, 1992.

10. EDM Services, Inc., “Hazardous Liquid Pipeline Risk Assessment,” California State Fire Marshal,
Pipeline Safety Division, CA, 1993.
11. NACE RP 0169, Standard Recommended Practice: Control of External Corrosion on Underground or
Submerged Metallic Piping Systems, NACE International, Houston, TX.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>4-140
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.10 Caustic Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.10.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Localized corrosion due to the concentration of caustic or alkaline salts that usually occurs under
evaporative or high heat transfer conditions.  However, general corrosion can also occur depending on
alkali or caustic solution strength.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.10.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Primarily carbon steel, low alloy steels and 300 Series SS.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.10.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Major contributing factors are the presence of caustic (NaOH or KOH). The following are sources of
caustic:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Caustic is sometimes added to process streams for neutralization or as a reactant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
It is sometimes intentionally added to boiler feedwater at low concentrations or may enter
inadvertently during regeneration of demineralizers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Alkaline salts may also enter process streams through leaks in condensers or process equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Some process units utilize caustic solutions for neutralizing, for removal of sulfur compounds, or for
removal of chloride compounds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
A concentrating mechanism must exist to build up the caustic strength.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Caustic may become concentrated by departure from DNB, evaporation and deposition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.10.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Caustic corrosion is most often associated with boilers and steam generating equipment including
heat exchangers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Similar concentrating effects of caustic may occur where caustic is added to crude unit charge.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Accelerated localized corrosion can occur in preheat exchangers, furnace tubes and transfer lines,
unless the caustic is effectively mixed in the oil stream.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Units that use caustic for removing sulfur compounds from product streams.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.10.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Typically characterized by localized metal loss which may appear as grooves in a boiler tube or
locally thinned areas under insulating deposits ( Figure 4-99  and  Figure 4-100 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Deposits may fill corroded depressions and mask damage below.  Probing suspect areas with a
sharp instrument may be required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Localized gouging may result along a waterline where corrosives concentrate.  In vertical tubes, this
may appear as a circumferential groove.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In horizontal or sloped tubes, grooving may appear at the top of the tube or as longitudinal grooves
on opposite sides of the tube.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Exposure to high solution strength caustic can result in general corrosion of carbon steel above
175°F (79°C) and very high corrosion rates above 200°F (93°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_165>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-141
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.10.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
In steam generating equipment, caustic corrosion is best prevented through proper design.  Damage
can be minimized by reducing the amount of free caustic, by ensuring adequate water flooding and
water flow, by ensuring proper burner management to minimize hot spots on heater tubes, and by
minimizing the ingress of alkaline producing salts into condensers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
In process equipment, caustic injection facilities should be designed to allow proper mixing and
dilution of caustic in order to avoid the concentration of caustic on hot metal surfaces.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Carbon steel and 300 Series SS have serious corrosion problems in high strength caustic solutions
above about 150°F (66°C).  Alloy 400 and some other nickel base alloys exhibit much lower
corrosion rates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.10.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For process equipment, UT thickness gauging is useful to detect and monitor general corrosion due
to caustic. However, localized losses due to caustic corrosion may be difficult to locate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Injection points should be inspected in accordance with API 570.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
UT scans and radiography can be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Steam generation equipment may require visual inspection with the use a boroscope.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.10.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Caustic corrosion is also referred to as caustic gouging or ductile gouging.  A related mechanism is
known as Departure from Nucleate Boiling (DNB) as discussed in steam blanketing (See  4.2.11 ).<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.10.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, “Failure Analysis and Prevention,” Volume 11, ASM International, Materials
Park, OH.
2. R.D. Port and H.M. Herro,  “The NALCO Guide to Boiler Failure Analysis,” McGraw-Hill, Inc., NY,
1991, pp. 58 -70.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_167>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-143
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.11 Dealloying<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.11.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Dealloying is a selective corrosion mechanism in which one or more constituents of an alloy are
preferentially attacked leaving a lower density (dealloyed) often porous structure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Component failure may occur suddenly and unexpectedly because mechanical properties of the
dealloyed material are significantly degraded.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.11.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Primarily copper alloys (brass, bronze, tin) as well as Alloy 400 and cast iron.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.11.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Factors which influence dealloying include the composition of the alloy and exposure conditions
including temperature, degree of aeration, pH and exposure time.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Dealloying occurs with several different alloys but is usually limited to very specific alloy-environment
combinations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Exact conditions under which dealloying occurs are often hard to define and damage may occur
progressively over many years in service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Common examples of where dealloying has been found to occur are listed in  Table 4-7 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.11.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Underground cast iron piping when exposed to certain soils.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
In cooling water applications, heat exchanger tubing (brass, Al brass) is susceptible to dealloying in
some brackish and seawater applications but often the tubesheets suffer significant damage.
Problems may also occur in some fresh or domestic water systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Boiler feedwater piping systems and afterboiler components may suffer dealloying including bronze
pumps, Monel strainers and brass pressure gage fittings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.11.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
There is often a significant color change or a deep etched (corroded) appearance as one element is
removed from the alloy.  However, depending on the alloy, the outward appearance of the affected
material may not be noticeable upon visual inspection, even where the full wall thickness is
degraded.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Attack may be uniform through the cross-section (layer-type) or it can be localized (plug-type)
( Figure 4-101  and  Figure 4-102 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In some cases, the original material is completely dealloyed yet the component exhibits virtually no
dimensional or other visible changes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.11.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
It is often difficult to predict whether conditions will be conducive to dealloying in a particular
environment or service, so that one must be cognizant of the susceptibility of certain alloys, and the
possible resulting consequences.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Resistance to dealloying can sometimes be improved by the addition of certain alloying elements so
that a similar alloy with a different composition may be resistant.  For example, tin tends to inhibit
dealloying of copper alloys; admiralty brass is inhibited by the addition of a very small amount of
phosphorous, antimony or arsenic; and dealuminification of aluminum-bronze can be prevented by
heat treatment to produce an  α  and  β  microstructure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_168>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-144
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Continued degradation of a dealloyed component can only be prevented by altering the exposure
conditions or replacing it with a resistant material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Depending on the alloy-environment combination, cathodic protection or barrier coatings may be
effective.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.11.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Many alloys change color in the affected area, however, scale removal may be required to determine
the depth of attack.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Dealloying in brasses is visually evident by a reddish, copper color instead of the yellow brass color.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Graphitic corrosion turns<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
cast iron charcoal gray and the material can be cut or gouged with a knife.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Metallographic examination may be required to confirm the extent of damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
A significant reduction in hardness may accompany dealloying, although affected areas may be
localized.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Acoustic techniques (loss of “metallic ring”) and ultrasonic attenuation are applicable, but UT
thickness measurements are not.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Fitness-For-Service (FFS) analysis of dealloyed components should consider that the dealloyed
portion may be brittle and contribute little or no mechanical strength or load bearing capability.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.11.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Dealloying is often referred to by the element removed, as in dezincification, destannification,
denickelification, dealuminification and graphitic corrosion.  Dealloying has also been referred to as
selective leaching.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Graphitic corrosion affects cast irons and is further described in  4.3.12 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.11.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion,” Volume 13, ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
2. A. Cohen, “Copper and Copper-Base Alloys,” Process Industries Corrosion – The Theory and
Practice, NACE International,  Houston,TX, 1986.
3. R.D. Port and H.M. Herro,  “The NALCO Guide to Boiler Failure Analysis,” McGraw-Hill, Inc., NY,
1991, pp. 259-263.
4. ASM Metals Handbook, “Failure Analysis and Prevention,” Volume 11, ASM International, Materials
Park, OH.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-145
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Table 4-7 – Combinations of Alloys and Environment Subject to Dealloying. (Reference 1)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Alloy
Environment
Element Removed<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Brasses (>15% Zn) *
Many waters, especially
stagnant conds.

<<PARAGRAPH>>Gray Cast Iron
Soils, many waters
Iron (graphitic corrosion)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Aluminum bronze<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>HF acid, acids w/chloride ions,<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>seawater
Aluminum (dealuminification)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>(primarily w/> 8% Al)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Silicon bronzes
High-temp steam and acidic
species
Silicon (desiliconification)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Tin bronzes
Hot brine or steam
Tin (destannification)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copper nickels (70-30)
High heat flux and low water
velocity
Nickel (denickelification)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Monel
Hydrofluoric and other acids
Nickel (denickelification)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>*   The extent of dezinification increases with increasing zinc content.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Alloy                                                                  | Environment                     | Element Removed              |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------------|:--------------------------------|:-----------------------------|
| Brasses (>15% Zn) *                                                    | Many waters, especially         | Zinc (dezincification)       |
|                                                                        | stagnant conds.                 |                              |
| Gray Cast Iron                                                         | Soils, many waters              | Iron (graphitic corrosion)   |
| Aluminum bronze                                                        | HF acid, acids w/chloride ions, | Aluminum (dealuminification) |
| (primarily w/> 8% Al)                                                  | seawater                        |                              |
| Silicon bronzes                                                        | High-temp steam and acidic      | Silicon (desiliconification) |
|                                                                        | species                         |                              |
| Tin bronzes                                                            | Hot brine or steam              | Tin (destannification)       |
| Copper nickels (70-30)                                                 | High heat flux and low water    | Nickel (denickelification)   |
|                                                                        | velocity                        |                              |
| Monel                                                                  | Hydrofluoric and other acids    | Nickel (denickelification)   |
| * The extent of dezinification increases with increasing zinc content. |                                 |                              |
<<TABLE_END>>

<<PAGE_171>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-147
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.12 Graphitic Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.12.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cast irons are comprised of graphite particles embedded in an iron matrix. Graphitic corrosion is a
form of dealloying in which the iron matrix is corroded, leaving corrosion products and porous
graphite.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Attack results in a porous structure with a loss of strength, ductility and density.  It usually occurs
under low pH and stagnant conditions, especially in contact with soils or waters high in sulfates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.12.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Primarily gray cast iron, but also nodular and malleable cast irons experience graphitic corrosion.
However, nodular and malleable cast irons tend to crumble when attacked.  White iron is not subject to
this damage because there is no free graphite.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.12.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Graphitic corrosion occurs with several different cast iron alloys but is usually limited to very specific
microstructure-environment combinations.  Factors that influence graphitic corrosion include the
composition of the alloy and exposure conditions including temperature, degree of aeration, pH and
exposure time.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Damage occurs in the presence of moisture or an aqueous phase, usually below 200°F (93°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Damage may take many months or years to progress but can increase in severity if the pH drops.
Much of the damage occurs during stagnant conditions when high concentrations of sulfates are
present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Graphite is cathodic to the iron matrix.  The iron matrix preferentially corrodes and cathodically
protects the graphite in certain conductive waters or soils.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Graphitic corrosion may affect adjacent components by causing galvanic corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.12.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Graphitic corrosion can occur in soft water, salt water, mine waters, dilute acids and in underground
piping as well as in boiler feedwater equipment.  Typical examples include feedwater piping, pumps
(including pump impellers), valves, and underground cast iron pipe. Fire water systems are particularly
vulnerable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.12.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Damage may be widespread or it may also occur in localized areas in which the majority of the
component is unaffected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The damage may not be noticeable upon visual inspection even where the full wall thickness is
degraded.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Damaged areas will be soft and easily gouged with a knife or hand tool.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Metallographic examination may be required to confirm the extent of damage ( Figure 4-103  through
Figure 4-110 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.12.6
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
UT is not a good method for detecting damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Acoustic techniques (loss of “metallic ring”) and ultrasonic attenuation are applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
A significant reduction in hardness may accompany dealloying, although affected areas may be
localized.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |

<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_172>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-148
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.12.7
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
It is often difficult to predict if exposure conditions will cause this form of dealloying in a particular
environment or service. One must be aware of the potential susceptibility of cast irons.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Internal graphitic corrosion can be prevented by coatings and/or cement linings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
External graphitic corrosion can be prevented by external coatings or cathodic protection in severely
corrosive soils.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.3.12.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Also known as selective leaching, graphitic corrosion is a form of dealloying (see  4.3.11 ) of cast irons.  It
should not be confused with graphitization, the decomposition of carbides at high temperatures (see
4.2.1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.3.12.9
References
1. R.D. Port and H.M. Herro, “The NALCO Guide to Boiler Failure Analysis,” McGraw-Hill, Inc., NY,
1991, pp. 259-263.
2. ASM Metals Handbook, “Failure Analysis and Prevention,” Volume 11, ASM International, Materials
Park, OH.
3. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion,” Volume 13, ASM International, Materials Park, OH.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_177>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-153
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4
High Temperature Corrosion [>400°F (204°C)]<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.1
Oxidation<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.1.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Oxygen reacts with carbon steel and other alloys at high temperature converting the metal to oxide
scale.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
It is most often present as oxygen is in the surrounding air (approximately 20%) used for combustion
in fired heaters and boilers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.1.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All iron based materials including carbon steel and low alloy steels, both cast and wrought.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
All 300 Series SS, 400 Series SS and nickel base alloys also oxidize to varying degrees, depending
on composition and temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.1.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The primary factors affecting high temperature oxidation are metal temperature and alloy
composition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Oxidation of carbon steel begins to become significant above about 1000°F (538°C).  Rates of metal
loss increase with increasing temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In general, the resistance of carbon steel and other alloys is determined by the chromium content of
the material.  Increasing chromium levels produce a more protective oxide scale.  The 300 Series SS
are resistant to scaling up to about 1500°F (816°C). See  Table 4-8 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The presence of water vapor can significantly accelerate oxidation rates of some steels including
9Cr-1Mo (Reference 4.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.1.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Oxidation occurs in fired heaters and boilers as well as other combustion equipment, piping and
equipment that operates in high temperature environments when metal temperatures exceed about
1000°F (538°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.1.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Most alloys, including carbon steels and low alloy steels, suffer general thinning due to oxidation.
Usually, the component will be covered on the outside surface with an oxide scale, depending on the
temperature and exposure time ( Figure 4-111  to  4-113 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
300 Series SS and nickel alloys generally have a very thin dark scale unless exposed to extremely
high temperatures where metal loss rates are excessive.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.1.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Resistance to oxidation is best achieved by upgrading to a more resistant alloy.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Chromium is the primary alloying element that affects resistance to oxidation.  Other alloying
elements, including silicon and aluminum, are effective but their concentrations are limited due to
adverse affects on mechanical properties.  They are often used in special alloys for applications such
as heater supports, burner tips and components for combustion equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.1.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Process conditions should be monitored for establishing trends of high temperature equipment
where oxidation can occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_178>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-154
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Temperatures can be monitored through the use of tubeskin thermocouples and/or infrared
thermography.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Loss in thickness due to oxidation is usually measured using external ultrasonic thickness
measurements.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.1.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Oxidation damage referred to in this section is due to surface scaling.  Some damage mechanisms result
in internal oxidation  which is outside the scope of this document.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.4.1.9
References
1. API RP 581, Risk-Based Inspection Technology, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.,
2008.
2. J. Gutzeit et al., “Corrosion in Petroleum Refining and Petrochemical Operations” ASM Metals
Handbook, Volume 13, ASM International, OH, 1987, pp. 1262 – 1288.
3. “Corrosion Basics – An Introduction,” NACE International, Houston, TX, 1984, pp. 276 - 288.
4. F. Dettenwanger  et al., “The influence  of  Si, W and  water vapor on the oxidation behavior of 9Cr
steels”, Paper No. 01151, NACE International, Houston, TX, 2001.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

} | p 1 t ,]
<<HEADING level=3>>Figure 4-111 – Oxidation of a carbon steel nut on a stainless steel stud at 1300°F (704°C).<<HEADING_END>>

<<PAGE_183>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-159
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.2
Sulfidation<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.2.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Corrosion of carbon steel and other alloys resulting from their reaction with sulfur compounds in high
temperature environments. The presence of hydrogen accelerates corrosion.  This mechanisms is also
known as sulfidic corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.2.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All iron based materials including carbon steel and low alloy steels, 300 Series SS and 400 Series
SS.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Nickel base alloys are also affected to varying degrees depending on composition, especially
chromium content.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Copper base alloys form sulfide at lower temperatures than carbon steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.2.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Major factors affecting sulfidation are alloy composition, temperature and concentration of corrosive
sulfur compounds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Susceptibility of an alloy to sulfidation is determined by its ability to form protective sulfide scales.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Sulfidation of iron-based alloys usually begins at metal temperatures above 500°F (260°C).  The
typical effects of increasing temperature, chromium content and sulfur content on metal loss are
shown in  Figure 4-114  and  Figure115.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Note: These graphs are provided for reference only for general estimating of corrosion behavior and
trends, and should not be used to make an exact determination of corrosion rates.  The references at
the end of this section should be consulted for additional background on the development of these
curves.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
In general, the resistance of iron and nickel base alloys is determined by the chromium content of the
material.  Increasing the chromium content significantly increases resistance to sulfidation.  300
Series SS, such as Types 304, 316, 321 and 347, are highly resistant in most refining process
environments. Nickel base alloys are similar to stainless steels in that similar levels of chromium
provide similar resistance to sulfidation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Crude oils, coal and other hydrocarbon streams contain sulfur at various concentrations.  Total sulfur
content is made up of many different sulfur-containing compounds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Sulfidation is primarily caused by H 2 S and other reactive sulfur species as a result of the thermal
decomposition of sulfur compounds at high temperatures.  Some sulfur compounds react more
readily to form H 2 S. Therefore, it can be misleading to predict corrosion rates based on weight
percent sulfur alone.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
A sulfide scale on the surface of the component offers varying degrees of protection depending on
the alloy and the severity of the process stream.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.2.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Sulfidation occurs in piping and equipment in high temperature environments where sulfur-containing
streams are processed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Common areas of concern are the crude, FCC, coker, vacuum, visbreaker and hydroprocessing
units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Heaters fired with oil, gas, coke and most other sources of fuel may be affected depending on sulfur
levels in the fuel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Boilers and high temperature equipment exposed to sulfur-containing gases can be affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_184>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-160
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.2.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Depending on service conditions, corrosion is most often in the form of uniform thinning but can also
occur as localized corrosion or high velocity erosion-corrosion damage ( Figure 4-116  to  4-120 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
A sulfide scale will usually cover the surface of components.  Deposits may be thick or thin
depending on the alloy, corrosiveness of the stream, fluid velocities and presence of contaminants .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.2.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Resistance to sulfidation is generally achieved by upgrading to a higher chromium alloy.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Piping and equipment constructed from solid or clad 300 Series SS or 400 Series SS can provide
significant resistance to corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Aluminum diffusion treatment of low alloy steel components is sometimes used to reduce sulfidation
rates and minimize scale formation, however, it may not offer complete protection.  300 Series SS
catalyst support screens in hydroprocessing reactors can also be treated to prolong life.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.2.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Process conditions should be monitored for increasing temperatures and/or changing sulfur levels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Temperatures can be monitored through the use of tubeskin thermocouples and/or infrared
thermography.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Evidence of thinning can be detected using external ultrasonic thickness measurements and profile
radiography.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Proactive and retroactive PMI programs are used for alloy verification and to check for alloy mix-ups
in services where sulfidation is anticipated (Reference 7).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.2.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Sulfidation is also known as sulfidic corrosion.  High temperature sulfidation in the presence of hydrogen
is covered in  5.1.1.5 .<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.4.2.9
References
1. H.F. McConomy, “High Temperature Sulfidic Corrosion in Hydrogen-Free Environments,” API
Proceedings, Vol. 43, (III), pp. 78-96, 1963.
2. J. Gutzeit,  “High Temperature Sulfidic Corrosion of Steels”, Process Industries Corrosion – The
Theory and Practice,” NACE International, Houston, TX, 1986, pp. 171-189.
3. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion in Petroleum Refining and Petrochemical Operations,” Volume 13,
ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
4. E. B Backenstow et al, “ High Temperature Hydrogen Sulfide Corrosion”, CORROSION, Vol. 12, No.
1, 1956, pp 6t-16t.
5. NACE Task Group 176 Draft Report, “Overview of Sulfidic Corrosion in Petroleum Refining”, NACE
International, Houston, TX, 2003.
6. API RP 939-C Guidelines for Avoiding Sulfidation Corrosion Failures in Oil Refineries, American
Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C,.
7. API RP 578, “Material Verification Program for New and Existing Alloy Piping Systems”, American
Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_190>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-166
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.3
Carburization<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.3.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon is absorbed into a material at elevated temperature while in contact with a carbonaceous material
or carburizing environment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.3.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel and low alloy steels, 300 Series SS and 400 Series SS, cast stainless steels, nickel base
alloys with significant iron content (e.g., Alloys 600 and 800) and HK/HP alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.3.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Three conditions must be satisfied:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Exposure to a carburizing environment or carbonaceous material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Temperature high enough to allow diffusion of carbon into the metal [typically above 1100°F
(593°C)].<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Susceptible material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Conditions favoring carburization include a high gas phase carbon activity (hydrocarbons, coke,
gases rich in CO, CO 2 , methane, ethane) and low oxygen potential (minimal O 2  or steam).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Initially, carbon diffuses into the component at a high rate and then tapers off as the depth of
carburization increases.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In carbon steels and low alloy steels, carbon reacts to form a hard, brittle structure at the surface that
may crack or spall upon cooling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
300 Series SS are more resistant than carbon steel and the low alloy steels due to higher chromium
and nickel content.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Carburization can result in the loss of high temperature creep ductility, loss of ambient temperature
mechanical properties (specifically toughness/ductility), loss of weldability, and corrosion resistance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.3.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Fired heater tubes are the most common type of equipment susceptible to carburization in the
environments mentioned earlier.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Coke deposits are a source of carbon that may promote carburization, particularly during decoke
cycles where temperatures exceed the normal operating temperatures, accelerating the
carburization.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Carburization is sometimes found in heater tubes in catalytic reformers and coker units or other
heaters where steam/air decoking is performed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Carburization is also encountered in ethylene pyrolysis and steam reformer furnaces. Significant
carburization occurs during decoking cycles.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.3.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The depth of carburization can be confirmed by metallography.  Figure 4-121  to  4-122 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Carburization can be confirmed by substantial increases in hardness and loss in ductility.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In a more advanced stage, there may be a volumetric increase in the affected component.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
A change (increase) in the level of ferromagnetism can occur in some alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_191>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-167
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Carburization results in the formation of metal carbides depleting the surrounding matrix of the
carbide-forming element.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.3.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Select alloys with adequate resistance to carburization including alloys with a strong surface oxide or
sulfide film formers (silicon and aluminum).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Reduce the carbon activity of the environment through lower temperatures and higher oxygen/sulfur
partial pressures.  Sulfur inhibits carburization and is often added in the process stream in small
amounts in steam/gas cracking in olefin and thermal hydrodealkylation units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.3.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Inspection for carburization in the initial stages of attack is difficult.  If the process side surfaces are
accessible, hardness testing and field metallography can be used.  Destructive sampling and
magnetic based techniques (Eddy Current) have also been used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Inspection techniques based on determining increased levels of ferromagnetism (magnetic
permeability) are also useful for alloys that are paramagnetic when initially installed (austenitic
alloys). However, surface oxides may interfere with the results.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In the advanced stages of carburization where cracking has initiated, RT, UT and some magnetic
techniques may be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.3.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A severe form of carburization known as metal dusting is discussed in  4.4.5 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.4.3.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion,” Volume 13, ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
2. Dr. Hans J. Grabke, “Carburization,”  Part 1: State-of-the-Art Review; Part 2: Best Practices for
Testing Alloys, MTI Publication No. 52.
3. API RP 939-C “Guidelines for Avoiding Sulfidation Corrosion Failures in Oil Refineries”, American
Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C..<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_193>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-169
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.4
Decarburization<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.4.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A condition where steel loses strength due the removal of carbon and carbides leaving only an iron
matrix.  Decarburization occurs during exposure to high temperatures, during heat treatment, from
exposure to fires, or from high temperature service in a gaseous environment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.4.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steels and low alloy steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.4.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Time, temperature and carbon activity of the process stream are the critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The material must be exposed to a gas phase that has a low carbon activity so that carbon in the
steel will diffuse to the surface to react with gas phase constituents.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The extent and depth of decarburization is a function of the temperature and exposure time.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Typically, shallow decarburization can slightly decrease the strength of the material, but has no
detrimental effect on the overall performance of the component.  However, it is indicative that the
steel may have been overheated and suggests other effects may be present (e.g. decarburization
associated with HTHA in hydrogen services).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Potential loss in room temperature tensile strength and creep strength may occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.4.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Decarburization can occur in almost any equipment that is exposed to elevated temperatures, heat
treated or exposed to a fire.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Piping and equipment in hot hydrogen service in hydroprocessing units or catalytic reforming units as
well as fired heater tubes can be affected.  Pressure vessel components that are hot formed during
fabrication can be affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.4.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Damage can be verified by metallography.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Damage occurs on the surface exposed to the gas environment but in extreme cases may be
through wall.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The decarburized layer will be free of carbide phases. Carbon steel will be pure iron ( Figure 4-123  to
4-124 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.4.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Decarburization can be controlled by controlling the chemistry of the gas phase and alloy selection
(API RP 941).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Alloy steels with chromium and molybdenum form more stable carbides and are more resistant to
decarburization.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Steels operating in high temperature hydrogen environments should be selected in accordance with
API RP 941.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.4.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Field Metallography and Replication (FMR) can confirm decarburization.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Decarburization results in a softening that can be confirmed by hardness testing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>4-170
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.4.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>High Temperature Hydrogen Attack (HTHA) (see  5.1.3.1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.4.4.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion,” Volume 13, ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
2. API RP941, Steels for Hydrogen Service at Elevated Temperatures in Petroleum Refineries and
Petrochemical Plants, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

pearlite carbide (dark layered phases).<<HEADING_END>>

providing pearlitic phases have been decomposed as a result of the removal of carbon atoms by
diffusion to the surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute

<<PAGE_196>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-172
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.5
Metal Dusting<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.5.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Metal dusting is form of carburization resulting in accelerated localized pitting which occurs in carburizing
gases and/or process streams containing carbon and hydrogen.  Pits usually form on the surface and
may contain soot or graphite dust.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.5.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Low alloy steels, 300 Series SS, nickel base alloys and heat resisting alloys.  There is currently no known
metal alloy that is immune to metal dusting under all conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.5.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Process stream composition, operating temperature and alloy composition are critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Metal dusting is preceded by carburization and is characterized by rapid metal wastage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Metal dusting involves a complex series of reactions involving a reducing gas such as hydrogen,
methane, propane or CO.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
It usually occurs in the operating temperature range of 900°F to 1500°F (482°C to 816°C). Damage
increases with increasing temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The mechanism of metal dusting is considered to be:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Saturation of the metal matrix by carburization;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Precipitation of metal carbides at the metal surface and grain boundaries;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Deposition of graphite from the atmosphere onto the metal carbides at the surface;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Decomposition of the metal carbides under the graphite and metal particles; and<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Further deposition of graphite catalyzed by the metal particles on the surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
In high nickel alloys, it is thought that metal dusting occurs without the formation of metal carbides.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Metal dusting can also occur under alternating reducing and oxidizing conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.5.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Primarily fired heater tubes, thermowells and furnace components operating in carburizing
environments are affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Metal dusting has been reported in catalytic reforming unit heater tubes, coker heaters, gas turbines,
methanol reforming unit outlet piping and thermal hydrodealkylation furnaces and reactors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.5.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
In low alloy steels, the wastage can be uniform but usually is in the form of small pits filled with a
crumbly residue of metal oxides and carbides.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The corrosion product is a voluminous carbon dust containing metal particles and sometimes metal
oxides and carbides.  Frequently, this dust will be swept away by the flowing process stream, leaving
behind only the thinned or pitted metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In stainless and high alloy steels, the attack is frequently local, appearing as deep, round pits ( Figure
4-125 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Metallography will show that the metal is heavily carburized under the attacked surface ( Figure 4-
126 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_197>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-173
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.5.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Sulfur in the carburizing atmosphere (usually as H 2 S), forms a protective sulfide that minimizes
carburization and metal dusting. It is thought that sulfur retards the carbon transfer from the
atmosphere to the metal and suppresses graphite nucleation and growth.  For protection, sufficient
H 2 S must always be in the process environment.  If the H 2 S level drops too low, even for a short
period of time, damage may occur.  Sulfur is a catalyst poison in some processing units so that the
introduction of H 2 S into a process stream may not always be practical.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
There is currently no known metal alloy that is immune to metal dusting under all conditions.
Materials selection must be made based on the specific application and environment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
An aluminum diffusion treatment to the base metal substrate can be beneficial in some applications.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.5.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For heater tubes with suspected damage, compression wave ultrasonic testing is probably the most
efficient method of inspection since large areas can be inspected relatively quickly.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
RT techniques can be employed to look for pitting and wall thinning.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
If internal surfaces are accessible, visual inspection is effective.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Filtering the cooled furnace or reactor effluent may yield metal particles that are a tell tale indication
of a metal dusting problem upstream.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.5.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Metal dusting is also known as catastrophic carburization.  Carburization is discussed in  4.4.3.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.4.5.9
References
1. H. J. Grabke, “Metal Dusting of Low- and High-Alloy Steels,” CORROSION/51, 1995,  p. 711.
2. H. J. Grabke, R. Krajak, and J. C. Nava Paz, “On the Mechanism of Catastrophic Carburization:
Metal Dusting,” Corrosion Science, Vol. 35, Nos. 5-8, 1993,  p. 1141.
3. B. A. Baker and G. D. Smith, “Metal Dusting of Nickel-Containing Alloys,” CORROSION/98, Paper
No. 445, NACE International, Houston, TX, 1998.
4. “Corrosion Control in the Refining Industry,” NACE Course Book, NACE International, Houston, TX,
1999.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_199>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-175
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.6
Fuel Ash Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.6.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Fuel ash corrosion is accelerated high temperature wastage of materials that occurs when
contaminants in the fuel form deposits and melt on the metal surfaces of fired heaters, boilers and
gas turbines.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion typically occurs with fuel oil or coal that is contaminated with a combination of sulfur,
sodium, potassium and/or vanadium.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The resulting molten salts (slags) dissolve the surface oxide and enhance the transport of oxygen to
the surface to re-form the iron oxide at the expense of the tube wall or component.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.6.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All conventional alloys used for process heater and boiler construction are susceptible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Alloys of the 50Cr-50Ni family show improved resistance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.6.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The concentration of molten salt forming contaminants, metal temperature and alloy composition are
the critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The severity of damage depends on the type of fuel (i.e., the concentrations of contaminants in the
fuel), sulfur content and metal temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion occurs by this mechanism only if the metal temperature is above the temperature of the
liquid species formed, and it is most severe where the temperatures are the highest.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The corrosion rates differ depending on the alloy and location within the heater.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The liquid species (slags) are different for the oil and coal ash and are also different for waterwall-
tube corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
For oil ash, the liquid species are mixtures of vanadium pentoxide and sodium oxide, or
vanadium pentoxide and sodium sulfate.  Depending on the precise composition, melting points
below 1000°F (538°C) are possible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
For waterwall corrosion, the liquid species are mixtures of sodium and potassium pyrosulfates
that have melting points as low as 700°F (371°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
For coal ash, superheater and reheater corrosion is caused by sodium and potassium iron
trisulfates that melt between 1030°F and 1130°F (544°C and 610°C), depending on the ratio of
sodium and potassium. Reducing conditions, that is, a flue gas rich in carbon monoxide,
hydrogen sulfide and hydrogen will aggravate the corrosion rates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Unburned coal particles also add carbon to the fly ash deposits and provide a reducing environment
on the tube surface where corrosion occurs. Carburization of the tube surface, especially on
austenitic alloys will decrease corrosion resistance and increase tube wastage rates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Corrosion rates under reducing conditions may be 2 to 5 times faster than under oxidizing conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.6.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Fuel ash corrosion can occur in any fired heater or gas turbine utilizing fuels with the aforementioned
contaminants.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Fuel ash corrosion is most often associated with fired heaters burning vanadium and sodium
contaminated fuel oils or residue.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,``<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute `,`                            |
|:----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API ,``                            |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS ``,` |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_200>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-176
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Heater tubes are sometimes not affected because their skin temperatures are cooler than the
threshold melting point of the slags in most heaters.  Tube hangers and supports, however, operate
hotter and can suffer severe fuel ash corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Some gas turbines suffer blade corrosion when switched over to burning fuel oil.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
In some cases, coking of the heater tubes may cause operators to increase heat flux that may push
some components above the threshold temperature where fuel ash corrosion is possible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Since the melting points of these liquid species are around 1000°F (538°C) and higher in the
superheaters and reheaters, any unit that has metal temperatures above the melting point of the
sulfates may have the problem.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
For oil-fired boilers, fuel oils that do not contain vanadium are less prone to liquid ash corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
For waterwalls, if the temperature can be maintained below the melting point of the pyrosulfates [that
is below 700°F (371°C)], damage will be minimized.  Thus, steam generating pressures below about
1800 psi are nearly immune.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.6.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Oil ash corrosion is manifested as severe metal loss associated with slagging.  In some cases,
corrosion rates of 100 to 1000 mpy may be experienced.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Metallographic examination and deposit-analysis techniques can be used to verify the presence of
fuel ash corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
For oil ash corrosion of superheaters and reheaters, the appearance of the ash deposit will be in at
least two distinct layers.  The important deposit is adjacent to the component, which will have a dark
gray or black appearance at room temperature. As the liquid sulfates sinter the corrosion debris to
the surface,  a hard, glassy, tenacious scale is formed.  When removed, the surface of the steel will
have an “alligator-hide” appearance ( Figure 4-127  and  Figure 4-128 ) as shallow grooves will have
penetrated the steel in a cross-hatched pattern.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
For waterwalls, the cracks are predominantly circumferential and, to a lesser extent, axial.  The
overall appearance on the waterwalls is one of circumferential grooving.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
After the liquid ash layer develops, the “slush” can only hold a certain weight of ash.  When the
weight is excessive, the slag is shed, exposing a bare, uninsulated tube to the heat flux of the
firebox.  The temperatures will spike on waterwalls, by perhaps 100°F (38°C) and the cracking
is then similar to thermal fatigue.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
The mechanism for the steam-cooled tubes is similar, except that the temperature spike is
probably less and, therefore, the thermal fatigue damage is less severe.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
The alligator-hide morphology of superheaters and reheaters and the circumferential cracking
on waterwalls in coal-fired boilers is caused by a similar mechanism.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
For coal ash, the appearance will be a smooth interface between a glassy slag layer and the metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.6.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Fuel ash corrosion can be prevented by blending or changing fuel sources (minimizing the
contaminants) and by operating equipment so that hot components are below the temperature where
molten deposits are formed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Proper burner design and burner management can help to reduce flame impingement and localized
hot spots.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_201>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-177
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In some cases, the characteristics and melting points of the slags can be changed by firing with low
excess oxygen or by injecting special additives into the fuel.  These changes can increase the
melting point of the slags and reduce the tendency of the deposits to stick to metal surfaces or
dissolve the protective oxide scale.  Even with changes to reduce slag formation, corrosion may
continue if metal surfaces are not cleaned to remove slag and corrosion products.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Corrosion of some components, such as tube hangers and supports, can be minimized by changing
to a 50%Cr-50%Ni alloy, such as Alloy 657.  Designs of tube hangers may need to be modified to
account for the lower stress-rupture strength of the 50Cr-50Ni alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.6.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Visual inspection is usually sufficient to detect hot ash corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Metal loss is likely to be severe and the presence of a slag will be apparent.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Tubes need to be grit blasted in order to remove the tenacious glass-like ash deposit.  UT
examination may be useful to measure loss of thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.6.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Hot corrosion, hot ash corrosion, molten salt corrosion, oil ash corrosion and coal ash corrosion are
all terms used to describe this mechanism.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Circumferential cracking in waterwall tubes is similar to thermal fatigue aggravated by a corrosive
environment ( Figure 4-129 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.4.6.9
References
1. “Steam - Its Generation and Use,” 40th Edition,  Babcock and Wilcox, 1992.
2. “Combustion Fossil Power Systems,” Third Edition, Combustion Engineering, Windsor, CT, 1981.
3. H. Thielsch, “Defects and Failures In Pressure Vessels and Piping,” Krieger Publishing Co., NY,
1977.
4. R.D. Port and H.M. Herro, “The NALCO Guide to Boiler Failure Analysis,” McGraw Hill, NY, 1991.
5. D.N. French,  “Metallurgical Failures In Fossil Fired Boilers,” John Wiley and Sons, Publishers, Inc.,
NY, 1993.
6. B. Dooley and W. Mcnaughton, “Boiler Tube Failures: Theory and Practice – 3 Volumes,” EPRI, CA,
1995.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
