<<PAGE_204>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-180
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.7
Nitriding<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.7.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A hard, brittle surface layer will develop on some alloys due to exposure to high temperature process
streams containing high levels of nitrogen compounds such ammonia or cyanides, particularly under
reducing conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.7.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbon steels, low alloy steels, 300 Series SS and 400 Series SS.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Nickel base alloys are more resistant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.7.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Nitriding is a diffusion controlled process dependent on temperature, time, partial pressure of
nitrogen and metal composition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Temperatures must be high enough to allow for the thermal breakdown/disassociation of nitrogen
from ammonia or other compounds and for diffusion of nitrogen into the metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Nitriding begins above 600°F (316°C) and becomes severe above 900°F (482°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
High gas phase nitrogen activity (high partial pressures of nitrogen) promotes nitriding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Corrosion resistance may be adversely affected by nitriding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Alloys containing 30% to 80% nickel are more resistant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
A loss of high temperature creep strength, ambient temperature mechanical properties (specifically
toughness/ductility), weldability and corrosion resistance may result.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.7.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Nitriding can occur at any location where appropriate environment and temperature conditions are met,
but it is considered to be fairly rare.  Nitriding has been observed in steam methane-reformers, steam gas
cracking (olefin plants) and ammonia synthesis plants.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.7.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Nitriding is usually confined to the surface of most components and will have a dull, dark gray
appearance.  However, during initial stages of nitriding, damage can only be seen with
metallography as shown in  Figure 4-130 ,  Figure 4-131  and  Figure 4-132 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
In a more advanced stage, the material will exhibit very high surface hardness.  In most cases, a
slightly harder surface layer of a vessel or component will not affect the mechanical integrity of the
equipment. However, the concern is for the potential development of cracks in the nitrided layer that
could propagate into the base metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Nitriding of low alloy steels containing up to 12% chromium is accompanied by an increase in
volume. The nitrided layer tends to crack and flake.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Above 770°F (410°C), preferential grain boundary nitriding may lead to microcracking and
embrittlement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Stainless steels tend to form thin, brittle layers that may crack and spall from thermal cycling or
applied stress.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Nitrogen diffuses into the surface and forms needle-like particles of iron nitrides (Fe 3 N or Fe 4 N) that
can only be confirmed by metallography.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_205>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-181
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.7.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Changing to more resistant alloys with 30% to 80% nickel is usually required.   It is usually not practical to
modify the process conditions to reduce the nitrogen partial pressure or to lower temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.7.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
A change in surface color to a dull gray may indicate nitriding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Materials exposed to nitriding conditions should be inspected thoroughly because good appearance
may mask damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Hardness testing of the affected surfaces (400 to 500 BHN or higher) can help indicate nitriding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Nitrided layers are magnetic. Therefore, 300 Series SS should be checked for magnetism as an
initial screening.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Metallography is generally required to confirm nitriding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
EC testing may be used in some cases to detect nitriding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
In the advanced stages of nitriding, where cracking may have initiated, appropriate inspection
techniques include PT, RT and UT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.4.7.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Similar gas-metal surface reactions occur in other environments including carburization (see  4.4.3 ) and
metal dusting (see  4.4.5 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.4.7.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion,” Volume 13, ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
2. “Corrosion Basics – An Introduction,”  NACE International, Houston, TX, 1984, pp. 93-94.
3. J. Scherzer and D.P. McArthur, “Test Show Effects of Nitrogen Compounds on Commercial Fluid Cat
Cracking Catalysts,” Oil and Gas Journal, Vol. 84, 1986, p 76-82.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_208>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-184
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5
Environment – Assisted Cracking<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.1
Chloride Stress Corrosion Cracking (Cl - SCC)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.1.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Surface initiated cracks caused by environmental cracking of 300 Series SS and some nickel base alloys
under the combined action of tensile stress, temperature and an aqueous chloride environment.  The
presence of dissolved oxygen increases propensity for cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.1.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All 300 Series SS are highly susceptible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Duplex stainless steels are more resistant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Nickel base alloys are highly resistant, but not immune.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.1.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Chloride content, pH, temperature, stress, presence of oxygen and alloy composition are critical
factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Increasing temperatures increase the susceptibility to cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Increasing levels of chloride increase the likelihood of cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
No practical lower limit for chlorides exists because there is always a potential for chlorides to
concentrate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Heat transfer conditions significantly increase cracking susceptibility because they allow chlorides to
concentrate. Alternate exposures to wet-dry conditions or steam and water are also conducive to
cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
SCC usually occurs at pH values above 2. At lower pH values, uniform corrosion generally
predominates. SCC tendency decreases toward the alkaline pH region.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Cracking usually occurs at metal temperatures above about 140 o F (60 o C), although exceptions can
be found at lower temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Stress may be applied or residual. Highly stressed or cold worked components, such as expansion
bellows, are highly susceptible to cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
Oxygen dissolved in the water normally accelerates SCC but it is not clear whether there is an
oxygen concentration threshold below which chloride SCC is impossible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>j)
Nickel content of the alloy has a major affect on resistance.  The greatest susceptibility is at a nickel
content of 8% to 12%.  Alloys with nickel contents above 35% are highly resistant and alloys above
45% are nearly immune.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>k)
Low-nickel stainless steels, such as the duplex (ferrite-austenite) stainless steels, have improved
resistance over the 300 Series SS but are not immune.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>l)
Carbon steels, low alloy steels and  400 Series SS are not susceptible to Cl-SCC .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.1.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All 300 Series SS piping and pressure vessel components in any process units are susceptible to Cl-
SCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracking has occurred in water-cooled condensers and in the process side of crude tower overhead
condensers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_209>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-185
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Drains in hydroprocessing units are susceptible to cracking during startup/shutdown if not properly
purged.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Bellows and instrument tubing, particularly those associated with hydrogen recycle streams
contaminated with chlorides, can be affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
External Cl–SCC has also been a problem on insulated surfaces when insulation gets wet.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Cracking has occurred in boiler drain lines.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.1.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Surface breaking cracks can occur from the process side or externally under insulation ( Figures 4-
133  to  4-134 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The material usually shows no visible signs of corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Characteristic stress corrosion cracks have many branches and may be visually detectable by a
craze-cracked appearance of the surface ( Figure 4-135  to  Figure 4-136 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Metallography of cracked samples typically shows branched transgranular cracks ( Figure 4-137  to  4-
139 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Sometimes intergranular cracking of sensitized 300 Series SS may also be seen.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Welds in 300 Series SS usually contain some ferrite, producing a duplex structure that is usually
more resistant to Cl–SCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Corrosion-resistant nickel-based alloys are also susceptible to cracking under severe conditions
( Figure 4-140 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Fracture surfaces often have a brittle appearance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.1.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Use resistant materials of construction.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
When hydrotesting, use low chloride content water and dry out thoroughly and quickly.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Properly applied coatings under insulation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Avoid designs that allow stagnant regions where chlorides can concentrate or deposit.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
A high temperature stress relief of 300 Series SS after fabrication may reduce residual stresses.
However, consideration should be given to the possible effects of sensitization that may occur,
increasing susceptibility to polythionic SCC, possible distortion problems and potential reheat
cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.1.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cracking is surface connected and may be detected visually in some cases.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
PT or phase analysis EC techniques are the preferred methods.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Eddy current inspection methods have also been used on condenser tubes as well as piping and
pressure vessels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Extremely fine cracks may be difficult to find with PT.  Special surface preparation methods,
including polishing or high-pressure water blast, may be required in some cases, especially in high
pressure services.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
UT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Often, RT is not sufficiently sensitive to detect cracks except in advanced stages where a significant
network of cracks has developed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>4-186
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.1.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Caustic SCC (see  4.5.3 ) and polythionic acid SCC (see  5.1.2.1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.5.1.9
References
1. C.P. Dillon, “Corrosion Control in The Chemical Process Industries,” Materials Technology Institute,
MO, 1994, pp. 88-90.
2. “Corrosion Basics – An Introduction,”  NACE International, Houston, TX, 1984, pp. 111-123.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-187
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<IMAGE_87>>

<<PAGE_217>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-193
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.2
Corrosion Fatigue<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.2.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A form of fatigue cracking in which cracks develop under the combined effects of cyclic loading and
corrosion.  Cracking often initiates at a stress concentration such as a pit in the surface. Cracking can
initiate at multiple sites.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.2.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All metals and alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.2.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The critical factors are the material, corrosive environment, cyclic stresses and stress raisers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracking is more likely to occur in environments that promote pitting or localized corrosion under
cyclic stress due to thermal stress, vibration or differential expansion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Contrary to a pure mechanical fatigue, there is no fatigue limit load in corrosion-assisted fatigue.
Corrosion promotes failure at a lower stress and number of cycles than the materials’ normal
endurance limit in the absence of corrosion and often results in propagation of multiple parallel
cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Crack initiation sites include concentrators such as pits, notches, surface defects, changes in section
or fillet welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.2.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Rotating equipment, deaerators and cycling boilers, as well as any equipment subjected to cyclic stresses
in a corrosive environment. Some examples include:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Rotating Equipment<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Galvanic couples between the impeller and the pump shaft or other corrosion mechanisms may
result in a pitting problem on the shaft. The pitting can act as a stress concentrator or stress riser to
promote cracking.  Most cracking is transgranular with little branching.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Deaerators<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In the late 1980’s, deaerators in the pulp and paper, refining and petrochemical and fossil fueled
utility industries had major deaerator cracking problems. Complete vessel failures in the pulp and
paper industry resulted in a diligent inspection program that found major cracking problems across
the various industries. It was concluded that residual welding and fabrication stresses, stress risers
(attachments and weld reinforcement) and the normal deaerator environment could produce multiple
corrosion fatigue cracking problems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Cycling Boilers<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A cycling boiler may see several hundred cold starts over its useful life which, because of differential
expansion, continually cracks the protective magnetite scale, allowing corrosion to continue.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_218>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-194
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.2.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The fatigue fracture is brittle and the cracks are most often transgranular, as in stress-corrosion
cracking, but not branched, and often results in propagation of multiple parallel cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Fatigue cracking will be evidenced by very little plastic deformation except that final fracture may
occur by mechanical overload accompanied by plastic deformation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In cycling boilers, the damage usually appears first on the water side of buckstay (structural)
attachments ( Figure 4-141 ).  The cracking pattern may be circular cracks surrounding the weld
between the buckstay attachment and the waterwall tube.  In cross-section, the cracks tend to be
bulbous with numerous lobes ( Figure 4-142 ).  The crack tips themselves may be somewhat blunted
but are oxide filled and transgranular  Figure 4-143  to  4-145 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In sulfidizing environments, cracks will have a similar appearance but will be filled with a sulfide
scale.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
In rotating equipment, most cracking is transgranular with minimal branching.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.2.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Rotating Equipment<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Modify the corrosive environment by using coatings and/or inhibitors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Minimize galvanic couple effects.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Use more corrosion resistant materials.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Deaerators<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Proper feedwater and condensate chemical control.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Minimize residual welding and fabrication stresses through PWHT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Minimize weld reinforcement by grinding weld contours smooth.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Cycling Boilers<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Start up slowly to minimize the differential expansion strains.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Always start up with the chemistry of the boiler water under proper control.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.2.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Rotating Equipment<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
UT and MT techniques can be used for crack detection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Deaerators<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Cracking is generally detected with WFMT inspection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Many of the cracks are very tight and difficult to detect.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Cycling Boilers<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
The first sign of damage is usually a pinhole leak on the cold side of a waterwall tube at a
buckstay attachment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Inspect highly stressed regions in the boiler by UT or EMATS techniques.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Cracking may occur at the membranes in the highly stressed regions, particularly corners at
buckstays.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.2.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Mechanical fatigue (see  4.2.16 ) and vibration induced fatigue (see  4.2.17 ).<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.5.2.9
References
1. “Steam – Its Generation and Use,” 40th Edition, Babcock and Wilcox, 1992.
2. “Combustion Fossil Power Systems,” Third Edition, Combustion Engineering, CT, 1981.

1977.
4. R.D. Port and H.M. Herro, “The NALCO Guide To Boiler Failure Analysis,” McGraw Hill, NY, 1991.
5. D.N. French, “Metallurgical Failures in Fossil Fired Boilers,” John Wiley and Sons, Publishers, Inc.,
NY, 1993.

1995.

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-199
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.3
Caustic Stress Corrosion Cracking (Caustic Embrittlement)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.3.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Caustic embrittlement is a form of stress corrosion cracking characterized by surface-initiated cracks that
occur in piping and equipment exposed to caustic, primarily adjacent to non-PWHT’d welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.3.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Carbon steel, low alloy steels and 300 Series SS are susceptible.  Nickel base alloys are more resistant.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.3.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Susceptibility to caustic embrittlement in caustic soda (NaOH) and caustic potash (KOH) solutions is
a function of caustic strength, metal temperature and stress levels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Increasing caustic concentration and increasing temperatures increase the likelihood and severity of
cracking.  Conditions likely to result in cracking have been established through plant experience and
are presented in  Figure 4-146 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Cracking can occur at low caustic levels if a concentrating mechanism is present.  In such cases,
caustic concentrations of 50 to 100 ppm are sufficient to cause cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Stresses that promote cracking can be residual that result from welding or from cold working (such
as bending and forming) as well as applied stresses ( Figure 4-147  and  Figure 4-148 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
It is generally accepted that stresses approaching yield are required for SCC so that thermal stress
relief (PWHT) is effective in preventing caustic SCC ( Figure 4-146 ).  Although failures have occurred
at stresses that are low relative to yield, they are considered more rare ( Figure 4-149  to  Figure 4-
150 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Crack propagation rates increase dramatically with temperature and can sometimes grow through
wall in a matter of hours or days during temperature excursions, especially if conditions promote
caustic concentration.  Concentration can occur as a result of alternating wet and dry conditions,
localized hot spots or high temperature steamout.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Special care must be taken with steam tracing design and steamout of non-PWHT’d carbon steel
piping and equipment ( Figure 4-151  to  Figure 4-152 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.3.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Caustic embrittlement is often found in piping and equipment that handles caustic, including H 2 S and
mercaptan removal units, as well as equipment that uses caustic for neutralization in sulfuric acid
alkylation units and HF alkylation units.  Caustic is sometimes injected into the feed to the crude
tower for chloride control.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Failures have occurred in improperly heat-traced piping or equipment as well as heating coils and
other heat transfer equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Caustic embrittlement may occur in equipment as a result of steam cleaning after being in caustic
service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Traces of caustic can become concentrated in BFW and can result in caustic embrittlement of boiler
tubes that alternate between wet and dry conditions due to overfiring.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.3.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Caustic stress corrosion cracking typically propagates parallel to the weld in adjacent base metal but
can also occur in the weld deposit or heat-affected zones.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_224>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-200
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The pattern of cracking observed on the steel surface is sometimes described as a spider web of
small cracks which often initiate at or interconnect with weld-related flaws that serve as local stress
raisers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Cracks can be confirmed through metallographic examination as surface breaking flaws that are
predominantly intergranular.  The cracking typically occurs in as-welded carbon steel fabrications as
a network of very fine, oxide-filled cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Cracking in 300 Series SS is typically transgranular and is very difficult to distinguish from chloride
stress corrosion cracking ( Figure 4-153 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.3.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cracking can be effectively prevented by means of a stress-relieving heat treatment (e.g. PWHT).  A
heat treatment at 1150°F (621°C) is considered an effective stress relieving heat treatment for
carbon steel.  The same requirement applies to repair welds and to internal and external attachment
welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
300 Series SS offer little advantage in resistance to cracking over CS.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Nickel base alloys are more resistant to cracking and may be required at higher temperatures and/or
caustic concentrations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Steamout of non-PWHT’d carbon steel piping and equipment should be avoided.  Equipment should
be water washed before steamout.  Where steamout is required, only low-pressure steam should be
used for short periods of time to minimize exposure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Proper design and operation of the injection system is required to ensure that caustic is properly
dispersed before entering the high-temperature crude preheat system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.3.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Although cracks may be seen visually, crack detection is best performed with WFMT, EC, RT or
ACFM techniques.  Surface preparation by grit blasting, high pressure water blasting or other
methods is usually required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
PT may not be effective for finding tight, scale-filled cracks and should not be used as the only
means of detection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Fine cracks may be difficult to find with RT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Crack depths can be measured with a suitable UT technique including external SWUT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
AET can be used for monitoring crack growth and locating growing cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.3.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Amine cracking (see  5.1.2.2 ) and carbonate cracking (see  5.1.2.5 ) are two other similar forms of alkaline
SCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.5.3.9
References
1. NACE 37519, NACE Corrosion Data Survey - Metals Section, Fifth Edition, NACE International,
Houston, TX.
2. “Fitness-For Service Evaluation Procedures for Operating Pressure Vessels, Tanks, and Piping in
Refinery and Chemical Service,” MPC Report FS-26,  Draft #5, Consultants Report,  Materials
Properties Council, NY, 1995.
3. J.K. Nelson, “Materials of Construction for Alkalies and Hypochlorites,” Process Industries Corrosion -
The Theory and Practice,  NACE International,  Houston, TX, 1986, pp. 297-310.
4. NACE SP0403, Avoiding Caustic Stress Corrosion Cracking of Carbon Steel Refinery Equipment and
Piping, NACE International,  Houston, TX.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_230>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-206
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.4
Ammonia Stress Corrosion Cracking<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.4.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Aqueous streams containing ammonia may cause Stress Corrosion Cracking (SCC) in some copper
alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Carbon steel is susceptible to SCC in anhydrous ammonia.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.4.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Some copper alloys in environments with aqueous ammonia and/or ammonium compounds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Carbon steel in anhydrous ammonia.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.4.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For copper alloys<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Susceptible alloys may suffer cracking under the combination of residual stress and chemical
compounds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Copper-zinc alloys (brasses), including admiralty brass and aluminum brasses, are susceptible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Zinc content of brasses affects susceptibility, especially as zinc increases above 15%.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
A water phase with ammonia or ammoniacal compounds must be present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Oxygen is necessary, but trace amounts are sufficient.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6)
pH above 8.5.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7)
Occurs at any temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>8)
Residual stresses from fabrication or tube rolling are sufficient to promote cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
For steel<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Anhydrous ammonia with <0.2% water may cause cracking in carbon steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Cracking has been reported as low as -27°F(-33°C) in laboratory testing.  Crack growth rates
and cracking susceptibility with increasing temperature and can occur at ambient or refrigerated
conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
PWHT eliminates susceptibility of most common steels (<70 ksi tensile strength).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Contamination with air or oxygen increases tendency toward cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
High residual stresses from fabrication and welding increase susceptibility.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.4.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Copper-zinc alloy tubes in heat exchangers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Ammonia is present as a process contaminant in some services or may be intentionally added as an
acid neutralizer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Carbon steel is used for ammonia storage tanks, piping and equipment in ammonia refrigeration
units as well as some lube oil refining processes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.4.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Copper alloys<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Surface breaking cracks may show bluish corrosion products.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Exchanger tubes show single or highly branched cracks on the surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_231>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-207
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Cracking can be either transgranular ( Figure 4-154  to  4-155  or intergranular ( Figure 4-156 ).
depending on the environment and stress level.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
For carbon steel<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Cracking will occur at exposed non-PWHT welds and heat-affected zones.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Cracking is primarily intergranular in nature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.4.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Copper alloys<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Copper-zinc alloys show improved resistance as zinc content decreases below 15%.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
The 90-10CuNi and 70-30CuNi alloys are nearly immune.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
SCC in steam service can sometimes be controlled by preventing the ingress of air.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
300 Series SS and nickel base alloys are immune.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Carbon steel<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
SCC of steel can be prevented through the addition of small quantities of water to the ammonia
(0.2% minimum). Consideration must be given to vapor spaces could have less than 0.2%
water present due to partitioning of ammonia in water phase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
An effective PWHT of the vessel reduces residual stress to the point where ammonia SCC can
be prevented.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Low strength steels (<70 ksi tensile strength) should be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Weld hardness should not exceed 225 BHN.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Prevent ingress of oxygen into storage facilities.  Low levels of oxygen (< 10 ppm) have been
reported to lead to cracking under some conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.4.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For copper alloys<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Monitor pH and ammonia of water draw samples to assess susceptibility of copper alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Inspect heat exchanger tubes for cracking using EC or visual inspection. Rolled area is highly
susceptible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
For steel storage tanks and or piping in anhydrous ammonia<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
WFMT welds inside tanks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
External UT Shear wave inspection using TOFD.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
AET.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.4.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Not applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.5.4.9
References
1. “Corrosion Basics – An Introduction,”  NACE International, Houston, TX, 1984, pp. 117.
2. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion,” Volume 13, ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
3. Cohen, “Copper and Copper-Base Alloys,” Process Industries Corrosion – The Theory and Practice,
NACE International,  Houston, TX, 1986.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_234>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-210
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.5
Liquid Metal Embrittlement (LME)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.5.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Liquid Metal Embrittlement (LME) is a form of cracking that results when certain molten metals come in
contact with specific alloys.  Cracking can be very sudden and brittle in nature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.5.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Many commonly used materials including carbon steel, low alloy steels, high strength steels, 300 Series
SS, nickel base alloys and the copper alloys, aluminum alloys and titanium alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.5.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
LME occurs in very specific combinations of metals in contact with low melting point metals such as
zinc, mercury, cadmium, lead, copper and tin.  Typical combinations of industrial significance are
shown in  Table 4-9 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
High tensile stress promotes cracking, however, cracking can initiate simply through contacting the
molten metal with the susceptible alloy.  Very small quantities of the low melting point metal are
sufficient to cause LME.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Tensile stress contributes to crack propagation rates.  Cracking under load can be extremely rapid
such that cracks may pass through the wall within seconds of contact with the molten metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Cracking can occur after long periods of time when contaminated surfaces are exposed to liquid
metals.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
A susceptible metal in contact with a low melting metal at low temperatures may crack later when the
temperature rises above the melting temperature of the low melting alloy.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.5.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
During a fire, molten metals may drip onto or contact a susceptible metal.  Examples include melted
zinc galvanizing, cadmium electrical housings, tin or lead from solders, and melted copper
components.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
LME can occur in any location where the LME couples are found.  A common example is 300 Series
SS piping or vessels in contact with (or previously rubbed against) galvanized steel ( Figure 4-157
and  Figure 4-158 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In refineries, mercury is found in some crude oils and can condense in the atmospheric tower
overhead system thereby embrittling brass, Alloy 400, titanium or aluminum exchanger components.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Failure of process instruments that utilize mercury can introduce the liquid metal into refinery
streams ( Figure 4-159 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
LME of aluminum components has occurred in LNG facilities and cryogenic gas plant components
due to condensation of liquid mercury.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.5.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Damage resulting from LME will appear as brittle cracks in an otherwise ductile material.  LME can
only be confirmed through metallography by the presence of intergranular cracks, usually filled with
the low melting metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Techniques such as spectrographic analysis may be required to confirm the presence of the molten
metal species.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_235>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-211
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.5.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
LME can only be prevented by protecting metal substrates from coming into contact with the low
melting metal.  For example, galvanized steel components should not be welded to 300 Series SS.
300 Series SS should be protected to avoid contact with galvanized components and overspray from
zinc and inorganic zinc coatings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Once cracking from LME has initiated, grinding out the affected area is not an acceptable fix.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.5.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cracks can be detected with MT examination for ferritic steel and PT examination for 300 Series SS
and nickel base alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Because of the high density of mercury, radiography has been used to locate deposits inside heat
exchanger tubes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.5.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
LME is also referred to as Liquid Metal Cracking (LMC).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Nickel alloys are susceptible to a similar mechanism caused by the nickel-nickel sulfide eutectic that
forms at 1157°F (625°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.5.5.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, “Failure Analysis and Prevention,” Volume 11, ASM International, Materials
Park, OH.
2. C.P. Dillon, “Corrosion Control in The Chemical Process Industries,” Materials  Technology Institute,
MO, 1994, pp. 84 –85.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_239>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-215
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.6
Hydrogen Embrittlement (HE)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.6.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A loss in ductility of high strength steels due to the penetration of atomic hydrogen can lead to brittle
cracking.  Hydrogen Embrittlement (HE) can occur during manufacturing, welding, or from services that
can charge hydrogen into the steel in an aqueous, corrosive, or a gaseous environment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.6.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel and low alloy steels, 400 Series SS, Precipitation Hardenable (PH) SS and some high
strength nickel base alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.6.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Three conditions must be satisfied:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Hydrogen must be present at a critical concentration within the steel/alloy.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
The strength level and microstructure of the steel/alloy must be susceptible to embrittlement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
A stress above the threshold for HE must be present from residual stresses and/or applied
stresses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The hydrogen can come from:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Welding – if wet electrodes or high moisture content flux weld electrodes are used, hydrogen
can be charged into the steel (delayed cracking).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Cleaning and pickling in acid solutions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Service in high temperature hydrogen gas atmospheres, molecular hydrogen dissociates to
form atomic hydrogen that can diffuse into the steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Wet H 2 S services or HF acid services in which atomic hydrogen diffuses into the steel.
(Cyanides, arsenic and FeS can act as hydrogen recombination poisons that diminish the
hydrogen gas reaction and allows for greater charging rates.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Manufacturing – melting practices or manufacturing processes particularly where components
are plated (hydrogen flaking).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6)
Cathodic protection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The effect is pronounced at temperatures from ambient to about 300°F (149°C). Effects decrease
with increasing temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
HE affects static properties to a much greater extent than impact properties.  If the hydrogen is
present and a sufficient stress is applied, failure can occur quickly.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The amount of trapped hydrogen depends on the environment, surface reactions and the presence
of hydrogen traps in the metal such as imperfections, inclusions and pre-existing flaws or cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
The amount of hydrogen needed to have a measurable effect on the mechanical properties varies
with the strength level, microstructure and heat treatment for the alloy.  In some cases, thresholds of
critical hydrogen concentrations have been established.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Stresses include cooling during manufacture, residual stresses from welding or applied loads.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Thick wall components are more vulnerable due to increased thermal stress and high restraint and
take longer for hydrogen to diffuse out.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
In general, as strength increases, susceptibility to HE increases. Certain microstructures, such as
untempered martensite and pearlite, are more susceptible at the same strength level than tempered
martensite.  Carbon steel that is severely hydrogen charged will have lower toughness than with no
hydrogen.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_240>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-216
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.6.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Services where HE is a concern include carbon steel piping and vessels in wet H 2 S services in FCC,
hydroprocessing, amine, sour water services and HF alkylation units.  However, mild steel used for
vessels and piping in most refining, fossil utility and process applications have low hardness and are
usually not susceptible to HE except at weldments, particularly the HAZ, if suitable PWHT is not
performed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Storage spheres are often made of slightly higher strength steels and are more susceptible than
most other refinery equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Bolts and springs made of high strength steel are very prone to HE. (Alloys that have a tensile
strength above 150 ksi can absorb hydrogen during electroplating and crack.)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Cr-Mo reactors, drums and exchanger shells on hydroprocessing units and catalytic reforming units
are susceptible if the weld heat-affected zone hardness exceeds 235 BHN.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.6.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Cracking due to HE can initiate sub-surface, but in most cases is surface breaking ( Figure 4-160  to
4-161 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
HE occurs at locations of high residual or tri-axial stresses (notches, restraint) and where the
microstructure is conducive, such as in weld HAZ’s.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
On a macro-scale, there is often little evidence, although some materials will appear to have brittle
fracture surfaces.  On a microscale, the material will contain less ductile fracture surface, but must
often be compared to a fracture without the presence of hydrogen.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In higher strength steels, cracking is often intergranular.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.6.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Dependent on the source of the hydrogen, alloy composition and fabrication/heat treatment history.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Use lower strength steels and PWHT to temper the microstructure, improve ductility and reduce
residual stresses and hardness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
During welding, use low hydrogen, dry electrodes and preheating methods.  If hydrogen is expected
to have diffused into the metal, an elevated temperature bake out [400°F or higher (204°C or higher)]
may be required to drive the hydrogen out prior to welding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Heavy wall equipment in hot hydrogen service requires controlled shutdown and start-up procedures
to control the pressurization sequence as a function of temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
In corrosive aqueous services, apply a protective lining, SS cladding or weld overlay to prevent the
surface hydrogen reactions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.6.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For surface cracking inspection use PT, MT or WFMT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
UT may also be useful in finding HE cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
RT often is not sufficiently sensitive to detect HE cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
If the source of hydrogen is a low temperature aqueous environment, hydrogen flux can be
monitored using specialized instruments.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.6.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Also known as hydrogen flaking, underbead cracking, delayed cracking, hydrogen assisted cracking,
hydrogen induced cracking.  Sulfide stress cracking (see  5.1.2.3 ) and hydrogen stress corrosion cracking
in HF (see  5.1.2.4 ) are closely related forms of hydrogen embrittlement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-217
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.5.6.9
References
1. W.E. Erwin and J.G. Kerr, , “The Use of Quenched and Tempered 2-1/4Cr-1Mo Steel for Thick Wall
Reactor Vessels in Petroleum Refinery Processes: An Interpretive Review of 25 Years of Research
and Application,” WRC Bulletin No.275, Welding Research Council, Shaker Heights, OH.
2. R.S. Treseder, “Guarding Against Hydrogen Embrittlement, ” Chemical Engineering Magazine, June
1981, Chemical Week Publishing, NY, 1981.
3. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion,” Volume 13, ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
4. “Corrosion Basics – An Introduction,”  NACE International, Houston, TX, 1984, pp. 120-121.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_244>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4-220
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.7
Ethanol Stress Corrosion Cracking (SCC)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.7.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Surface-initiated cracks caused by environmental cracking of carbon steel under the combined action of
tensile stress and a fuel grade ethanol (FGE, ASTM D 4806) or FGE / gasoline blend environment.
Dissolved oxygen and the presence of variable stresses such as cyclic stress or component flexing,
increase the propensity for cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.7.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All grades of carbon steel are susceptible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Ethanol SCC has not been reported in materials other than carbon steel, but general corrosion may
be a concern with other materials including some alloys of aluminum, copper and copper alloys, lead
and zinc.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
FGE and blends with gasoline may adversely affect non-metallic materials (e.g. coatings and seals)
causing swelling, hardness changes, etc.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.7.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Several factors have been identified by field observations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Stress may be applied or residual.  Highly stressed, locally cold worked components, or
components with stress concentrators are susceptible to cracking.  Variable stresses, such as
those produced by loading and unloading of tanks, have led to cracking in tank bottoms and
floating roofs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Cracking has been found to occur in FGE meeting ASTM D 4806 specifications, including the
water content requirement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Corrosion inhibitors may be added to ethanol to prevent general corrosion in vehicle fuel
systems, but their affect on SCC is not fully understood.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Other factors have been identified in controlled laboratory conditions using conservative Slow Strain
Rate Test (SSRT) methods which stress the steel sample to failure.  Evidence of SCC is based on
the stress / strain behavior and an examination of the fracture surfaces.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Aeration (i.e. the dissolved oxygen content) of the ethanol appears to be the most important
factor for determining ethanol SCC susceptibility.  Cracking has not been found under
deaerated conditions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
The maximum potential for ethanol SCC occurs within a narrow range of water content between
0.1 and 4.5 vol%.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Ethanol SCC has been found to occur in blends of FGE and gasoline containing as little as 20
vol% FGE.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Galvanic coupling of a new steel to corroded steel increases the likelihood of ethanol SCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Increasing the chloride content of the ethanol tends to increase the severity of cracking and
changes the crack type from mainly intergranular found in the field to transgranular cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.7.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbon steel storage tanks, rack piping, and associated equipment are susceptible to ethanol SCC.
All grades of carbon steel are susceptible<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracking has also been reported in a pipeline used to transport FGE to and from a terminal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Ethanol SCC has not been reported in FGE manufacturers’ equipment and tankage, or in
transportation equipment (barges, trucks, railcars).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_245>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-221
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Cracking has not been reported in equipment handling FGE after it has been blended with gasoline
at end-use concentrations in unleaded gasoline (10 vol%).  There has been one reported failure of
an end-user E-85 tank.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.7.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Ethanol SCC is often found in the vicinity of welds and can appear as cracks that are parallel to the
weld or transverse to the weld ( Figures 4-162  to  4-169 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracks are typically tight and may be filled with corrosion product.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Ethanol SCC cracks are typically branched and intergranular, but transgranular or mixed-mode
cracking has also been reported.  Field failures tend to be intergranular, while laboratory testing has
produced all crack morphologies.  The cracking mode appears to depend on the chloride level, with
an increased chloride content tending to shift the cracking from intergranular to transgranular or
mixed mode.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Microrostructure of materials subjected to ethanol SCC are typically ferrite, or ferrite and pearlite.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.7.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The likelihood of ethanol SCC can be reduced though PWHT (when possible) or by applying
coatings.  Given the high threshold stress intensities required to initiate ethanol SCC, standard
carbon steel PWHT is expected to be effective.  Research to confirm this is currently under way.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Avoid designs with highly localized tensile stresses.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Avoid the usage of lap seam welds that may concentrate strain in components.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Minimize cold working during fabrication.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.7.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
It is difficult to visually detect ethanol SCC because the cracks are typically tight and filled with
corrosion product.  Some small leaks may occur before an ethanol crack can be visually detected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
WFMT is the preferred method for detecting ethanol cracking.  Methods for ethanol SCC inspection
are similar to those used for detecting other types of SCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Shear wave UT may be used in instances where WFMT is not feasible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
ACFM can be used with less surface preparation than WFMT in areas such as weld HAZ’s.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
EC is unproven as a method for detection of ethanol SCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.7.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Ethanol SCC is assumed to be similar to other reported in methanol and various alkaline aqueous
solutions..<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4.5.7.9
References
1. API Technical Report 939-D, Stress Corrosion Cracking of Carbon Steel in Fuel-Grade Ethanol:
Review, Experience Survey, Field Monitoring, and Laboratory Testing, Second Edition, May 2007,
American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.
2. API Bulletin 939E, Identification, Repair, and Mitigation of Cracking of Steel Equipment in Fuel
Ethanol Service, First Edition, November 2008, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.
3. ASTM D 4806, Standard Specification for Denatured Fuel Ethanol for Blending with Gasolines for
Use as Automotive Spark-Ignition Engine Fuel, ASTM International, West Conshohocken, PA.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_251>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
4-227
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.8
Sulfate Stress Corrosion Cracking<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.8.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Surface initiated cracks caused by environmental cracking of copper alloys in sulfate solutions over many
years.  Most commonly found in heat exchanger tubes, primarily in cooling water services.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.8.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Some copper alloys are highly susceptible, especially admiralty brass.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The 90/10 and 70/30 copper nickel alloys are more resistant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.8.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Susceptible alloys may suffer cracking under the combination of stress and the presence of sulfate
chemical compounds.  Residual stresses are sufficient to promote cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The process environment must contain sulfates as part of the process or where sulfates can form
due to reactions with other chemical species.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Ammonia is usually present, often at very low concentrations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Cracking usually occurs over a period of many years, sometimes taking as long as 10 to 15 years to
cause tube leaks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.8.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Sulfate SCC is most often associated with tubes in heat exchanger bundles in overhead distillation
systems where sulfates can form or are present in low concentrations.  Crude tower overhead
exchangers are one example where this form of damage has been observed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.8.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Exchanger tubes show single or highly branched cracks on the surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Upon metallurgical examination, the cracks will have a branched, transgranular appearance which
may be visually difficult to differentiate form ammonia stress corrosion cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Tube failures usually result in slow leaks as opposed to tube rupture.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.8.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
It has been suggested that the life of susceptible copper alloy exchanger tubes may be lengthened
by periodic cleaning once every five years but limited published information is available to support
this claim.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Alloys that are highly resistant to ammonia stress corrosion cracking such as the 90-10CuNi and 70-
30CuNi alloys are also highly resistant to sulfate SCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Non-copper based alloys are immune from this form of damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.8.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Inspect heat exchanger tubes for cracking using EC or visual inspection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Physical bending of sample tubes can also be performed to detect shallow cracks indicative of
sulfate SCC in the beginning stages.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>4.5.8.7.1
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Not applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_255>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-3
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1
General<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage mechanisms found in the refining environment are discussed in the following sections. Section
5.2 includes process unit PFD’s. These PFD’s show the location in the unit where particular damage
mechanisms are most likely to be found.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1
Uniform or Localized Loss in Thickness Phenomena<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.1
Amine Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.1.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Amine corrosion refers to the general and/or localized corrosion that occurs principally on carbon
steel in amine treating processes. Corrosion is not caused by the amine itself, but results from
dissolved acid gases (CO 2  and H 2 S), amine degradation products, Heat Stable Amine Salts (HSAS)
and other contaminants.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Stress corrosion cracking of carbon steel in amine services is discussed in  5.1.2.2 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.1.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Primarily carbon steel. 300 Series SS are highly resistant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.1.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion depends on design and operating practices, the type of amine, amine concentration,
contaminants, temperature and velocity.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Amine corrosion is very closely tied to the operation of the unit.  With a few exceptions, carbon steel
is suitable for most components in a properly designed and operated unit.  Most problems can be
traced to faulty design, poor operating practices or solution contamination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion is also dependent on the type of amine used.  In general, alkanolamine systems can be
rated in order of aggressiveness from most to least as follows: monoethanolamine (MEA),
diglycolamine (DGA), diisopropylamine (DIPA), diethanolamine (DEA), and methyldiamine (MDEA).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Lean amine solutions are generally not corrosive because they have either low conductivity and or
high pH. However, an excessive accumulation of heat stable amine salts (HSAS) above about 2%,
depending on the amine, can significantly increase corrosion rates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Lean amine solutions contain a small amount of H 2 S which helps to maintains a stable iron sulfide
film. Overstripped lean solutions can be corrosive if there is inadequate H 2 S present to maintain the
protective iron sulfide film.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Ammonia, H 2 S and HCN accelerate corrosion in the regenerator overhead condenser and outlet
piping as well as reflux piping, valves and pumps.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Corrosion rates increase with increasing temperature, particularly in rich amine service.
Temperatures above about 220°F (104°C) can result in acid gas flashing and severe localized
corrosion due to 2-phase flow, if the pressure drop is high enough.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Process stream velocity will influence the amine corrosion rate and nature of attack. Corrosion is
generally uniform however high velocities and turbulence will cause localized thickness losses. For
carbon steel, common velocity limits are generally limited to 3 to 6 fps for rich amine and about 20
fps for lean amine.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.1.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Amine units are used in refineries to remove H 2 S, CO 2  and mercaptans from process streams
originating in many units including the crude, coker, FCC, hydrogen reforming, hydroprocessing, and
tail gas units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_256>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-4
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The regenerator reboiler and the regenerator are areas where the temperature and turbulence of the
amine stream are the highest and can cause significant corrosion problems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The rich amine side of the lean/rich exchangers, hot lean amine piping, hot rich amine piping, the
amine solution pumps, and the reclaimers are also areas where corrosion problems occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.1.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbon steel and low alloy steels suffer general uniform thinning, localized corrosion or localized
underdeposit attack ( Figure 5-1  to  5-6 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Thinning will be uniform in nature when the process stream velocity is low while it will be localized for
high velocities associated with turbulence.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.1.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Proper operation of the amine system is the most effective way to control corrosion, with particular
attention to acid gas loading levels.  In addition, to avoid corrosive amine degradation products, the
process temperature should not exceed recommended limits.  Proper control of the reboiler rate and
temperature is necessary in order to maintain a regenerator top temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Proper attention should be given to avoid the buildup of HSAS to unacceptable levels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The system design should incorporate measures to control local pressure drop to minimize flashing.
In areas where it is unavoidable, upgrading to 300 Series SS or other corrosion resistant alloys may
be required.  SS410 trays and internals are also used in absorber and stripping towers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Oxygen inleakage causes high corrosion rates and contributes to heat stable salt formation.  Storage
tanks and surge vessels should be blanketed with inert gas.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Solids and hydrocarbons should be removed from the amine solution by filtration and through
process control.  Filtration of rich amine solutions has the potential to be more effective than lean
amine filtration for solids removal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Corrosion inhibitors may be required to control amine corrosion within acceptable levels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.1.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Visual examination and UT thickness measurement are the methods used for internal equipment
inspection. UT scans or profile radiography are used for external inspection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion monitoring can also be achieved with corrosion coupons and/or corrosion probes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Monitoring should target the hot areas of the unit such as the reboiler feed and return line, the hot
lean/rich amine piping, and the stripper overhead condenser piping.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Fouling of exchangers and filters can be a sign of corrosion problems on the unit.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.1.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Amine stress corrosion cracking may also be found in  5.1.2.2 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.1.1.9
References
1. J. Gutzeit “Refinery Corrosion Overview,” Process Industries Corrosion - The Theory and Practice,
NACE International, Houston, TX, 1986, pp. 171-189.
2. L.R. White and D.E. Street, “Corrosion Control in Amine Treating Units,” Proceedings of the Special
Symposium on Corrosion in the Oil Refining Industry, NACE International, Houston,  TX, 1996.
3. R.B. Nielsen et al, “Corrosion in Refinery Amine Systems,”CORROSION/95, Paper No. 571, NACE
International, Houston, TX, 1995.
4. API Recommended Practice 945, Avoiding Environmental Cracking in Amine Units, American
Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.
5. M. A. Saleem and A.A. Hulaibi, , “Corrosion Challenges in Gas Treating Units”, Paper # 08416, NACE
International, Houston, TX, 2008.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
