<<PAGE_261>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-9
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.2
Ammonium Bisulfide Corrosion  (Alkaline Sour Water)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.2.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Aggressive corrosion occurring in hydroprocessing reactor effluent streams and in units handling
alkaline sour water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Several major failures have occurred in hydroprocessing reactor effluent systems due to localized
corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.2.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbon steel is less resistant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
300 Series SS, duplex SS, aluminum alloys and nickel base alloys are more resistant, depending on
ammonium bisulfide (NH 4 HS) concentration and velocity.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.2.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
NH 4 HS concentration, H2S partial pressure, velocity and/or localized turbulence, pH, temperature,
alloy composition and flow distribution are all critical factors to consider.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion increases with increasing NH 4 HS concentration and increasing velocity. Below 2 wt %,
solutions are not generally corrosive.  Above 2 wt % NH 4 HS, solutions are increasingly corrosive.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In hydroprocessing reactors, FCC reactors and coker furnaces, nitrogen in the feed is converted to
ammonia and reacts with H 2 S to form NH 4 HS.  NH 4 HS precipitates out of the gas phase in the
reactor effluent stream at temperatures below about 150°F (66°C), depending on the concentration
of NH 3  and H 2 S, and may cause fouling and plugging unless flushed away with wash water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
NH 4 HS salt deposits lead to underdeposit corrosion and fouling.  The salts are not corrosive unless
they become hydrated at which point they are very corrosive.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Oxygen and iron in the wash water injected into hydroprocessing reactor effluent can lead to
increased corrosion and fouling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Presence of cyanides increases severity of corrosion in FCC gas plants, coker gas plants and sour
water stripper overheads by destroying the normally protective sulfide film.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.2.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Hydroprocessing Units<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
NH 4 HS salts precipitate in the reactor effluent streams when temperatures drop to within the
range of 120°F to 150°F (49°C to 66°C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Fouling and/or velocity accelerated corrosion may be found at:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Air cooler header boxes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Inlet and outlet piping of air coolers, as well as exchanger tubes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Effluent separators, and piping into and out of the reactor effluent separators.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>•
Sour water draw piping from reactor effluent separators; flashing may cause severe
erosion-corrosion downstream of control valves ( Figure 5-7 ).<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Vapor line from the high pressure separators.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Hydrocarbon lines from reactor effluent separators due to entrained sour water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Stripper Column overhead sour water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
FCC Units<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>NH 4 HS concentrations are usually less than 2 wt % but high velocities and/or the presence of
cyanides can remove protective iron sulfide scales.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_262>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-10
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Sour Water Strippers (SWS)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>High concentrations of NH 4 HS in stripper overhead piping, condensers, accumulator and reflux
piping, and possible presence of cyanides.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Amine Units<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>High concentrations of NH 4 HS may be found in regenerator overheads and reflux piping
depending on unit operation.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Delayed Coker<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>High concentrations of NH 4 HS may be found in the gas concentration plant downstream of the
fractionator tower.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.2.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
General loss in thickness of carbon steel, with the potential for extremely high localized rates of wall
loss can occur at changes in direction or turbulent flow areas above 2 wt % concentration.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Low velocities may result in extremely localized under-deposit corrosion if insufficient water is
available to dissolve the NH 4 HS salts that precipitated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Heat exchangers may show plugging and loss of duty due to fouling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
NH 4 HS rapidly corrodes admiralty brass tubes and other copper alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.2.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Good design practice should consist of symmetrical and hydraulically balanced flow in and out of air
cooled exchangers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Carefully review design and localized velocities as process conditions change, particularly as NH 4 HS
concentrations exceed 2 wt % and begin to approach 8 wt % or higher.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Maintain velocities within industry guidelines of 10 to 20 fps for carbon steel.  Carbon steel may be
susceptible to high corrosion rates above about 8 wt % NH 4 HS concentration<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Use resistant materials of construction (e.g. Alloy 825, duplex SS) at velocities above 20 fps,
depending on NH 4 HS concentration.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Properly design and maintain water wash injection with low oxygen content; provide sufficient excess
water to ensure that an adequate amount of water remains as liquid to dilute the NH 4 HS salts. Use
proper injection spray nozzles and metallurgy.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Titanium and Alloy C276 have been used in overhead condensers in SWS units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Aluminum exchanger tubes are extremely susceptible to erosion-corrosion damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.2.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
A carefully designed plan should include input from process engineers and materials/corrosion
engineers to determine specific areas of vulnerability. Determine ammonium bisulfide content
through sampling and calculation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Frequent UT scanning and/or RT profile thickness of high and low velocity areas.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
UT downstream of control valves at high NH 4 HS concentrations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
IRIS, RFEC and flux leakage inspection of steel air cooler tubes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
EC inspect non-magnetic air cooler tubes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Monitor water injection facilities and flow meters to ensure proper operation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.2.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Erosion/erosion corrosion (see  4.2.14 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

References

Protection, NACE International, Houston, TX, 1975.

95.

October 1999, pp. 59-72.

Overhead Systems,” Paper #392,CORROSION/99, April 1999, NACE International, Houston,TX,

International, Houston,TX, 2001.

<<PAGE_265>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-13
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.3
Ammonium Chloride Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.3.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>General or localized corrosion, often pitting, normally occurring under ammonium chloride or amine salt
deposits, often in the absence of a free water phase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.3.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All commonly used materials are susceptible, in order of increasing resistance: carbon steel, low alloy
steels, 300 Series SS, Alloys 400, duplex SS, 800, and 825, Alloys 625 and C276 and titanium.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.3.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Concentration (NH 3 , HCl, H 2 0 or amine salts), temperature and water availability are the critical
factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Ammonium chloride salts may precipitate from high temperature streams as they are cooled,
depending upon the concentration of NH 3  and HCl, and may corrode piping and equipment at
temperatures well above the water dewpoint [> 300°F (149°C)]<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Ammonium chloride salts are hygroscopic, and readily absorb water.  A small amount of water can
lead to very aggressive corrosion [>100 mpy (>2.5 mm/y] .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Ammonium chloride and amine hydrochloride salts are highly water soluble, highly corrosive and
form an acidic solution when mixed with water.  Some neutralizing amines react with chlorides to
form amine hydrochlorides that can act in a similar fashion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Corrosion rates increase with increasing temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
When they deposit above the water dewpoint, a water wash injection may be required to dissolve the
salts.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.3.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Crude Tower Overheads<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Tower top, top trays, overhead piping and exchangers may be subject to fouling and corrosion.
Deposits may occur in low flow zones due to ammonia and/or amine chloride salts condensing
from the vapor phase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Top pumparound streams may be affected if ammonia or amine chloride salts are present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Hydroprocessing<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Reactor effluent streams are subject to ammonium chloride salt fouling and corrosion.  Water
washing may be required if exchanger fouling or loss in duty occurs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Catalytic Reforming<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Reactor effluent streams and the H 2  recycle system are subject to ammonium chloride salting and
corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
FCCU and coker fractionator overheads and top pumparounds are subject to ammonium chloride
corrosion and salting.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.3.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The salts have a whitish, greenish or brownish appearance.  Water washing and/or steamout will
remove deposits so that evidence of fouling may not be evident during an internal visual inspection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion underneath the salts is typically very localized and results in pitting.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion rates can be extremely high.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_266>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-14
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.3.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Alloys that are more pitting resistant will have improved resistance to ammonium chloride salts but even
the most corrosion resistant nickel base alloys and titanium alloys may suffer pitting corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Crude Unit<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Limit salts by limiting chlorides in the tower feed through desalting and/or the addition of caustic
to the desalted crude.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
A water wash may be required in the crude tower overhead line to flush the salt deposits.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Filming amine inhibitors are often added to control corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Hydroprocessing<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Limit chlorides in the hydrocarbon feed to the reactor.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Limit chlorides in the make-up hydrogen supply.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
A continuous or intermittent water wash may be required in the reactor effluent to flush out the
salt deposits.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Catalytic Reforming<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Reactor effluent can be treated to remove the chlorides.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Water washing has been used in some cases but the system must be carefully designed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Some tower overheads may require neutralizing or filming amines.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.3.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Accumulation of ammonium chloride salts can be very localized and the resulting corrosion may be
difficult to detect.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
RT or UT thickness monitoring can be used to determine remaining wall thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Monitoring of the feed streams and effluent waters will give an indication of the amount of ammonia
and chlorides present, however process simulation may be required to determine the concentration
and dewpoint temperatures.  If the ammonium chloride salt deposition temperature has been
calculated, temperature monitoring and control may be effective for maintaining metal temperatures
above the salt deposition temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The presence of deposits is often detected when the pressure drop increases or the thermal
performance of exchangers has deteriorated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Corrosion probes or coupons can be useful, but the salt must deposit on the corrosion probe element
to detect the corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.3.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>HCl corrosion (see  5.1.1.4 ), chloride SCC ( 4.5.1 ) and organic acid corrosion of distillation tower overhead
systems ( 5.1.1.12 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-15
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.1.3.9
References
1. C. Shargay et al, “Design Considerations to Minimize Ammonium Chloride Corrosion in Hydrotreater
REACs,” CORROSION/2001, Paper No. 1543, NACE International, Houston, TX, 2001.
2. C. Shargay et al, "Ammonium Salt Corrosion in Hydrotreating Unit Stripper Column Overhead
Systems," NACE Corrosion/99 Conference, Paper No. 392, NACE International, Houston, TX, 1999.
3. “Refinery Injection and Process Mixing Points,” NACE International Publication 34101, NACE

Fouling”, NACE International, Houston, TX.

<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_268>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-16
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.4
Hydrochloric Acid (HCl) Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.4.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Hydrochloric acid (aqueous HCl) causes both general and localized corrosion and is very aggressive
to most common materials of construction across a wide range of concentrations.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Damage in refineries is most often associated with dew point corrosion in which vapors containing
water and hydrogen chloride condense from the overhead stream of a distillation, fractionation or
stripping tower. The first water droplets that condense can be highly acidic (low pH) and promote
high corrosion rates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.4.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All common materials of construction used in refineries.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.4.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
HCl acid concentration, temperature and alloy composition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The severity of corrosion increases with increasing HCl concentration and increasing temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Aqueous HCl can form beneath deposits of ammonium chloride or amine hydrochloride salts in
exchangers and piping. The deposits readily absorb water from the process stream or from injected
wash water.  Hydrogen chloride is normally not corrosive in dry process streams, but becomes very
corrosive where water is available to form hydrochloric acid.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Carbon steel and low alloy steels are subject to excessive corrosion when exposed to any
concentration of HCl acid that produces at pH below about 4.5<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
300 series SS and 400 series SS are not usefully resistant to HCl at any concentration or
temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Alloy 400, titanium and some other nickel base alloys have good resistance to dilute HCl acid in
many refinery applications.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
The presence of oxidizing agents (oxygen, ferric and cupric ions) will increase the corrosion rate,
particularly for alloy 400 and Alloy B-2.  Titanium performs well in oxidizing conditions but fails rapidly
in dry HCl service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.4.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>HCl corrosion is found in several units, especially crude and vacuum units, hydroprocessing units and
catalytic reformer units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Crude Unit<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
In the atmospheric tower overhead system, corrosion from HCl acid occurs as the first droplets
of water condense from the vapor stream off the top of the tower.  This water can have a very
low pH and can result in high rates of corrosion in piping, as well as exchanger shells, tubes
and header boxes, and cold dead legs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
HCl corrosion can also be a problem in the vacuum ejector and condensing equipment off the
top of the vacuum tower.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Hydroprocessing Units<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Chlorides may enter the unit as organic chloride in the hydrocarbon feed or with the recycle
hydrogen and react to form HCl.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Ammonium chloride salts can form in various parts of the unit including the effluent side of the
hot feed/effluent exchangers because both NH 3  and HCl are present or they may condense with
water in the effluent train.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,`<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute --`                           |
|:---------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API ,,,`                          |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS `,` |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_269>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-17
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
HCl containing streams can migrate through the fractionation section resulting in severe acid
dewpoint corrosion at the mixing point where it contacts water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Catalytic Reforming Units<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Chlorides may be stripped from the catalyst and react to form HCl that carries through the
effluent train, regeneration system, stabilizer tower, debutanizer tower and feed/preheat
exchangers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
HCl containing vapors can migrate through the gas plant fractionation section resulting in mix
point or acid dew point corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.4.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbon steel and low alloy steels suffer general uniform thinning, localized corrosion or underdeposit
attack.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
300 Series SS and 400 Series SS will often suffer pitting attack and 300 Series SS may experience
chloride stress corrosion cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.4.6
Prevention/Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Crude Units<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Optimize the crude oil tank water separation and withdrawal and crude desalting operation to
reduce chloride in the feed to the crude tower.  A common target is 20 ppm or fewer chlorides in
the overhead accumulator water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Upgrading carbon steel to nickel base alloys or titanium can reduce HCl acid corrosion
problems. Titanium tubes will solve most overhead condenser tube corrosion problems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Water washing can be added to quench the overhead stream and to help dilute the condensing
hydrochloric acid concentration.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Caustic injection downstream of the desalter is another common method used to reduce the
amount of HCl going overhead.  Proper design and operating guidelines must be used to avoid
caustic SCC and fouling in the feed preheat train.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Various combinations of ammonia, neutralizing amines and filming amines can be injected in
the atmospheric tower overhead line before the water dewpoint.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Hydrodroprocessing<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Minimize carryover of water and chloride salts from upstream units including neutralizing amine
hydrochloride salts.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Minimize HCl in H 2  streams (e.g., install scrubbers or guard beds to remove Cl- ions from
hydrogen produced in catalytic reforming units).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Selective use of corrosion resistant nickel base alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Catalytic Reforming<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Same as hydroprocessing, but in addition, water washing the hydrocarbon stream has also
been used to remove the highly water soluble chlorides. Special care in the design and
operation of this equipment is recommended.  Minimizing water and/or oxygenates in the feed
will reduce stripping of chlorides from the catalyst.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Special adsorbents in chloride beds and chloride treaters can be used to remove chlorides from
the recycle hydrogen streams and from liquid hydrocarbon streams.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.4.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For carbon steel, damage is usually in the form of general thinning but may be highly localized where
a water phase is condensing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_270>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-18
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Serious corrosion can also be found at mix points where dry chloride containing streams mix with
streams containing free water or where water saturated streams are cooled below the dewpoint.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Evidence of locally thinned areas can be found using automatic ultrasonic scanning methods or
profile radiography.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Process and corrosion monitoring are important aspects of a well-developed program to minimize
the effects of HCl corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The pH of the water in the boot of the atmospheric tower overhead accumulator is normally checked
every shift. Other variables including chloride and iron content are checked on a less frequent basis
but do need to be monitored regularly.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Water phases in other units are also monitored by periodic sampling of water draws from the
overhead drums of fractionating or stripping towers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Strategically placed corrosion probes and/or corrosion coupons can provide additional information on
the rate and extent of damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.4.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Ammonium chloride corrosion (see  5.1.1.3 ), chloride SCC ( 4.5.1 ) and organic acid corrosion of distillation
tower overhead systems ( 5.1.1.12 ).<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.1.4.9
References
1. Metals Handbook, “Corrosion,” Volume 13, ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
2. A. Bagdasarian et al, “Crude Unit Corrosion and Corrosion Control,” CORROSION/96, Paper No.615,
NACE International, Houston, TX, 1996.
3. NACE International Publication 34105, “Effect of Nonextractable Chlorides on Refinery Corrosion and
Fouling”, NACE International, Houston, TX.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_271>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-19
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.5
High Temp H 2 /H 2 S Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.5.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>The presence of hydrogen in H 2 S-containing hydrocarbon streams increases the severity of high
temperature sulfide corrosion at temperatures above about 500°F (260°C).  This form of sulfidation
usually results in a uniform loss in thickness associated with hot circuits in hydroprocessing units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.5.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In order of increasing resistance: carbon steel, low alloy steels, 400 Series SS, and 300 Series SS.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.5.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The major factors affecting high temperature sulfidation are the temperature, the presence of
hydrogen, the concentration of H 2 S and the alloy composition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Depending on the quantity of hydrogen that is present, corrosion rates may be significantly different
than those associated with high temperature sulfidation in the absence of hydrogen (see  4.4.2 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Sulfidation rates increase with increasing H 2 S content and especially increasing temperature as
illustrated in  Figure 5-8 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Higher corrosion rates are found more in gas oil desulfurizers and hydrocrackers than naphtha
desulfurizers by a factor of almost ‘2’.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Susceptibility to sulfidation is determined by the chemical composition of the alloy.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Increasing chromium content of the alloy improves resistance ( Figure 5-9 ). However, there is little
improvement with increasing chromium content until about 7-9Cr as shown by the relative rate
reduction factors in  Table 5-1 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Chromium-containing nickel base alloys are similar to stainless steel. Similar levels of chromium
provide similar corrosion resistance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.5.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
This form of corrosion occurs in piping and equipment in units where high temperature H 2 /H 2 S
streams are found including all hydroprocessing units such desulfurizers, hydrotreaters and
hydrocracking units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Noticeable increases in corrosion may be found downstream of hydrogen injection points.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.5.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion will appear as a uniform loss in thickness from the process side and is accompanied by
the formation of an iron sulfide scale.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Scale is about 5 times the volume of lost metal and may be in multiple layers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The tightly adherent shiny gray scale attached to the surface may be mistaken for unaffected metal.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.5.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The corrosion damage is minimized by using alloys with high chromium content.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The 300 Series SS such as Types 304L, 316L, 321 and 347 are highly resistant at service
temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.5.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
UT, VT and RT thickness readings are used to monitor loss in thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Actual operating temperatures should be verified in the field to compare against design.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |

| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>

| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_272>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-20
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Process simulations should be checked periodically to confirm that H 2 S levels have not significantly
increased.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.5.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>High temperature sulfidation in the absence of hydrogen is discussed in  4.4.2<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.1.5.9
References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion in Petroleum Refining and Petrochemical Operations,” Volume 13,
ASM International, Materials Park,OH.
2. NACE Course Book, “Corrosion Control in the Refining Industry,” NACE International,  Houston, TX,
1999.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-23
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.6
Hydrofluoric (HF) Acid Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.6.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Corrosion by HF acid can result in high rates of general or localized corrosion and may be accompanied
by hydrogen cracking, blistering and/or HIC/SOHIC (see  5.1.2.3  and  5.1.2.4 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.6.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbon steel, copper-nickel alloys, Alloy 400.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Other nickel base alloys such as Alloy C276 have also been used in some applications.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Low alloy steels, 300 Series SS and the 400 Series SS are susceptible to corrosion and/or cracking
and are generally not suitable for HF service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.6.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
HF acid concentration (water content), temperature, alloy composition and the presence of
contaminants including oxygen and sulfur compounds are the controlling factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Carbon steel forms a protective fluoride scale in dry concentrated acid.  Loss of the protective scale
through high velocities or turbulence, will result in greatly accelerated corrosion rates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The presence of water can destabilize the fluoride scale and convert it into a voluminous
nonprotective scale.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The primary concern is the “HF-in-water” concentration of the acid phase.  Although the process
stream may be comprised primarily of hydrocarbon, the acid is considered as a separate phase.
Concentration is determined by the amount of water present in the acid phase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Typical HF alkylation units operate with 1% to 3% water in the acid, equivalent to an HF-in-water
concentration of 97% to 99% and the temperatures are generally below 150 o F (66 o C).  Under these
conditions carbon steel is widely used for all equipment except where close tolerances are required
for operation (i.e., pumps, valves, instruments).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Corrosion rates increase with increasing temperature and decreasing HF concentration (increasing
water content) as shown in  Figures 5-10  to  5-11 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
In carbon steel, the “Residual Element” (RE) content of base metal and weld metal may have an
affect on corrosion rates in certain parts of the unit.  This  RE content refers  to  the  effect  of  trace
elements, primarily %C, %Cu, %Ni, %Cr that are present in carbon steel during the steel
manufacturing process (References 1- 4).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Industry guidelines regarding RE content have been developed and implemented into some industry
consensus standards as indicated below.  A more detailed discussion of these guidelines is outlined
in References 1 and 2.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
•    For Base Metal:          %C > 0.18 wt.% and %Cu + %Ni < 0.15 wt.%<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
•    For Weld Metal:          %Cu + %Ni + %Cr < 0.15 wt.%<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
Oxygen contamination increases the corrosion rate of carbon steel and promotes accelerated
corrosion and SCC of Alloy 400.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.6.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Piping and equipment in the HF alkylation unit, flare piping and downstream units exposed to acid
carryover are also affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Most equipment is made from carbon steel with the exception of the HF acid rerun/regenerator tower
and the acid relief neutralizer vessel which are usually made partially or completely from Alloy 400.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_276>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-24
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
High corrosion rates have been observed:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
In piping and equipment operating above 150°F (66°C);<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
In deadlegs including inlets to relief valves, as well as small bore vents and drains;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Condensing overhead vapors in piping and exchangers off top of  the Isostripper, Depropanizer
and HF Stripper/Propane Stripper;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
On flange faces;<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Heat exchanger bundles that heat acid-containing streams such as the acid vaporizer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Severe fouling due to iron fluoride corrosion product has been observed in the piping, heat
exchangers and in the tops of the Isostripper and Depropanizer towers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.6.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion is in the form of localized general or severe thinning of carbon steel.  Preferential corrosion
may not always conform to behavior predicted by the RE guidelines in API RP 751 ( Figure 5-12  to  5-
15 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion may be accompanied by cracking due to hydrogen stress cracking, blistering and/or
HIC/SOHIC damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Significant fouling due to iron fluoride scales may also accompany corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Alloy 400 shows uniform loss in thickness but is not accompanied by significant scaling.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Alloy 400 is susceptible to stress corrosion cracking when in contact with moist HF vapors in the
presence of oxygen.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.6.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbon steel operating above 150° o F (66°C) should be closely monitored for loss in thickness and
may need to be upgraded to Alloy 400.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion can be prevented by careful operation of the unit to minimize water, oxygen, sulfur and
other contaminants in the feed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Maintain strict controls on the water content of the circulating acid.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Alloy 400 (solid or clad) can be used to eliminate the problems associated with blistering and
HIC/SOHIC.  A stress relieving heat treatment is required to help minimize, but not eliminate, the
possibility of SCC ( Figure 5-16  to  5-18  ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Alloy C276 has been used where there have been cracking problems with Alloy 400.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.6.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
UT and RT are used to monitor for loss in thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Special emphasis programs to monitor small bore piping, flange face corrosion, blistering and
HIC/SOHIC are recommended as outlined in API RP 751.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Track and monitor RE content of carbon steel components in accordance with API 751 guidelines.
Inspect for the potential for localized corrosion of piping components and or welds in accordance
with API 751 and industry best practices.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.6.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Environmental cracking of carbon steel and Alloy 400 can occur in HF.  Refer to  5.1.2.4  hydrogen stress
cracking in HF and to  5.1.2.3  for a discussion of blistering and HIC/SOHIC damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST

International, Houston, TX.

CORROSION/2003, Paper #. 03651 NACE International, Houston, TX, 2003.

Units,” Oil and Gas Journal, March 6, 1995, Vol. 93, No.10, pp. 63-68.

Paper No.01345, NACE International, Houston, TX, 2001.

International, Houston, TX, 2006.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-31
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.7
Naphthenic Acid Corrosion (NAC)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.7.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A form of high temperature corrosion that occurs primarily in crude and vacuum units, and downstream
units that process certain fractions or cuts that contain naphthenic acids.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.7.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel, low alloy steels, 300 Series SS, 400 Series SS and nickel base alloys.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.7.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
NAC is a function of the naphthenic acid content (neutralization number), temperature, sulfur
content, velocity and alloy composition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Severity of corrosion increases with increasing acidity of the hydrocarbon phase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Neutralization number or Total Acid Number (TAN) is a measure of the acidity (organic acid content)
as determined by various test methods such as ASTM D-664.  However, NAC corrosion is
associated with hot dry hydrocarbon streams that do not contain a free water phase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The Total Acid Number (TAN) of the crude may be misleading because this family of acids has a
range of boiling points and tends to concentrate in various cuts. Therefore, NAC is determined by the
acidity of the actual stream not the crude charge.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The various acids which comprise the naphthenic acid family can have distinctly different corrosivity.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
No widely accepted prediction methods have been developed to correlate corrosion rate with the
various factors influencing it.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Sulfur promotes iron sulfide formation and has an inhibiting effect on NAC, up to a point.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Naphthenic acids remove protective iron sulfide scales on the surface of metals.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
NAC can be a particular problem with very low sulfur crudes with TAN’s as low as 0.10.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>j)
NAC normally occurs in hot streams above 425 o F (218 o C) but has been reported as low as 350 o F
(177 o C).  Severity increases with temperature up to about 750 o F (400 o C), however, NAC has been
observed in hot coker gas oil streams up to 800 o F (427 o C)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>k)
Naphthenic acids are destroyed by catalytic reactions in downstream hydroprocessing and FCCU
units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>l)
Alloys containing increasing amounts of molybdenum show improved resistance. A minimum of 2%
to 2.5% is required depending on the TAN of the whole crude and its side cuts.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>m) Corrosion is most severe in two phase (liquid and vapor) flow, in areas of high velocity or turbulence,
and in distillation towers where hot vapors condense to form liquid phase droplets.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.7.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Crude and vacuum heater tubes; crude and vacuum transfer lines; vacuum bottoms piping, AGO
circuits; HVGO and sometimes LVGO circuits. NAC has also been reported in the LCGO and HCGO
streams on delayed coking units processing high TAN feed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Piping systems are particularly susceptible in areas of high velocity, turbulence or change of flow
direction, such as pump internals, valves, elbows, tees and reducers as well as areas of flow
disturbance such as weld beads and thermowells.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Crude and vacuum tower internals may also be corroded in the flash zones, packing and internals
where high acid streams condense or high velocity droplets impinge.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_284>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-32
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
NAC may be found in hot hydrocarbon streams downstream of the crude and vacuum units,
upstream of any hydrogen mix points.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.7.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
NAC is characterized by localized corrosion, pitting corrosion, or flow induced grooving in high
velocity areas ( Figure 5-19  and  Figure 5-20 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
In low velocity condensing conditions, many alloys including carbon steel, low alloy steels and 400
Series SS may show uniform loss in thickness and/or pitting.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.7.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For units and/or components of systems which have not been designed for resistance to NAC, the
options are to change or blend crudes, upgrade metallurgy, utilize chemical inhibitors or some
combination thereof.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
NAC can be reduced by blending crude to reduce the TAN and/or increase the sulfur content.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Use alloys with higher molybdenum content for improved resistance ( Table 5-2 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
High temperature NAC inhibitors have been used with moderate success, however potential
detrimental effects on downstream catalyst activity must be considered.  Inhibitors effectiveness
needs to be monitored carefully.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
For severe conditions, Type 317L stainless steel or other alloys with higher molybdenum content
may be required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.7.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
UT and RT are used for thickness monitoring but localized erosion may be difficult to locate so RT
should be the primary detection method followed by UT thickness measurement.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Monitor TAN and sulfur content of the crude charge and side streams to determine the distribution of
acids in the various cuts.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Electrical resistance corrosion probes and corrosion coupon racks can be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Streams can be monitored for Fe and Ni content to assess corrosion in the system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Hydrogen probes have also been reported to detect NAC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.7.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Sulfidation is a competing and complimentary mechanism which must be considered in most situations
with NAC.  In cases where thinning is occurring, it is difficult to distinguish between NAC and sulfidation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.1.7.9
References
1. Derungs, “Naphthenic Acid Corrosion - An Old Enemy of the Petroleum Industry,” CORROSION, Vol.
12 No. 12, NACE International, Houston, TX, pp. 41.
2. J. Gutzeit, “Naphthenic Acid Corrosion,” NACE Paper No. 156, CORROSION/76, NACE International,
Houston, TX, 1976.
3. R. Piehl, “Naphthenic Acid Corrosion in Crude Distillation Units,” Materials Performance, January,
1988.
4. B.E. Hopkinson and L. E. Penuela, “Naphthenic Acid Corrosion by Venezuelan Crudes,” Paper No.
502, CORROSION/97,NACE International, Houston, TX, 1997.
5. M.J. Nugent and J.D. Dobis, “Experience with Naphthenic Acid Corrosion in Low TAN Crudes,” Paper
No. 577, CORROSION/98, NACE International, Houston, TX, 1998.
6. API RP 581, Risk-Based Inspection Technology, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.,
2008.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-35
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.8
Phenol (Carbolic Acid) Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.8.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Corrosion of carbon steel can occur in plants using phenol as a solvent to remove aromatic compounds
from lubricating oil feedstocks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.8.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In order of increasing resistance: carbon steel, 304L, 316L and Alloy C276.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.8.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Temperature, water content, alloy chemistry and velocity are the critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion is usually minimal in the treating section when the temperature is below 250°F (121 o C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion can occur in the recovery section where spent phenol is separated by vaporization.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Sulfur and organic acids may lead to naphthenic acid attack and sulfidation in the hot extract circuit.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Carbon steel and 304/304L stainless steel corrode rapidly in phenol service above 450°F (232 o C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Dilute aqueous solutions (5-15% phenol) are very corrosive to the extract dryer condensers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
High velocities may promote localized corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.8.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Phenol extraction facilities in lubes plant.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.8.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion will be in the form of general or localized corrosion of carbon steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Localized loss in thickness due to erosion-corrosion may occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Erosion-corrosion and/or condensation corrosion may be observed in tower overhead circuits.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.8.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion is best prevented through proper materials selection and control of phenol solvent
chemistry.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Overhead piping circuits should be designed for a maximum velocity of 30 fps in the recovery
section.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Recovery tower overhead temperatures should be maintained to at least 30°F (17°C) above the dew
point.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Type 316L stainless steel may be used in the top of the dry tower, phenol flash tower and various
condenser shells and separator drums that handle phenol-containing water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Tubes and headers in extract furnaces should be 316L.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Alloy C276 has been used in areas of high velocity or other locations where 316L is inadequate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.8.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
UT and RT to monitor for loss in thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
ER corrosion probes and corrosion coupons have been used for corrosion monitoring.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.8.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Not applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

References
1. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion in Petroleum Refining and Petrochemical Operations,” Volume 13,
ASM International, Materials Park, OH.<<HEADING_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-37
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.9
Phosphoric Acid Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.9.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Phosphoric acid is most often used as a catalyst in polymerization units.  It can cause both pitting
corrosion and localized corrosion of carbon steels depending on water content.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.9.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In order of increasing resistance: carbon steel, 304L SS, 316L SS and Alloy 20.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.9.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Acid concentration, temperature and contaminants.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Solid phosphoric acid catalysts are not corrosive to carbon steel unless free water is present.  When
water is present, severe corrosion of carbon steel may occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion rates increase with increasing temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Corrosion can penetrate a 1/4-inch thick steel tube in eight hours.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Most corrosion probably occurs during water washing operations at shutdowns.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Contaminants, such as chlorides, can increase phosphoric acid corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.9.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Piping and equipment in the polymerization unit where water mixes with catalyst.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion is usually found in low velocity areas where there is little or no circulation such as piping
manifolds, the bottom of kettle-type reboilers, partial penetration welds, and exchangers where there
is sufficient residence time to permit the settling of acid droplets.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.9.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>General or localized thinning of carbon steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.9.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Selective upgrading to corrosion resistant materials is the only option where water cannot be
eliminated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Type 304L SS is satisfactory for phosphoric acid concentration of 100% up to about 120°F (49°C).
Type 316L SS is required from 120°F to 225°F (49°C to 107°C)).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Type 316L SS and Alloy 20 are effective at concentrations up to 85% at boiling temperatures.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.9.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
UT and RT for loss of thickness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Sample iron in water from first column overhead receiver.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Online corrosion monitoring using ER probes and/or corrosion coupons in the water draw from the
first column overhead condenser and the reboiler.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.9.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Not applicable.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>5-38
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.1.9.9
References
1. R.A. White and E.F. Ehmke, “Materials Selection for Refineries and Associated Facilities,” NACE
International, Houston, TX.
2. NACE Course Book, “Corrosion Control in the Refining Industry,”  NACE International, Houston, TX,
1999.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_291>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-39
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.10
Sour Water Corrosion (Acidic)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.10.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion of steel due to acidic sour water containing H 2 S at a pH between 4.5 and 7.0. Carbon
dioxide (CO 2 ) may also be present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Sour waters containing significant amounts of ammonia, chlorides or cyanides may significantly
affect pH but are outside the scope of this section.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.10.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Primarily affects carbon steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Stainless steels, copper alloys and nickel base alloys are usually resistant.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.10.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
H 2 S content, pH, temperature, velocity and oxygen concentration are all critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The H 2 S concentration in the sour water is dependent on the H 2 S partial pressure in the gas phase
as well as temperature and pH.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
At a given pressure, the H 2 S concentration in the sour water decreases as temperature increases.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Increasing concentrations of H 2 S tend to decrease solution pH down to about 4.5.  Streams with a
pH below 4.5 indicate the presence of a strong acid which would be the main corrosion concern (see
5.1.1).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Above a pH of about 4.5, a protective, thin iron sulfide layer limits the corrosion rate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
In some instances at a pH above 4.5, a thicker, porous sulfide film layer can form.  This can promote
pitting under sulfide deposits. Typically, this does not affect the general corrosion rate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Other contaminants have a significant affect on water pH.  For example, HCl and CO 2  lower pH
(more acidic).  Ammonia significantly increases pH and is more often associated with alkaline sour
water where the main concern is ammonia bisulfide corrosion (see  5.1.1.2 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
The presence of air or oxidants may increase the corrosion and usually produces pitting or
underdeposit attacks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.10.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Acid sour water corrosion is a concern in overhead systems of FCC and coker gas fractionation plants
with high H 2 S levels and low NH 3  levels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.10.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion damage from acidic sour water is typically general thinning. However, localized corrosion
or localized underdeposit attack can occur, especially if oxygen is present. Corrosion in CO 2
containing environments may be accompanied by carbonate stress corrosion cracking (see  5.1.2.5 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
300 Series SS are susceptible to pitting attack and may experience crevice corrosion and/or chloride
stress corrosion cracking (see  4.5.1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.10.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
300 Series SS can be used at temperatures below about 140 o F (60 o C) where Chloride Stress
Corrosion Cracking (CSCC) is not likely.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Copper alloys and nickel alloys are generally not susceptible to acid sour water corrosion. However,
copper alloys are vulnerable to corrosion in environments with ammonia.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_292>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-40
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.10.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Evidence of locally thinned areas can be found using scanning ultrasonic thickness methods or
profile radiography.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
For carbon steel, damage is usually in the form general thinning but may be highly localized to
specific areas of high velocity or turbulence, typically where a water phase is condensing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Process and corrosion monitoring are important aspects of a well-developed program to minimize
the effects of acidic sour water corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The water draws of overhead accumulators should be monitored periodically to measure pH.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Properly placed corrosion probes and corrosion coupons provide additional information on the rate
and extent of potential damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.10.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Other factors to consider in these environments include wet H 2 S damage (see  5.1.2.3 ) and carbonate
SCC. (see  5.1.2.5 ).<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.1.10.9
References
1. Joerg Gutzeit, ”Corrosion of Steel by Sulfides and Cyanides in Refinery Condensate Water,”
Materials Protection, December, 1968, p. 17-23.
2. R.H. Hausler and N.D. Coble, “Corrosion Control in Crude Unit Overhead Systems,” Paper 42-72 at
API 37th Midyear Meeting, May, 1972.
3. Bruce D. Craig, “The Nature of Sulfides Formed on Steel in an H 2 S-O 2  Environment,” CORROSION
Vol. 35, No. 3, March 1979, p. 136-138.
4. Dillon, C.P., “Corrosion Control in the Chemical Process Industries,” MTI Publication No. 45, Second
Edition, NACE International, Houston, TX, 1994.
5. Jones, Denny A., “Principles and Prevention of Corrosion,” Prentice-Hall, Inc., NY, 1996.
6. Bruce D. Craig, “Sour-Gas Design Considerations,” Society of Petroleum Engineers (SPE)
Monograph Series, Monograph Volume 15, TX, 1993.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_293>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-41
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.11
Sulfuric Acid Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.11.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Sulfuric acid promotes general and localized corrosion of carbon steel and other alloys. Carbon steel heat
affected zones may  experience severe corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.11.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In order of increasing resistance: carbon steel, 316L SS, Alloy 20, high silicon cast iron, high nickel cast
iron, Alloy B-2 and Alloy C276.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.11.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Acid concentration, temperature, alloy content, velocity, contamination and presence of oxidizers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Figure 5-21  shows a plot of carbon steel corrosion rates as a function of sulfuric acid concentration
and temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Carbon steel corrosion rates increase significantly if the flow velocity exceeds about 2 to 3 fps (0.6 to
0.9 m/s) or at acid concentrations below 65%.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Mix points with water cause heat to be released and high corrosion rates can occur where the acid
becomes diluted.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The presence of oxidizers can greatly increase the corrosion rate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.11.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Sulfuric acid alkylation units and waste water treatment plants are affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Areas of vulnerability in sulfuric acid alkylation units include reactor effluent lines, reboilers,
deisobutanizer overhead systems and the caustic treating section ( Figure 5-22  and  Figure 5-23 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Acid usually ends up in the bottom of fractionation towers and reboilers where it becomes
concentrated.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.11.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Mostly general in nature, but attacks carbon steel weld heat affected zones rapidly.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Hydrogen grooving may occur in low flow or stagnant areas such as in storage tanks or rail cars.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Sulfuric acid attacks slag left from welding.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
If the corrosion rate and velocity are high, there will be no scale.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Corrosion of steel by dilute acid is usually in the form of overall metal loss or pitting and becomes
more severe with increasing temperature and velocity.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.11.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion is minimized through materials selection and proper operation within design velocities.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Alloys such as Alloy 20, Alloy 904L and Alloy C-276 resist dilute acid corrosion and form a protective
iron sulfate film on the surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Acidified product streams can be washed with caustic to neutralize the acid.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.11.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
UT or RT inspection of turbulent zones and hottest areas.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion monitoring with coupons and ER probes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.11.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Not applicable.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.1.11.9
References
1. NACE Publication 5A151, Materials of Construction for Handling Sulfuric Acid, NACE International,
Houston, TX, 1985.
2. Sheldon W. Dean and George D. Grab, “Corrosion of Carbon Steel by Concentrated Sulfuric Acid,”
NACE Paper No.147, NACE International, TX, 1984.
3. S. K. Brubaker, “Materials of Construction for Sulfuric Acid,” Process Industries Corrosion—The
Theory and Practice, NACE International, Houston, TX, pp. 243-258.
4. API RP 581, Risk-Based Inspection Technology, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.,
2008.
5. NACE Course Book, “Corrosion Control in the Refining Industry,” NACE International, Houston, TX,
1999.
6. NACE Standard RP0294, Design, Fabrication, and Inspection of Tanks for the Storage of
Concentrated Sulfuric Acid and Oleum at Ambient Temperatures, NACE International, Houston, TX.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
