<<PAGE_297>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-45
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.12
Aqueous Organic Acid Corrosion<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.12.1
Description of Damage.<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Organic compounds present in some crude oils decompose in the crude furnace to form low molecular
weight organic acids which condense in distillation tower overhead systems.  They may also result from
additives used in upstream operations or desalting.  These naturally occurring acids may contribute
significantly to aqueous corrosion depending on the type and quantity of acids, and the presence of other
contaminants.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.12.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All grades of carbon steel are affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
b)  Most other corrosion resistant alloys used in crude tower overhead systems are generally not
affected.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.12.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion is a function of the type and quantity of organic acids, metal temperature, fluid velocity,
system pH, and presence of other acids.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The low molecular weight organic acids that are formed include formic acid, acetic acid, propionic
acid, and butyric acid.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The lower molecular weight acids such as formic acid and acetic acid are the most corrosive.  They
are soluble in naphtha and are extracted into the water phase, once the water condenses, and
contribute to a reduction of pH.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The presence of organic acids will contribute to the overall demand for neutralizing chemicals but
their affects may be completely masked by the presence of other acids such as HCl, H 2 S, carbonic
acid and others.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Corrosion is most likely to be a problem where relatively ‘non-corrosive’ conditions exist in an
overhead system and there is a sudden increase in low molecular weight organic acids that reduces
the pH of the water in the overhead system requiring a potentially unexpected increase in neutralizer
demand.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
The type and quantity of organic acids formed in the overhead system are crude specific.  One
source of acid is believed to be the result of thermal decomposition of naphthenic acids in the crude
may be precursors to light organic acid formation and that processing of higher TAN crudes may
increase organic acid in the overheads but very little published data is available on this subject.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Some of the higher molecular weight organic acids condense above the water dew point in overhead
systems but are generally not present in sufficient quantities to cause corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Light organic acids such as acetic acid are sometimes added to upstream dehydrators or desalters
to improve performance and inhibit calcium naphthenate salt deposition (Reference 2). Such acids
will vaporize in the crude preheat and furnace, and go up the column into the crude tower overhead
system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>i)
Other high molecular weight acids used as additives can thermally decompose at crude unit
temperatures forming volatile acidic species, such as acetic and formic acids.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>j)
In general, these light organic acids do not generate the severity of corrosion associated with
inorganic acids such as HCl.   Table 5-3  shows the HCl equivalent factor for corrosion in overhead
systems.  To calculate the HCl equivalent of an organic acid, multiply the content of the organic acid
(in ppm-weight) by the factor for that acid, and result will be the equivalent content of HCl (in ppm).
This number can then be used to estimate the neutralizer demand in the overhead system, and the
additional neutralizer needed to compensate for organic acids in overhead systems.  Excess
neutralizer can lead to amine hydrochloride salts in overhead systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_298>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-46
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.12.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All carbon steel piping and process equipment in crude tower, vacuum tower and coker fractionator
overhead systems including heat exchangers, towers and drums are susceptible to damage where
acidic conditions occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Corrosion tends to occur where water accumulates or where hydrocarbon flow directs water droplets
against metal surfaces.  For example, the bottoms of overhead exchangers, separator drums, boots
of separator drums, elbows, tees, pumps, and downstream of control valves.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion is also sensitive to flow rate and will tend to be more severe in turbulent areas in piping
systems including overhead transfer lines, overhead condensers, separator drums, control valves,
pipe elbows and tees, exchanger tubes, etc.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.12.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Light organic acid corrosion typically leaves the corroded surface smooth and damage may be
difficult to distinguish from corrosion by other acids in the overhead system.  It is sometimes
mistaken for HCl corrosion or carbonic acid corrosion.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
In pipe or other equipment where there is significant flow, the surfaces are sometimes smoothly
grooved.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.12.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Corrosion caused by light organic acids in crude unit overhead systems can be minimized through
the injection of a chemical neutralizing additive.  However, problems may arise when frequent
changes in crude blends lead to changes in neutralizer demand.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The TAN of the crudes being processed can be used as an initial guide to setting the neutralizer by
anticipating an increase in the acid concentration in the overhead system.  After a new crude is
processed, a review of analyses of water samples from the boot of the overhead separator drum can
be used to determine how much light organic acid reaches the overhead system optimize future
additions.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Filming amines can be used to prevent corrosion if the filming amine selected does not react with the
organic acid.  However, using filming amines is not as effective as neutralization.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Upgrading to corrosion-resistant alloys will prevent organic acid corrosion but the selection of
suitable materials should account for other potential damage mechanisms in the overhead system.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.12.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
UT and RT inspection for loss in thickness are the most common methods of inspection.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Long range UT techniques can also be used for long runs of pipe.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
For carbon steel, damage is usually in the form of general thinning but may be highly localized where
a water phase is condensing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Evidence of locally thinned areas can be found using automatic ultrasonic scanning methods or
profile radiography.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Process monitoring should include pH measurement and analysis of water in the crude tower
overhead drum to analyze for the presence of organic acids.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Strategically placed corrosion probes and/or corrosion coupons can provide additional information on
the rate and extent of damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.1.12.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This form of damage may be difficult to differentiate from HCl corrosion in crude tower overhead systems.
See also HCl corrosion (see  5.1.1.4 ). Ammonium chloride corrosion (see  5.1.1.3 ), and chloride SCC
( 4.5.1 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

5-47

<<PAGE_301>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-49
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2
Environment-Assisted Cracking<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.1
Polythionic Acid Stress Corrosion Cracking (PASCC)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.1.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
A form of stress corrosion cracking normally occurring during shutdowns, startups or during
operation when air and moisture are present.  Cracking is due to sulfur acids forming from sulfide
scale, air and moisture acting on sensitized austenitic stainless steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Usually adjacent to welds or high stress areas.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Cracking may propagate rapidly through the wall thickness of piping and components in a matter of
minutes or hours.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.1.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>300 Series SS, Alloy 600/600H and Alloy 800/800H.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.1.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
A combination of environment, material, and stress are required.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Environment - Metallic components form a surface sulfide scale when exposed to sulfur
compounds.  The scale may react with air (oxygen) and moisture to form sulfur acids
(polythionic acid).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Material - The material must be in a susceptible or “sensitized” condition.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Stress - Residual or applied.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Affected alloys become sensitized during exposure to elevated temperatures during manufacture,
welding or high temperature service. “Sensitization” refers to the composition/time/temperature
dependent formation of chromium carbide in the grain boundaries of the metal.  Sensitization occurs
in the 750 o F to1500 o F (400°C to 815°C) temperature range.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The carbon content and the thermal history of the alloy have a significant effect on sensitization
susceptibility.  Regular and controlled carbon grades of stainless steels such as types 304/304H and
316/316H are particularly susceptible to sensitizing in the weld HAZ.  Low carbon ”L” grades (<
0.03% C) are less susceptible and usually can be welded without sensitizing.  The L grades will not
sensitize provided long term operating temperatures do not exceed about 750°F (399 o C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Residual stresses in most components are usually sufficient to promote cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.1.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All units where sensitized alloys are used in sulfur-containing environments.  Commonly damaged
equipment includes heat exchanger tubes, furnace tubes and piping.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Fired heaters burning oil, gas, coke and most other sources of fuel may be affected depending on
sulfur levels in the fuel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Severe cases have been found in FCC units (air rings, plenums, slide valves, cyclone components,
expansion joint bellows and piping).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In hydroprocessing units (heater tubes, hot feed/effluent exchanger tubes, bellows).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Crude and coker units (piping).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Boilers and high temperature equipment exposed to sulfur-containing combustion products.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute

Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST

<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_302>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-50
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.1.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Typically occurs next to welds, but can also occur in the base metal ( Figure 5-24 ).  It is usually quite
localized and may not be evident until a leak appears during start-up or, in some cases, operation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracking propagates intergranularly ( Figure 5-25 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Corrosion or loss in thickness is usually negligible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.1.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
If equipment will be opened or exposed to air, preventive measures should be taken to minimize or
eliminate PASCC include flushing the equipment with alkaline or soda ash solution to neutralize
sulfur acids immediately after or during shutdown or purging with dry nitrogen or nitrogen/ammonia
during the shutdown to prevent air exposure.  Refer to guidelines in NACE RP0170.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
For furnaces, keep the firebox heated above the dewpoint to prevent acids from forming on heater
tubes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Low carbon grades such as 304L/316L/317L provide some measure of improvement over controlled
carbon grades.  The L grades will sensitize if exposed more than several hours above about 1000 o F
(538 o C) or long term above 750 o F (400 o C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Improved resistance to PASCC cracking can be achieved with modified versions of these alloys
containing small amounts of Ti and Nb.  Typically used are the chemically stabilized grades
(austenitic stainless steel types 321 and 347 and nickel base Alloys 825 and 625).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
ASTM specifications allow mill products to be shipped in a stabilized condition rather than solution
annealed.  This heat treatment will minimize potential sensitization problems especially with type
321.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
A thermal stabilization heat treatment at 1650 o F (899 o C) may be applied to chemically stabilized
austenitic stainless steel welds after all welding is complete in an attempt to reduce sensitization and
PTA susceptibility.  This heat treatment is difficult to apply in the field.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Susceptibility to PASCC can be determined by laboratory corrosion testing according to ASTM A262
Practice C.  A sensitizing heat treatment is often applied to L and/or chemically stabilized grades
prior to testing.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.1.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
PT examination can be used to detect PASCC cracking ( Figure 5-24  through  Figure 5-28 ). However,
because the cracks are filled with a tight deposit, flapper disc sanding may be needed to improve the
PT sensitivity.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
PASCC cracking can be an inspection challenge because the cracking may not occur until well into a
turnaround.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Monitoring for PASCC cracking during operation is not usually practical. Conditions causing the
cracking are not usually present while operating.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.1.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Also known as Polythionic Acid Stress Corrosion Cracking (PTA SCC), Intergranular Corrosion (IGC) and
Intergranular Attack (IGA).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_307>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-55
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.2
Amine Stress Corrosion Cracking<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.2.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Amine cracking is a common term applied to the cracking of steels under the combined action of
tensile stress and corrosion in aqueous alkanolamine systems used to remove/absorb H 2 S and/or
CO 2  and their mixtures from various gas and liquid hydrocarbon streams.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Amine cracking is a form of alkaline stress corrosion cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
It is most often found at or adjacent to non-PWHT’d carbon steel weldments or in highly cold worked
parts.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Amine cracking should not be confused with several other types of SCC that can occur in amine
environments which are further described in  5.1.2.3  and  5.1.2.5 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.2.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>Carbon steel and low alloy steels.<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.2.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The critical factors are the level of tensile stress, amine concentration and temperature.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracking is associated with residual stresses from welding, cold working or fabrication that have not
been removed through an effective stress-relieving heat treatment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Cracking is more likely to occur in lean MEA and DEA services but is also found in most amines
including MDEA and DIPA (ADIP).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Cracking has been reported down to ambient temperatures with some amines. Increasing
temperature and stress levels increases the likelihood and severity of cracking.  Refer to API RP 945
for guidelines on PWHT requirements for various amine services.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Amine cracking is most often associated with lean amine services.  The pure alkanolamine does not
cause cracking. Cracking in rich amine services are most often associated with wet H2S problems
(see  5.1.2.3 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Cracking can occur in non-PWHT’d piping and equipment as a result exposure to steamout and to
short-term amine carryover.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
Amine concentration does not appear to have a significant effect on the propensity for cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>h)
Some refiners believe cracking will not occur below an amine concentration of about 2% to 5%.
However, local enrichment and steamout can reduce this limit and some plants have used lower
limits down to 0.2%.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.2.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>All non-PWHT carbon steel piping and equipment in lean amine service including contactors, absorbers,
strippers, regenerators and heat exchangers as well as any equipment subject to amine carryover.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.2.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Amine cracking results in surface breaking flaws that initiate on the ID of piping and equipment
primarily in the weld HAZ but has also been found in weld metal and high stress areas adjacent to
the HAZ.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracking typically develops parallel to the weld and there may be parallel cracks.  In weld metal, the
cracks are either transverse or longitudinal with the weld.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
At set-on nozzles, the cracks are radial in the base metal, i.e., they fan out from the bore.  At set-in
nozzles, the cracks are usually parallel to the weld.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_308>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-56
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
The appearance of the cracks on the surface may be similar to those caused by wet H 2 S cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Since the driving force for cracking is residual stress, cracks are often found on the process side,
opposite external attachment welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Positive identification of amine cracking can be confirmed by metallographic analysis.  The cracking
is typically intergranular, oxide filled with some branching ( Figure 5-29  through  Figure 5-32 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.2.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
PWHT all carbon steel welds in piping and equipment in accordance with API RP 945.  The same
requirement applies to repair welds and to internal and external attachment welds ( Figure 5-33 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Use solid or clad stainless steel, Alloy 400 or other corrosion resistant alloys in lieu of carbon steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Water wash non-PWHT carbon steel piping and equipment prior to welding, heat treatment or
steamout.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.2.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Although cracks may be seen visually, crack detection is best performed with WFMT or ACFM
techniques.  Surface preparation by grit blasting, high pressure water blasting or other methods is
required for WFMT but may not be necessary for ACFM.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
PT is usually not effective in finding tight and/or scale filled cracks and should not be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
If the cracks have minimum branching, crack depths can be measured with a suitable UT technique
including external SWUT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
AET can also be used for monitoring crack growth and locating growing cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.2.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Amine cracking is more properly termed amine stress corrosion cracking and is a form of Alkaline Stress
Corrosion Cracking (ASCC).  Caustic stress corrosion cracking (see  4.5.3 ) and carbonate stress
corrosion cracking (see  5.1.2.5 ) are two other forms of ASCC that are similar in appearance.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.2.2.9
References
1. API Recommended Practice 945, Avoiding Environmental Cracking in Amine Units, American
Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.
2. “Fitness-For-Service Evaluation Procedures for Operating Pressure Vessels, Tanks, and Piping in
Refinery and Chemical Service.” Materials Properties Council, FS-26, Draft  No. 5,Consultants
Report, NY, 1995.
3. J. Gutzeit and J.M. Johnson, “Stress Corrosion Cracking of Carbon Steel Welds in Amine Service,”
Materials Performance, Vol. 25, No.7, 1986, p.18.
4. J.P. Richert et al, “Stress Corrosion Cracking of Carbon Steel in Amine Systems,” Paper No. 187,
CORROSION/87, NACE International, Houston, TX, 1987.
5. Bagdasarian et al, “Stress Corrosion Cracking of Carbon Steel in DEA and ADIP Solutions,” Materials
Performance, 1991, pp. 63-67.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_312>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-60
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.3
Wet H 2 S Damage (Blistering/HIC/SOHIC/SSC)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.3.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This section describes four types of damage that result in blistering and/or cracking of carbon steel and
low alloy steels in wet H 2 S environments.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Hydrogen Blistering<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Hydrogen blisters may form as surface bulges on the ID, the OD or within the wall thickness of a pipe
or pressure vessel.  The blister results from hydrogen atoms that form during the sulfide corrosion
process on the surface of the steel, that diffuse into the steel, and collect at a discontinuity in the
steel such as an inclusion or lamination.  The hydrogen atoms combine to form hydrogen molecules
that are too large to diffuse out and the pressure builds to the point where local deformation occurs,
forming a blister.  Blistering results from hydrogen generated by corrosion, not hydrogen gas from
the process stream.  ( Figure 5-34  and  Figure 5-35 .)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Hydrogen blisters can form at many different depths from the surface of the steel, in the middle of the
plate or near a weld.  In some cases, neighboring or adjacent blisters that are at slightly different
depths (planes) may develop cracks that link them together.  Interconnecting cracks between the
blisters often have a stair step appearance, and so HIC is sometimes referred to as “stepwise
cracking” ( Figure 5-36 ,  Figure 5-37  and  Figure 5-38 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Stress Oriented Hydrogen Induced Cracking (SOHIC)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SOHIC is similar to HIC but is a potentially more damaging form of cracking which appears as arrays
of cracks stacked on top of each other.  The result is a through-thickness crack that is perpendicular
to the surface and is driven by high levels of stress (residual or applied).  They usually appear in the
base metal adjacent to the weld heat affected zones where they initiate from HIC damage or other
cracks or defects including sulfide stress cracks ( Figure 5-39  and  Figure 5-40 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Sulfide Stress Cracking (SSC)<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Sulfide Stress Cracking (SSC) is defined as cracking of metal under the combined action of tensile
stress and corrosion in the presence of water and H 2 S.  SSC is a form of hydrogen stress cracking
resulting from absorption of atomic hydrogen that is produced by the sulfide corrosion process on the
metal surface.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>SSC can initiate on the surface of steels in highly localized zones of high hardness in the weld metal
and heat affected zones.  Zones of high hardness can sometimes be found in weld cover passes and
attachment welds which are not tempered (softened) by subsequent passes.  PWHT is beneficial in
reducing the hardness and residual stresses that render steel susceptible to SSC.  High strength
steels are also susceptible to SSC but these are only used in limited applications in the refining
industry.  ( Figure 5-42  and  Figure 5-43 ).  Some carbon steels contain residual elements that form
hard areas in the heat affected zones that will not temper at normal stress relieving temperatures.
Using preheat helps minimize these hardness problems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.3.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel and low alloy steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.3.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The most important variables that affect and differentiate the various forms of wet H 2 S damage are
environmental conditions (pH, H 2 S level, contaminants, temperature), material properties (hardness,
microstructure, strength) and tensile stress level (applied or residual).  These factors are outlined
below.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_313>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-61
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
All of these damage mechanisms are related to the absorption and permeation of hydrogen in steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
pH<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Hydrogen permeation or diffusion rates have been found to be minimal at pH 7 and
increase at both higher and lower pH.  The presence of hydrogen cyanide (HCN) in the
water phase significantly increases permeation in alkaline (high pH) sour water.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Conditions which are known to promote blistering, HIC, SOHIC and SSC are those
containing free water (in liquid phase) and:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
>50 wppm dissolved H 2 S in the free water, or
•
free water with pH <4 and some dissolved H 2 S present, or
•
free water with pH >7.6 and 20 wppm dissolved hydrogen cyanide (HCN) in the water
and some dissolved H 2 S present, or
•
>0.0003 MPa (0.05 psia) partial pressure of H 2 S in the gas phase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Increasing levels of ammonia may push the pH higher into the range where cracking can
occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
H 2 S<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Hydrogen permeation increases with increasing H 2 S partial pressure due to a concurrent
increase in the H 2 S concentration in the water phase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
An arbitrary value of 50 wppm H 2 S in the water phase is often used as the defining
concentration where wet H 2 S damage becomes a problem. However, there are cases
where cracking has occurred at lower concentrations or during upset conditions where wet
H 2 S was not ordinarily anticipated. The presence of as little as 1 wppm of H 2 S in the water
has been found to be sufficient to cause hydrogen charging of the steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Susceptibility to SSC increases with increasing H 2 S partial pressures above about 0.05 psi
(0.0003 Mpa) H 2 S in steels with a tensile strength above about 90 ksi or in steels with
localized zones of weld or weld HAZ hardness above 237 HB.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
Temperature<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Blistering, HIC, and SOHIC damage have been found to occur between ambient and 300 o F
(150 o C) or higher.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
SSC generally occurs below about 180 o F (82 o C).  However, equipment operating above this
temperature are susceptible to SSC if there is an aqueous phase with H 2 S as outlined
above.  Some  susceptible  equipment  can  fail even during short sour water excursions
such as those encountered during equipment shutdowns.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Hydrogen charging potential increases with increasing temperature if the aqueous phase is
not eliminated by elevated temperature.  Elevated temperature promotes  dissociation  of
H 2 S  (thereby producing  more  monatomic  hydrogen), together with an increase in the
diffusion rates of hydrogen in metals, resulting in increased level of hydrogen charging.
However, the SSC cracking potential is maximized at near-ambient temperature. This
distinction is important because metals can become charged during high-temperature
exposure and subsequently crack during excursions to lower temperatures (Reference 8).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Hardness<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Hardness is primarily an issue with SSC.  Typical low-strength carbon steels used in
refinery applications should be controlled to produce weld hardness <200 HB in accordance
with NACE RP0472.  These steels are not generally susceptible to SSC unless localized
zones of hardness above 237 HB are present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
The time to failure by SSC decreases as material strength, applied tensile   stress, and
environmental charging potential increase.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_314>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-62
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Blistering, HIC and SOHIC damage are not related to steel hardness.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Steelmaking<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Blistering and HIC damage are strongly affected by the presence of inclusions and
laminations which provide sites for diffusing hydrogen to accumulate.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Steel chemistry and manufacturing methods also affect susceptibility and can be tailored to
produce the HIC resistant steels outlined in NACE Publication 8X194.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Improving steel cleanliness and processing to minimize blistering and HIC damage may still
leave the steel susceptible to SOHIC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
The disadvantage is that an absence of visual blistering may leave a false sense of security
that H 2 S damage is not active yet subsurface SOHIC damage may be present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
HIC is often found in so-called “dirty” steels with high levels of inclusions or other internal
discontinuities from the steel-making process.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6)
PWHT<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
Blistering and HIC damage develop without applied or residual stress so that PWHT will not
prevent them from occurring.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
High local stresses or notch-like discontinuities such as shallow sulfide stress cracks can
serve as initiation sites for SOHIC.  PWHT is highly effective in preventing or eliminating
SSC by reduction of both hardness and residual stress.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>•
SOHIC is driven by localized stresses so that PWHT is also somewhat effective in reducing
SOHIC damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.3.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Blistering, HIC, SOHIC and SSC damage can occur throughout the refinery wherever there is a wet
H 2 S environment present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
In hydroprocessing units, increasing concentration of ammonium bisulfide above 2% increases the
potential for blistering, HIC and SOHIC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Cyanides significantly increase the probability and severity of blistering, HIC and SOHIC damage.
This is especially true for the vapor recovery sections of the fluid catalytic cracking and delayed
coking units.  Typical locations include fractionator overhead drums, fractionation towers, absorber
and stripper towers, compressor interstage separators and knockout drums and various heat
exchangers, condensers, and coolers. Sour water stripper and amine regenerator overhead systems
are especially prone to wet H 2 S damage because of generally high ammonia bisulfide concentrations
and cyanides.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
SSC is most likely found in hard weld and heat affected zones and in high strength components
including bolts, relief valve springs, 400 Series SS valve trim, compressor shafts, sleeves and
springs.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.3.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All four forms of wet H 2 S damage are best illustrated though the pictures and diagrams shown in
Figure 5-34  through  Figure 5-43 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Hydrogen blisters appear as bulges on the ID or OD surface of the steel and can be found anywhere
in the shell plate or head of a pressure vessel.  Blistering has been found on rare occasions in pipe
and very rarely in the middle of a weld.  HIC damage can occur wherever blistering or subsurface
laminations are present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In pressure-containing equipment, SOHIC and SSC damage is most often associated with the
weldments.  SSC can also be found at any location where zones of high hardness are found in
vessels or in high strength steel components.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>

| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |

<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_315>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-63
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.3.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Effective barriers that protect the surface of the steel from the wet H 2 S environment can prevent
damage including alloy cladding and coatings.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Process changes that affect the pH of the water phase and/or ammonia or cyanide concentration can
help to reduce damage.  A common practice is to utilize wash water injection to dilute the HCN
concentration, for example, in FCC gas plants. Cyanides can be converted to harmless thiocyanates
by injecting dilute streams of ammonium polysulfides. Injection facilities require careful design.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
HIC-resistant steels can be used to minimize the susceptibility to blistering and HIC damage.
Detailed materials and fabrication guidance can be found in NACE Publication 8X194.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
SSC can generally be prevented by limiting the hardness of welds and heat affected zones to 200
HB maximum through preheat, PWHT, weld procedures and control of carbon equivalents.
Depending on the service environment, small zones of hardness up to 22 HRC should be resistant to
SSC.   Refer to NACE RP0472 for additional details.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
PWHT can also help to minimize susceptibility to SOHIC.  PWHT has limited value in preventing
blistering and HIC damage from initiating but is beneficial in reducing residual stresses and strength
levels that might otherwise contribute to crack propagation.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Specialized corrosion inhibitors can be used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.3.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Process conditions should be evaluated by process engineers and corrosion/materials specialists to
identify piping and equipment where conditions are most likely to promote wet H 2 S damage.  Field
sampling of the free water phase should be performed on a periodic or as-needed basis to monitor
conditions or changes in conditions, particularly if water washing or polysulfide injection is used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Inspection for wet H 2 S damage generally focuses on weld seams and nozzles.  Since the
consequences can be severe, refineries generally have a procedure to prioritize and execute
inspection for this type of damage.  General notes on inspection for wet H 2 S damage are included
below.  However, for the development of more detailed inspection plans including methods,
coverage and surface preparation, the reader is directed to extensive recommendations on detection
and repair outlined in NACE RP0296.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Although cracks may be seen visually, crack detection is best performed with WFMT, EC, RT or
ACFM techniques.  Surface preparation by grit blasting, high pressure water blasting or other
methods is usually required for WFMT but not for ACFM.  PT cannot find tight cracks and should not
be depended on.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
UT techniques including external SWUT can be used.  SWUT is especially useful for volumetric
inspection and crack sizing. Electrical resistance instruments are not effective for measuring crack
depth.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Grinding out the crack or removal by thermal arc gouging is a viable method of crack depth
determination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
AET can be used for monitoring crack growth.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.3.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
SSC is a form of hydrogen stress cracking (hydrogen embrittlement).  Refer to  4.5.6 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Amine cracking (see  5.1.2.2 ) and carbonate cracking (see  5.1.2.5 ) can also occur in wet H 2 S
environments, may be similar in appearance, and are sometimes confused with the various forms of
wet H 2 S damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001

Petroleum Refinery Pressure Vessels in Wet H2S Environments, NACE International, Houston, TX.

Tanks, and Piping in Refinery and Chemical Service, Draft 5, October 1995, Materials Properties
Council, NY, 1995.
3. G.M. Buchheim, “Ways to Deal With Wet H2S Cracking Revealed by Study,” Oil and Gas Journal,
July 9, 1990, pp. 92-96.

International, Houston, TX, 1995.

Carbon Steel Weldments in Corrosive Petroleum Refining Environments, NACE International,
Houston, TX.

H2S Refinery Service, NACE International, Houston, TX.

Weldments,” NACE International, Houston, TX, 1996.

Refining Environments, NACE International, Houston, TX.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>5-70
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.4
Hydrogen Stress Cracking - HF<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.4.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Hydrogen Stress Cracking is a form of environmental cracking that can initiate on the surface of high
strength low alloy steels and carbon steels with highly localized zones of high hardness in the weld metal
and HAZ as a result of exposure to aqueous HF acid environments.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.4.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel and low alloy steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.4.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Steel hardness, strength and stress are the critical factors.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Susceptibility increases with increasing hardness. Hardness levels above Rockwell C 22 (237 BHN)
are highly susceptible. Time-to-failure decreases as the hardness increases (higher strength
materials).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Under high levels of applied or residual tensile stress (from cold-forming or welding) embrittlement
results in cracking of susceptible steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Cracking may occur very rapidly, within hours after exposure to the HF environment, or considerable
time may pass before cracking initiates.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Hard microstructures may arise in welds, particularly in low heat input welds in the heat affected
zones, in low alloy steels, or may result from inadequate heat treatment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.4.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
All piping and equipment exposed to HF acid at any concentration with hardness levels above the
recommended limit are subject to hydrogen stress cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
High strength low alloy steels such as ASTM A193-B7 bolts and compressor components are
susceptible.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
ASTM A193B7M bolts are also susceptible if overtorqued.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.4.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
This mode of cracking can only be confirmed by metallographic examination.  The cracking will be
intergranular.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Produces surface breaking cracks, usually associated with weldments.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.4.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
PWHT is beneficial in reducing the hardness and residual stresses that render a steel susceptible to
SSC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Typical low-strength carbon steels used in refinery applications should be controlled to produce weld
hardness <200 HB in accordance with NACE SP0472.  These steels are not generally susceptible to
SCC unless localized zones of hardness above 237 HB are present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Use carbon steels with Carbon Equivalents (CE) less than 0.43. Where CE is defined as:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>CE = %C + %Mn/6+ %(Cr + Mo + V)/5 + %(Cu + Ni)/15<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
ASTM A193 grade B7M bolts are softer and lower strength than B7 bolts and are more resistant to
cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Alloy cladding or nonmetallic coatings that provide an effective barrier and protect the surface of the
steel from hydrogen permeation will prevent cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,`<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute ,,,                            |
|:----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API ``,                            |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS `,`` |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_323>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-71
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Alloy 400 is not susceptible to this form of cracking but may be susceptible to intergranular stress
corrosion cracking, particularly in the non-stress relieved condition (see  5.1.1.6 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.4.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Surface breaking cracks can be found by WFMT.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Hardness testing is the best method to determine the susceptibility of suspect material.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Zones of high hardness can sometimes be found on the process side in weld cover passes and
attachment welds that are not tempered (softened) by subsequent passes.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.4.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This is the same mechanism that is responsible for sulfide stress corrosion cracking in wet H 2 S
environments except that HF acid is generating the hydrogen.  Blistering, HIC and SOHIC damage is
similar to that found in wet H 2 S (see  5.1.2.3 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.2.4.9
References
1. J. D. Dobis, D. R. Clarida and J. P. Richert, “Survey Reveals Nature of Corrosion in HF Alkylation
Units,” Oil and Gas Journal, March 6, 1995, Vol. 93, No.10, pp. 63-68.
2. ASM Metals Handbook, “Corrosion in Petroleum Refining and Petrochemical Operations,” Volume 13,
ASM International, Materials Park, OH.
3. NACE SP0472, Methods and Controls to Prevent in-Service Environmental Cracking of Carbon Steel
Weldments in Corrosive Petroleum Refining Environments, NACE International, Houston, TX.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PAGE_324>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-72
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.5
Carbonate Stress Corrosion Cracking (ACSCC)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.5.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbonate stress corrosion cracking (often referred to as carbonate cracking) is the term applied to
surface breaking cracks that occur adjacent to carbon steel welds under the combined action of tensile
stress in systems containing a free water phase with carbonate, where some amount of H 2 S is also
present.  It is a form of Alkaline Stress Corrosion Cracking (ACSCC).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>This type of damage has also been observed in other environments which are outside the scope of this
discussion.  Those environments include the outside surface of buried pipelines; and piping and
equipment containing aqueous carbonate solutions   (e.g., potassium carbonate) used in the carbon
dioxide (CO 2 ) removal facilities associated with hydrogen reformers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.5.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbon steel and low alloy steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.5.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
The residual stress level of carbon steel and the water chemistry are the critical factors that
determine the likelihood of carbonate cracking.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Carbonate stress corrosion cracking can occur at relatively low levels of residual stress but usually
occurs at welds or cold worked areas that have not been stress relieved.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Additional details of water chemistry affecting susceptibility in FCC units are outlined below.  More
detailed information can be found in a NACE industry review published in 2008 (Reference 4).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Water - In all areas in which ACSCC has been reported, there has been a separate liquid water
phase present.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
pH - The pH of the sour water is a critical factor; most failures have occurred in the range of pH
8 to 10.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
H 2 S – Cracking occurs where alkaline water is present.  Although H 2 S is often present, no
threshold level has been established.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Ammonia - NH 3  in the sour water is usually higher in cases  where ACSCC  has been observed
than in cases with no ACSCC (e.g., 4,800 ppmw vs. 2,500 pmmw).  Increasing NH 3  and
decreasing H 2 S together increase the likelihood   of ACSCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5)
Carbonate ion concentration – Cracking occurs above a certain threshold concentration.  It has
been suggested that levels above 100 ppmw can cause ACSCC, depending on the pH of the
system.  However, specific guidelines are difficult to define, largely as a result of the difficulty of
sampling for carbonate ions and the lack of available data.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>6)
Cyanides – Cracking can occur with or without the presence of cyanides.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>7)
Polysulfides - There is  no  evidence  to suggest  that ammonium polysulfide injection increases
or  decreases the potential for ACSCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
FCCU feed quality and unit operation appear to have an effect on cracking susceptibility:<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>1)
Feed Nitrogen - The  total  nitrogen in FCCU feed is usually higher  in  cases  where  ACSCC
has been observed than  in  cases  with  no  ACSCC  (e.g., 2,645 ppmw   vs.  940 ppmw).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>2)
Feed Sulfur – In general, cracking is associated with low sulfur FCCU feeds as opposed to high
sulfur feeds.  Susceptibility to cracking appears to be much more likely with hydrotreated feed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>3)
N to S ratio – Most cases of ACSCC have been associated with N/S ratio in the FCCU feed of 0
to 70<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_325>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-73
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>4)
Full burn vs. partial burn – The likelihood of cracking occurring in the FCC Regenerator partial-
burn mode is approximately the same as full burn mode.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
In CO 2  removal units, cracking may occur when the CO 2  content is above 2% and temperatures
exceed 200 o F (93 o C).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.5.4
Affected Units or Equipment<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbonate cracking has been most prevalent in the fluid catalytic cracking unit main fractionator
overhead condensing and reflux system, the downstream wet gas compression system, and the sour
water systems emanating from these areas.  Both piping and vessels are affected.  See  Figure 5-44
and  5-45  for typical locations where cracking has occurred.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Carbonate cracking has also been observed in SWS units of the side-pumparound type in the
pumparound return line to the SWS tower; on the OD (process side) of highly cold worked SA179
condenser tube u-bends; and in the floor of tank storing sour water from an FCC unit.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Carbonate cracking has also occurred in piping and equipment in potassium carbonate in Catacarb
and CO 2  removal facilities of hydrogen manufacturing units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.5.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Carbonate cracking typically propagates parallel to the weld in the heat-affected zone, or adjacent
base metal within 2 inches (50 mm) of the weld.  At least two cases have been reported to occur
more than 3 inches away (80 mm) in highly cold worked fittings including an elbow and reducer.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracking can also occur in the weld deposit.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The pattern of cracking observed on the steel surface is sometimes described as a spider web of
small cracks, which often initiate at or interconnect with weld-related flaws that serve as local stress
raisers.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
These cracks may be easily mistaken for SSC or SOHIC, however, the carbonate cracks are usually
further from the toe of the weld and have multiple parallel cracks ( Figure 5-46  to  Figure 5-47 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Carbonate cracks are surface breaking flaws that are predominantly intergranular in nature and
typically occur in as-welded carbon steel fabrications as a network of very fine, oxide-filled cracks
similar in appearance to caustic stress corrosion cracking and amine stress corrosion cracking.  See
Figures 5-48  to  Figure 5-55 .<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.5.6
Prevention / Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Application of a post-fabrication stress-relieving heat treatment of 1200 o F to 1225°F (649 o C to
663 o C) in accordance with WRC 452 (Reference 8) is a proven method of preventing carbonate
cracking.  Heat treatment requirements apply to repair welds as well as internal and external
attachment welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Cracking can be eliminated through the use of effective barrier coatings, solid or clad 300 Series SS,
Alloy 400 or other corrosion resistant alloys in lieu of carbon steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Water wash non-PWHT piping and equipment prior to steamout or heat treatment in hot carbonate
systems.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
A metavanadate inhibitor can be used in hot carbonate systems in CO 2  removal units in hydrogen
manufacturing units to prevent cracking.  Proper dosing and oxidation of the inhibitor must be
maintained.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.5.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Monitoring the pH of FCC sour waters is the fastest and most practical and cost effective method to
locate areas where there is a potential for ASCC to occur.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_326>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-74
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The cracking can involve sporadic and rapid growth, depending on subtle changes in the process.
Periodic monitoring of CO3 -2  concentration in FCC sour waters should be done to determine
cracking susceptibility.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Although cracks may be seen visually, crack detection is best performed with WFMT or ACFM
techniques.  Surface preparation by grit blasting, high pressure water blasting or other methods is
usually required for WFMT.  PT usually cannot find tight or scale filled cracks and should not be
used.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
There is usually much branching so crack depths may be measured with a suitable UT technique
including external SWUT.  Electrical resistance type instruments that measure crack depth are not
effective because  the cracks typically contain magnetic iron oxide.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
This cracking is not susceptible to extension by grinding.  Grinding out the cracks is a viable method
of crack depth determination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
AET can be used for monitoring crack growth and locating growing cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.2.5.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Carbonate cracking is more properly termed carbonate stress corrosion cracking and is a form of Alkaline
Stress Corrosion Cracking (ASCC).  Amine cracking (see  5.1.2.2 ) and caustic stress corrosion cracking
(see  4.5.3 ) are two other similar forms of ASCC.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.2.5.9
References
1. J.H. Kmetz and D.J. Truax, “Carbonate Stress Corrosion Cracking of Carbon Steel in Refinery FCC
Main Fractionator Overhead Systems,” CORROSION/90, Paper No. 206, NACE International,
Houston, TX, 1990.
2. H.U. Schutt, “Intergranular Wet Hydrogen Sulfide Cracking,” CORROSION/92, Paper No. 454, NACE
International, Houston, TX, 1992.
3. E. Mirabel et al, “Carbonate-type Cracking in an FCC Wet Gas Compressor Station,” Materials
Performance, July, 1991, pp. 41-45.
4. NACE Standard RP0296, “Guidelines for Detection, Repair and Mitigation of Cracking of Existing
Petroleum Refinery Pressure Vessels in Wet H2S Environments, NACE International, Houston, TX.
5. NACE Publication 34108, Review and Survey of Alkaline Carbonate Stress Corrosion Cracking in
Refinery Sour Water, NACE International, Houston, TX, 2008.
6. M. Rivera et al., “Carbonate Cracking Risk Assessment for an FCCU Gas Plant”,  Paper #04639,
NACE International, Houston, TX, 2004.
7. D. Milton et al., , FCCU Light Ends Plant Carbonate Stress Corrosion Cracking Experience, Paper
#07564, NACE International, Houston, TX, 2007.
8. WRC Bulletin 452, “Recommended Practices for  Local  Heating  of  Welds  in  Pressure  Vessels”
9. Welding Research Council (WRC), Shaker Heights, OH.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |

<<PAGE_335>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-83
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3
Other Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3.1
High Temperature Hydrogen Attack (HTHA)<<HEADING_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3.1.1
Description of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
High temperature hydrogen attack results from exposure to hydrogen at elevated temperatures and
pressures.  The hydrogen reacts with carbides in steel to form methane (CH 4 ) which cannot diffuse
through the steel.  The loss of carbide causes an overall loss in strength.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Methane pressure builds up, forming bubbles or cavities, microfissures and fissures that may
combine to form cracks.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
Failure can occur when the cracks reduce the load carrying ability of the pressure containing part.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3.1.2
Affected Materials<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>In order of increasing resistance: carbon steel, C-0.5Mo, Mn-0.5Mo, 1Cr-0.5Mo, 1.25Cr-0.5Mo, 2.25Cr-
1Mo, 2.25Cr-1Mo-V, 3Cr-1Mo, 5Cr-0.5Mo and similar steels with variations in chemistry.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3.1.3
Critical Factors<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
For a specific material, HTHA is dependent on temperature, hydrogen partial pressure, time and
stress. Service exposure time is cumulative.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
HTHA is preceded by a period of time when no noticeable change in properties is detectable by
normal inspection techniques.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
The incubation period is the time period during which enough damage has occurred to be measured
with available inspection techniques and may vary from hours at very severe conditions to many
years.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
Figure 5-56  contains curves that show a temperature/hydrogen partial pressure safe operating
envelope for carbon and low alloy steels. Additional information on HTHA can be found in API RP
941.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
The curves are reasonably conservative for carbon steel up to about 10,000 psi hydrogen partial
pressure.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
300 Series SS, as well as 5Cr, 9Cr and 12 Cr alloys, are not susceptible to HTHA at conditions
normally seen in refinery units.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3.1.4
Affected Units<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Hydroprocessing units, such as hydrotreaters (desulfurizers) and hydrocrackers, catalytic reformers,
hydrogen producing units and hydrogen cleanup units, such as pressure swing absorption units, are
all susceptible to HTHA.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Boiler tubes in very high pressure steam service.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3.1.5
Appearance or Morphology of Damage<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
HTHA can be confirmed through the use of specialized techniques including metallographic analysis
of damaged areas as described below.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
The hydrogen/carbon reaction can cause surface decarburization of steel. If the diffusion of carbon
to the surface is limiting, the reaction can result in internal decarburization, methane formation and
cracking ( Figures 5-57  to  5-59 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
In the early stages of HTHA, bubbles/cavities can be detected in samples by a scanning microscope,
although it may be difficult to tell the difference between HTHA cavities and creep cavities. Some
refinery services expose low alloy steels to both HTHA and creep conditions.  Early stages of HTHA
can only be confirmed through advanced metallographic analysis of damaged areas.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<TABLE_1>>
| Copyright American Petroleum Institute                           |
|:-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| Provided by IHS under license with API                           |
| No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<TABLE_2>>
| Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001   |
|:-------------------------------------------------------|
| Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST                |
<<TABLE_END>>
<<PAGE_END>>
<<PAGE_336>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5-84
API Recommended Practice 571
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In later stages of damage, decarburization and/or fissures can be seen by examining samples under
a microscope and may sometimes be seen by in-situ metallography ( Figure 5-60  and  5-61 ).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Cracking and fissuring are intergranular and occur adjacent to pearlite (iron carbide) areas in carbon
steels.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Some blistering may be visible to the naked eye, due to either molecular hydrogen or methane
accumulating in laminations in the steel.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3.1.6
Prevention/Mitigation<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Use alloy steels with chromium and molybdenum to increase carbide stability thereby minimizing
methane formation.  Other carbide stabilizing elements include tungsten and vanadium.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Normal design practice is to use a 25 o F to 50 o F (14 o C to 28 o C) safety factor approach when using
the API RP 941 curves.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
While the curves have served the industry well, there have been several failures of C-0.5Mo steels in
refinery service under conditions that were previously considered safe. C-0.5Mo carbide stability
under HTHA conditions may be due at least in part to the different carbides formed during the
various heat treatments applied to the fabricated equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
As a result of the problems with the 0.5 Mo alloy steels, its curve has been removed from the main
set of curves and the material is not  recommended for new construction in hot hydrogen services.
For existing equipment, this concern has prompted an economic review of inspection cost versus
replacement with a more suitable alloy.  Inspection is very difficult because problems have occurred
in weld heat affected zones as well as base metal away from welds.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
300 Series SS overlay and/or roll bond clad material is used in hydrogen service where the base
metal does not have adequate sulfidation resistance.  Although it is recognized that properly
metallurgically bonded austenitic overlay/clad will decrease the hydrogen partial pressure seen by
the underlying metal, most refiners make sure the base metal has adequate resistance to HTHA
under service conditions.  In some cases, refiners take the decrease in partial pressure into account
when evaluating the need for hydrogen outgassing while shutting down heavy wall equipment.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3.1.7
Inspection and Monitoring<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>a)
Damage may occur randomly in welds or weld heat affected zones as well as the base metal,
making monitoring and detection of HTHA in susceptible materials extremely difficult.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>b)
Ultrasonic techniques using a combination of velocity ratio and AUBT have been the most successful
in finding fissuring and/or serious cracking.  HTHA damage can only be found using these
techniques if damage has progressed to the point where microvoids would be visible at a
magnification of 1500X or lower, if a sample of the metal was removed for examination.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>c)
HTHA can occur in the base metal at locations remote from welds.  In clad vessels, in particular,
HTHA damage can occur in base metal at locations where cladding has become disbonded.  Bulging
of the cladding away from the underlying base metal may be a tell tale sign that HTHA has occurred.
Localized damage under cladding might be overlooked if inspection methods focus only on the weld
seams and nozzles (Reference 4).<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>d)
In-situ metallography can only detect microfissuring, fissuring and decarburization near the surface.
However, most equipment has decarburized surfaces due to the various heat treatments used during
fabrication.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>e)
Visual inspection for blisters on the inside surface may indicate methane formation and potential
HTHA.  However, HTHA may frequently occur without the formation of surface blisters.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>f)
Other conventional forms of inspection, including WFMT and RT, are severely limited in their ability
to detect anything except the advanced stages of damage where cracking has already developed.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>--`,,,``,`,````,``,``,````,,,``-`-`,,`,,`,`,,`---<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>g)
AET is not a proven method for the detection of damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>Copyright American Petroleum Institute
Provided by IHS under license with API
Licensee=GS Engineering & Construction Co/5948933001
Not for Resale, 11/18/2012 20:58:40 MST
No reproduction or networking permitted without license from IHS<<PARAGRAPH_END>>

<<PARAGRAPH>>Damage Mechanisms Affecting Fixed Equipment in the Refining Industry
5-85
_____________________________________________________________________________________________<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<HEADING level=3>>5.1.3.1.8
Related Mechanisms<<HEADING_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>A form of HTHA can occur in boiler tubes and is referred to by the fossil utility industry as hydrogen
damage.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
<<PARAGRAPH>>5.1.3.1.9
References
1. API RP 941, Steels for Hydrogen Service at Elevated Temperatures and Pressures in Petroleum
Refineries and Petrochemical Plants, American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C.
2. J. Vitovec, F.H., “The Growth Rate of Fissures During Hydrogen Attack of Steels,” API Division of
Refining, Vol. 44 {III} 1964, pp. 179-188.
3. Materials Property Council Report FS-26, “Fitness-for Service Evaluation Procedures for Operating
Pressure Vessels, Tanks, and Piping in Refinery and Chemical Service,” Draft 5, Materials Properties
Council, NY, 1995.
4. S. Decker et al., “Safe Operation of a High Temperature Hydrogen Attack Affected DHT Reactor”,
Paper #09339, NACE International, Houston, TX, 2009.<<PARAGRAPH_END>>
